PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Identification Cards
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows that whereas:
(1) Identification cards and numbers severely threaten our freedom to live unfettered by excessive bureaucratic surveillance;
(2) the Government has been unable to present any realistic justification for the introduction of ID cards and numbers.
We humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should reject any proposal to inflict ID cards and numbers on the freedom-loving people of Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we oppose the proposed Bill of Rights because this Bill will:
Provide the Government and its agencies opportunity to interfere with the practice of religion in this country,
Transfer to the Government powers not given or intended to be given by the Constitution,
Threaten our rights by making them subject to the will of this or any future Government,
Turn the Human Rights Commission into a political `Star Chamber' with unjustifiable power,
Abrogate Common Law and common liberty,
Set the state above the individual.
We the undersigned believe in democracy and freedom and earnestly entreat you to recognise that this Bill will undermine the fundamental basis of these.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should reject the Bill of Rights.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pine Gap: Defence Space Research Facility
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:

(1) The Agreement between the United States of America and Australia concerning the Joint Defence Space Research Facility at Pine Gap may be terminated by either Government on one year's notice from 19 October 1986.
(2) In the event of war between the United States and the Soviet Union, access by the United States to Pine Gap's facilities makes it a probable nuclear target.
(3) Access by all nations to Pine Gap's capacity to monitor and verify compliance with existing and future nuclear limitations treaties could contribute to world peace and security.
(4) The people of Australia are entitled to be consulted, through their representatives in Parliament, on any extension or modification of the Agreement affecting their lives, security and welfare.
And your petitioners humbly pray that:
(1) The Agreement between the United States and Australia concerning the Joint Defence Space Research Facility at Pine Gap be terminated one year from October 1986.

(2) Public discussion and inquiry be instituted into the feasibility of negotiating a new agreement with the United Nations during the International Year of Peace offering the verification facilities of the Pine Gap base to all nations.
(3) Any agreement concerning the future use of Pine Gap be referred to Parliament for ratification.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
Graduated family allowances are of important assistance to families with more than one child.
All family allowances, whether for one, two, three or more children, have not kept pace with inflation.
There are suggestions that all family allowances should be paid at the one flat rate. This would severely disadvantage families with more than one child.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should reject any suggestion that family allowances be paid at a flat rate and instead should ask the Federal Government to increase the value of existing payments.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Oil Prices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That the Hawke Government should;
Pass on the full benefit of lower international oil prices on 1 March 1986;
Not increase or extend fuel taxes; and
Maintain its tax cut commitments.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Hawke Government honour its commitment to the Import Parity Pricing policy.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Michael Baume (from 14 citizens) and Peter Baume (from 25 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Oil Prices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. Your petitioners most humbly pray:
(i) that the Hawke Labor Government pass on the full benefits of lower international oil prices on March 1st, 1986; and
(ii) that the Hawke Labor Government does not increase or extend fuel taxes
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Military and Intelligence Facilities in Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

1. The Watsonia Army Barracks contains electronic communication facilities, operated by Australian and American personnel, that gives the United States the ability to pin-point Soviet nuclear submarines, hidden in the Oceans.

2. This would make it possible for U.S. killer-submarines to destroy all Soviet nuclear submarines, while the U.S. nuclear submarines launch their missiles in a `first strike' attack. This makes Watsonia a potential nuclear target. A nuclear attack on Watsonia would have a disastrous effect on Melbourne.
3. The `joint U.S.-Australian' bases in Australia endanger rather than protect us. They also add a new menace to nuclear arms race, that must be stopped.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should close the `joint Australian-U.S.' electronic communication facilities in the Watsonia Army Barracks.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Cooney (from 180 citizens) and Robertson (from 270 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Film Censorship Board
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President, and members of the Senate of the Parliament of Australia assembled. We, the undersigned, plead that Parliament will legislate, or act in accordance with the present legislation to replace the current members of the Film Censorship Board who have admitted to Senator Harradine on 12 December 1984 as reported in the Senate Select Committee on Video Material (see attached extracts), that they are not applying either the blasphemy or obscenity tests as required under the provisions of the Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations, and that these persons be replaced by persons who will apply these and the other related test in accordance with the said Regulations. Your petitioners humbly pray that you will give this matter your earnest consideration.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:

That the proposed Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985 will endanger the Federal system in Australia, the State and Federal criminal justice systems, the State and Federal Police Force, the State and Federal education systems, the independence of the churches and religious associations, marriage and the family, children, the unborn, the handicapped, the aged and the infirm, employer and employee relationships and Australian society generally.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray: That your Honourable House defer debate on the Bill for twelve months and circulate the Bill for twelve months for the widest possible debate, scrutiny and discussion.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights and Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That the Bill of Rights will have the power to override and negate our Common Law within five years of its enactment.

2. Because the Bill of Rights is based on an International Covenant, this will take the control of our country out of the hands of the people and their democratically elected representatives, giving the power to those outside Australia.
Your petitioners therefore pray:
1. That the Senate rejects the Australian Bill of Rights and all cognate Bills.
2. That as our representatives, you protect our Australian heritage and christian culture and values, both in the education system, and through the media.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognise that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection, storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving `property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely:
(i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programmes,
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the draft Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that it is my intention to withdraw, immediately after Question Time and any matter of public importance or urgency motion today, Business of the Senate, notice of motion No. 2, standing in my name. Mr President, I seek leave to make a brief statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This ordinance increased very considerably the fees payable for taxi licences. The Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances was concerned that the retrospective operation of this ordinance could have prejudiced the rights of individuals who might have applied for taxi licences before the fees were increased. It would have been unfair for such persons to have had to pay the new fees in relation to applications lodged before those fees became operative. The Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) has informed the Committee that there was one such application lodged and that the new ordinance applied retrospectively to it.

SPEECH.PARA: However, in that case the Registrar of Motor Vehicles, having properly considered the application, has granted the licence to the individual concerned and recommended that he should not be prejudiced by the large fee increases. As I remember, it went from $250 to $80,000. The Minister has decided to remit part of the fee payable for the licence so that the individual does not have to pay more than he would have if the amending ordinance had not been made. This is a very important gesture by the Minister for Territories in which he recognises that delegated legislation should not retrospectively prejudice an individual's pre-existing application to pursue a particular livelihood. The Committee expresses its admiration of the Minister for his decisive action in this matter.

This is the last day on which the Senate could consider these issues, and thus, under standing order 109a, I will withdraw my notice at a later hour of this day. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard for the information of honourable senators copies of the Committee's correspondence on this matter.
Leave granted.
The correspondence read as follows-
15 April 1986
The Hon. Gordon Scholes, M.P.
Minister for Territories
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister,

At its meeting on 10 April 1986, the Committee considered the Motor Traffic (Amendment) Ordinance 1986, being A.C.T. Ordinance No. 3 of 1986 tabled in the Senate on 9 April 1986. The Committee is concerned about the dramatic increase in the cost of a taxi or hire car licence and the reviewability of decision to grant such licences.

The Ordinance provides, among other things, for the payment of $80,000 for the grant of a taxi licence and $60,000 for the grant of a hire car licence. The Ordinance also limits the number of such licences to 149 and 22 respectively, or such other higher number as the Minister determines. Two points may be made.

Firstly, the Explanatory Statement indicates that the Ordinance was not referred to the A.C.T. House of Assembly before it was made. It was believed that the publicity attendant on such a referral would have encouraged persons to lodge advance applications for licences in order to avoid the scheme. Perhaps you could explain to the Committee how the respective licences were granted prior to this Ordinance and how this system has been altered by the Amendment. The Committee would be grateful if you could also indicate whether any licence applications presently pending before the Registrar of Motor Vehicles will be affected by these intentionally unpublished changes.

Secondly, it appears that the three hundred fold increase in fees may not affect those persons who are already licence holders except to the extent of legislatively legitimating and encouraging current commercial dealing in personal licences. Thus, it may be that no existing rights are threatened or affected by the Ordinance. However, the Committee must satisfy itself under Principles (b), (c) and (d) of its terms of reference whether it is appropriate for delegated legislation to provide that the granting of individual licences to engage in a particular livelihood should rest in the apparently unreviewable and unstructured discretion of the Registrar of Motor Vehicles, and, from 27 March 1986, the date of gazettal, require as a precondition the payment of a fee 300 times greater than the fee that was required on and prior to 26 March 1986.
The Committee would be grateful if you could assist it by commenting and advising on these two points.
Yours sincerely,
BARNEY COONEY
Chairman
Senator Barney Cooney
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee
on Regulations & Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Cooney
I refer to your letter of 15 April 1986 about the Motor Traffic (Amendment) Ordinance (No. 3) 1986 of the Australian Capital Territory.

By way of background, the amending Ordinance is an interim one. It will be followed by legislation to implement a comprehensive review of the taxi and private hire car industry. That review is nearly complete, and is based on recommendations made by the House of Assembly, in consultation with the industry. The thrust of the reforms will be to partially deregulate the industry and in particular to make all licences transferable.

Prior to the amendment, the number of licences on issue from time to time was determined by reference to a policy which took into account economic considerations including the viability of the taxi industry, the livelihood of those in the industry and consumer demands, in addition to the safety of the travelling public. Under the new scheme, to which the amending Ordinance gives partial effect, the same factors will be taken into account, but by the Minister (as distinct from the Registrar).

The other major change to the system is the increase in the fee payable on the issue of a licence. The new fee is based upon the current market value of a transferable taxi licence and has been assessed at $80,000 on the basis of recent sales. (Of the 149 licences which are currently on issue, 80 are transferable. The remainder, which have been issued since the change in the law in 1975, are non-transferable.) The new fee will form a central element in the reforms to which I have referred.

Although not all licences will be transferable until the remainder of the package has been made law, the purpose of increasing the fee at this stage is to prevent profiteering; that is, to avoid the situation where a licence obtained now, for a nominal fee, could be converted into a substantial asset when licences are made transferable. Also, to prevent profiteering by existing non-transferable licence holders, it is intended that a fee representing 50% of the assessed market value will be payable under the future legislation as the premium for converting a non-transferable licence into a transferable one.

The new fees apply across the board and are not discretionary. Moreover, the amending Ordinance will make the rights of applicants neither more nor less dependent on the Registrar's powers. On the question of reviewability of decisions of the Registrar, I draw your attention to Section 104 of the principal Ordinance, which provides for review on the merits of the Registrar's decisions by the Court of Petty Sessions. Implementation of the balance of the recommendations for reform will involve the inclusion in the Ordinance of provisions whereby decisions about the grant of taxi and private hire car licences will be made subject to legislatively prescribed criteria.

At the time of making of the amending Ordinance there was one application outstanding under the former provisions. I am told that this application is currently the subject of an inquiry by the Ombudsman and that it is the Department's intention to deal with it having regard to any recommendation that may be made by the Ombudsman.

It is correct that the new fees do not affect the rights or existing licence holders. It is not correct that the new legislation legitimates or encourages (to use your words) unlawful dealing in licences. The legal position of persons who have traded or who may trade licences illegally remains unchanged and action is being and will be taken against such persons.
Yours sincerely
GORDON SCHOLES
2 June 1986
The Hon. Gordon Scholes, M.P.
Minister for Territories
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister,
At its meeting on 29 May 1986, the Committee considered your letter of 12 May 1986, concerning the Motor Traffic (Amendment) Ordinance 1986 (A.C.T. Ordinance No. 3 of 1986).

The Committee notes that the Ordinance is an interim one to be followed shortly by legislation to implement a comprehensive review of the taxi and private hire-car industry in the A.C.T. The Committee also notes, and thanks you for, your observations concerning the reviewability of the Registrar's decision by a Court of Petty Sessions under section 104 of the Principal Ordinance.

By its letter to you of 15 April 1986, the Committee evidenced its concern to discover if the changes effected by the amendment Ordinance on 27 May 1986 could have adversely affected any person who had, pending before the Registrar, an application for a licence. On 6 May 1986, the Committee received a letter from a Mr P. J. Green of 19 Gleeson Place, Kambah, who argued that, as a person who had such an application pending since 13 August 1985, he had been disadvantaged by the Ordinance. Your letter to the Committee confirms that there is one application outstanding under the former provisions of the Ordinance.

It is not part of the Committee's function (as distinct from that of Senators) to act on behalf of an individual. However, individual cases of complaint or grievance can illustrate the possible abrogation by delegated legislation of existing legal rights and give rise to a need to apply the Committee's Principles to protect the rights of all or any individuals from undue trespass.
The Committee notes, with some concern, the statement in your letter in relation to the outstanding application-

``I am told that this application is currently the subject of an inquiry by the Ombudsman and that it is the Department's intention to deal with it having regard to any recommendation that may be made by the Ombudsman'' (emphasis added).

The Committee is strongly of the view that it is for you, as the responsible Minister, to give such directions as are proper and necessary to ensure that existing legislation in your portfolio is administered in accordance with its letter, spirit and intention and that new delegated legislation does not infringe the Principles of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee. Where you carry ministerial responsibility for a matter, the intentions of your Department are of interest only to the extent that they are also your intentions and have been conveyed as such to your Department for implementation.

Your letter therefore, leaves it a little unclear what remedy, if any, will be made available by you to any person whose rights, if any, may have been prejudiced by the amendment Ordinance. The Committee is most anxious to clarify this matter rather that engage in disallowance procedures, though because time is passing a protective notice of motion has been given.

The Committee would be grateful therefore, if you could indicate whether, notwithstanding an earlier application to the Registrar, the amendment Ordinance has or will have any retrospective effect on such an earlier application. It would assist the Committee whether such an application, pre-dating the amendment Ordinance, is thereby precluded from being dealt with on its merits, in accordance with the law as it stood when the application was made and without reference to the new amendments, in particular the 300 fold increase in fees.

As you will appreciate, the Committee's predominant concern in this matter is to ensure that a tabled instrument of delegated legislation does not infringe its Principles by trespassing unduly on important existing rights to a source of livelihood.
Yours sincerely,
BARNEY COONEY
Chairman
1 August 1986
Senator Barney Cooney
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee on
Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Cooney
I refer to your letter of 2 June 1986 concerning the Motor Traffic (Amendment) Ordinance 1986 (``the amending Ordinance'').

I have been advised that the amending Ordinance does apply to Mr Green's application. I have also received a recommendation from the Registrar of Motor Vehicles that Mr Green's application for a taxi licence be granted.

I have accepted the Registrar's recommendation. I have also accepted the Registrar's recommendation that Mr Green should not be prejudiced by the amending Ordinance. I will therefore be exercising my powers under section 209 of the Motor Traffic Ordinance to remit part of the fee for the licence, so that only the previously applicable fee of $250 is payable. I will also be exercising my power under section 3 of the amending Ordinance to increase the number of taxi licences on issue.
In these circumstances I can now assure the Committee that no persons who applied for a taxi licence before the amending Ordinance became law have been prejudiced by the amendment.
Yours sincerely
GORDON SCHOLES

TALK.START.PARA: —Might I say also that Senator Reid has been very active in this matter. I think she too has a notice and she has shown very considerable interest in this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, contingent upon (a) a Bill being introduced in the Senate or received from the House of Representatives, (b) an indication being given to the Senate by a Minister or the Senator in charge of the Bill that it is not intended that the Bill be passed during the current period of sittings and (c) the Senate on any day concluding its consideration of any item of business and prior to the Senate proceeding to the consideration of another item of business, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hamer moving a motion to refer the Bill to a Standing Committee.
I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a brief explanation of the reason for this contingent notice of motion.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

Senators will be aware that I am a strong advocate of more Government Bills being referred to Senate Legislative and General Purpose Standing Committees for public examination. I know many Senators share this view, and it is, I think, generally agreed that nearly all Bills which have been so referred have been substantially improved as a consequence. It is of course not to be expected that Governments will welcome such public examination-and probably criticism-but it is the job of the non-government parties to see that Government legislation is critically examined.

The normal objection to referring a Bill to a Committee has been that it would involve delay. It was in order to avoid this objection that at the end of the last session I proposed that six Bills be referred to various committees for examination and report back by the first sitting day in this session. These were Bills which the Government did not propose to proceed with last session, so there would have been no delays because of the committee examination. Before proposing the Bills to be referred, I consulted with Opposition and Australian Democrats Senators on the relevant committees to confirm that public examination of the Bills would be helpful, and that such examination was, in their opinion, within the capacity of the committee.

Unfortunately, all the Government Chairmen of the relevant committees-and some irrelevant ones-claimed that their committees could not possibly examine the bills adequately, because they were already fully committed on other work. Indeed, Mr President, the referral of bills is normally going to be with short notice, and it seems to me very bad administration if a Legislative and General Purpose Committee so locks itself in to its general purpose function that it is incapable of performing its legislative functions when such function is proposed.

I am therefore giving notice now of the possibility that, at the end of this session, I shall move to refer to appropriate committees any Bills which are to be stood over at the end of the session, but which would benefit from public examination by a committee.

It seems to me only normal administration that committees would keep their operations sufficiently flexible so that they can deal with any bills so referred, in the time scale determined by the Senate, which would normally be the first sitting day of the next session.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make it quite clear that the Opposition is opposed to this measure being passed by the Senate. We are particularly concerned that this measure should have been brought on for debate in such haste, without adequate opportunity for all honourable senators to make a close study of it and to consider whether, as an alternative, any amendments should be made to it. The fact is, Mr President, that just a few minutes ago you tabled some highly important and highly relevant documents concerning the matters that are to be debated in relation to this Bill. I understand that there was some last minute effort by the Government to delay the tabling of those documents, but I am very pleased to find that they have been tabled. Nevertheless, that emphasises the extraordinary haste with which the Government is seeking to have this legislation debated and passed by the Senate. This is yet another indication of the fact that this Government, its Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), and the representative of the Attorney-General in this place, the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans), have lost all sense of balance, judgment and reason in regard to this very difficult and very serious question which has been before the Parliament now for two and a half years.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe that it is a quite inappropriate time to be having these debates and to be forced to make statements in the public arena in the circumstances of Mr Justice Murphy's health. Most of us, and the public, have not had an opportunity to see the medical certificate which you, Mr President, tabled a few minutes ago. There have been references to it. Some people have had the opportunity to see it, but certainly not all honourable senators. That also is a most relevant matter. Let me say at the outset that we all have great sympathy for Mr Justice Murphy and his family in the circumstances in which he now finds himself. However, we feel that those circumstances impose some constraint in conducting this debate in a proper way in the Parliament at present. It would have been far better if the Government had adopted the approach of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry and left the decision as to how this matter should be handled in the present circumstances to the good sense of the commissioners, all three of whom are judges of great experience and high integrity who, as such, have had long experience in coping with the problem of a very grave illness being experienced by a litigant or an accused person before them in court. Their last comments in their report were:

If the Commission is to carry through its task to completion, it will be necessary for the Houses to extend time to a date not earlier than 31 March 1987. The prognosis of the medical certificate makes serious the problems posed by this course. To continue hearings if the judge were too ill to take part in them would be contrary to established practice and to natural justice.

The Commission adjourned hearings scheduled for Sydney on 5 August because of the medical certificate about the judge's health. We believe that the proper course in these circumstances is for the Parliament simply to extend the term of the Commission of Inquiry, as it indicated it would, and leave it to the Commission to decide what course it should adopt in relation to the medical condition of the judge. That would have saved the Parliament the very distressing task of debating the future of this Commission in the circumstances that have been outlined. I can only put down on record my very deep regret that on behalf of the Opposition-and indeed this relates to any honourable senator who speaks in this debate-we are being forced to speak now on this rushed legislation. It is a headlong attempt by the Government to bury this Commission as quickly as it possibly can without any adequate debate at all.

I remind the chamber that this Commission is one of the Government's own initiatives. It was also a measure pushed with great speed through the Parliament and we supported it because we saw it as about the only reasoned judgment that the Government has ever exercised in relation to the problem presented by Mr Justice Murphy. Mr Bowen is to be commended for the fact that, even bearing in mind the sorry history of this Government's sad lack of performance and its abdication of duty throughout this whole affair, in May this year when he proposed this special Commission of Inquiry he at least gave some recognition to the real problem that has always faced the Parliament and the nation. Mr Bowen then said that the Commission of Inquiry was being set up because of the need to protect the standing and the integrity of the High Court of Australia and the preservation of public confidence in it. That view has always been held by, and has animated all the actions of, the Opposition on this matter for the last two and a half years. The circumstances which led to the establishment of that inquiry in May still stand and that is made very clear by the Commission in its report to you, Mr President, which you tabled on Tuesday. The report of the Commission, dated 5 August, stated:

The situation which existed at the date when the Act became law, 13 May 1986, was such that Parliament regarded the task allotted to the Commission as one of national importance. That situation remains unchanged.

Clearly, as long as Mr Justice Murphy sits on the High Court and claims to sit on the High Court, as long as there is no clear statement by him or the Government and as long as he does not resign, those circumstances stand. As I have said it may be that the exercise given to the Commission will be very difficult to carry out in the light of Mr Justice Murphy's state of health. Unfortunately, as I have said, I am having to debate this matter without having seen the medical report which has just been tabled. The Government has been given ample opportunity to deal with this question. Questions were asked the other day about the future of Mr Justice Murphy. Mr Lionel Bowen, in answering a question on Tuesday of this week in another place, said about Mr Justice Murphy:

Regrettably, it appears that because of the diagnosis and the nature of the illness, he is weakening and therefore may not be able to resume sittings. I think when the medical evidence has been tabled, as it may, it will be conclusive as to that point. I would only hope, from the point of view of an ordinary human being and a fellow Australian, that there is a remission of his illness.
Certainly we would also share that hope. He continued:

I would hope that there is a chance that his health can be restored and that he can regain his position on the Court. He would then be able to meet any of the accusers that he may have, including those in the Opposition.

That is a very clear statement from the Attorney-General only two days ago about his hope-which we share-that Mr Justice Murphy may have a remission. He also raised the possibility that Mr Justice Murphy may continue to sit on the High Court. In a statement by Mr Justice Murphy at the end of July, in which he dropped something of a bombshell, he said:
On Tuesday, July 29, I resumed the full exercise of my constitutional and statutory functions as a justice of the High Court of Australia. . . . I have already commenced sitting.
He then talked about his medical advice. He stated:
I have chosen to spend what portion I can of the limited time available in doing as much judicial duty as I usefully can.
I will bear in my mind the interests of the litigants.

The fact is that we have no clear indication as to what are the intentions of Mr Justice Murphy about his sitting on the Court in the future. We have no clear indications from the Government, other than statements by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), Senator Gareth Evans and Mr Bowen, supporting Mr Justice Murphy in his resumption of what he called his constitutional rights. Therefore, in those circumstances, all the conditions, problems and allegations remain which led to the establishment of this Commission. It is, of course, quite inappropriate in our view, as it was in the view of everybody in this Parliament-and, indeed, everybody concerned, including Mr Justice Murphy-that he should sit until the various allegations that were made against him could be properly investigated and the Commission was able to report on them, so that Parliament could then make its final judgment.

That is the situation. It remains exactly the same, except for the question of Mr Justice Murphy's health. All those problems remain. All the great constitutional questions remain. In those circumstances there is absolutely no justification for this Commission to be terminated, and certainly not terminated with the incredible haste that the Government is exhibiting in the way in which it is handling the matter this week. For those reasons the Opposition opposes the Bill as a whole. The Commission of Inquiry has been working on the task the Parliament gave it. It has reported that it has formulated a number of specific allegations, made in precise terms, as is required by the Act that set up the Commission. Those have been delivered to the judge, but some are still being prepared.
The commissioners are ready to take evidence on the first allegation. They have not, of course, proceeded to do so because of the judge's health. They have said:

Counsel assisting the Commission estimate that the hearing of evidence on all present allegations, including cross-examination, up to the stage at which the Judge might be called to give evidence would last at least four months, and possibly much longer.

That is one reason why the commissioners cannot report to Parliament by 30 September. They seek an extension to 31 March 1987. It is obvious that the commissioners have a substantial amount of material on which they should be taking evidence, making findings and reporting to Parliament. I regret that I must be critical of His Honour in these circumstances but his response to the matter, which is on the public record, reveals a lack of appreciation of the decision of the Parliament and the Government. He said:
Between July 15 and 30 I received from those assisting the Commission a number of purported allegations.
They were allegations drawn up in precise terms by the Commission. They were specific, not purported, allegations. The judge went on to say:
In my view they-
that is, the allegations-
are either untrue or do not constitute misbehaviour. I have already been cleared of many of them by the unanimous decision of the first Senate committee.

I do not see the relevance of that first Senate committee to this question, because this is an altogether different Commission of Inquiry. In that statement, the judge is seeking to set himself up as a judge in his own cause in respect of both the meaning of misbehaviour and the truth, or otherwise, of the allegations. The responsibility of the Commission is repudiated by the judge. In other words, the decision of the Parliament and of the Government is being repudiated.

For all those reasons, there is absolutely no justification for the Government to wind up this Commission of Inquiry with the unseemly and unjustified haste being exhibited. I regret to say that this is an example of the long and sorry history of this Government's handling of this most difficult and sensitive issue. Despite all the bumbling ways and fumbling reasoning exhibited from time to time by the present Attorney-General, at least for a brief time back in May he saw the problem. I regret to say that he seems to have lost the fleeting grasp he had then. His statements in Parliament the other day and before Parliament resumed, to which I have referred, show that he has again lost his way. Indeed, the Prime Minister has lost his sense of judgment in this matter as well. Back in May, it was everybody's understanding that the judge would not sit again until the Commission reported. Yet, the other day, the Prime Minister supported this so-called `constitutional right'. Nobody seems to have understood that there are duties as well as rights on the part of judges as well as everyone else.

The happenings in the past few weeks and the terms of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry (Repeal) Bill 1986 exhibit the hand and influence of the former Attorney-General, the present Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans. Incidentally, all these matters seemed to be revived when he was acting Attorney-General. I suppose that that happened by chance. He was acting Attorney-General when these matters got off the rails again. The Bill exhibits his total lack of judgment and reasoning. It is a repudiation of all the principles that the former Attorney-General espoused in the past in respect of freedom of information, open government and the rest of it. This Bill is the worst example of repudiation of those principles that I or anyone else has ever seen. As reported in the morning Press, people such as Professor Howard, and Professor Winterton, and others, have indicated that they have never seen anything like it. So I charge great responsibility for this matter on Senator Gareth Evans who has, from the very beginning of this case, always shown a total abdication of responsibility. If the problem had been grasped by the Government in the first place when he was Attorney-General, the matter may well have been resolved in a speedy and satisfactory manner a long time ago.

I now turn to the terms of the Bill. I express the Opposition's utter abhorrence and rejection of the attempt by this Bill to suppress forever any allegations that have been made, not only against Mr Justice Murphy but also against any other person he may or may not have been associated with. Even allegations which may have been made against other persons are suppressed forever in this piece of legislation. This is the most utter repudiation of all the principles of open government, freedom of information, civil liberties and all the democratic principles that this Parliament has ever been asked to pass. If the Australian Democrats support this legislation, as I understand they propose to do, they will forfeit any respect that they may have ever had from any section of the population and certainly any claim that they may have ever had that they believe in these fundamental principles of government.

As I said, this legislation does not simply protect evidence that may have been given to the Commission in respect of Mr Justice Murphy. It protects any documents that contain material relating to the conduct of Mr Justice Murphy. They do not even have to be allegations. There may be favourable mention of Mr Justice Murphy. But if he is mentioned in documents, no matter what other highly important matters they contain, they are protected as class A documents, and they are protected forever.

There is another class of document which may be released by the Presiding Officers, but the Presiding Officers have no discretion either to release these class A documents at any time in the future. The class B documents may be released by the authority of the Presiding Officers, which presumably means they both have to agree. The class B documents, which are so extraordinarily closely protected, are documents which presumably do not contain any material relating to the conduct of Mr Justice Murphy but which may contain material relating to the meaning of section 72 of the Constitution of the Commonwealth of Australia or any other matter.

The Government is attempting to give effect to this Bill before it is even debated in the Senate. It wants to protect in this way any document which contains a reference to the meaning of section 72 of the Constitution. It wants to protect a document which simply gives an opinion as to what that section means. We know what Senator Gareth Evans thinks it means. We know the restricted meaning he wants to give it. He wants to suppress in this Bill any other meaning that an independent person or lawyer may have about the meaning of this section. He is so obsessed with his own opinions and their righteousness, so obsessed with the problem of Mr Justice Murphy, for whom I know he has such high regard and respect, that he also wants to repudiate all his academic standards of intellectual freedom by suppressing a document which contains an opinion about section 72 of the Constitution.

A more serious matter is the suppression of the class A documents. As I have said, in those there is not just material relating to Mr Justice Murphy-which, whether it is unfavourable or favourable, will be suppressed forever-but also documents that contain possible allegations against other people, or material relevant to other people's conduct. They also will be suppressed forever. The legislation, on the face of it-this may be the subject of debate at the Committee stage-would also suppress documents which have been received by this Commission from the National Crime Authority or some other body, documents which have come into existence in a way quite separate from the Commission but which have been given to it because under the Act setting up the inquiry it was envisaged that the Commission may require, and no doubt has received, material from the National Crime Authority. As a result of this definition of a class A document, it seems that those documents will be suppressed and frozen forever if they refer to Mr Justice Murphy.

The legislation goes on to provide quite draconian penalties of fines and imprisonment for any person who discloses any allegation relating to the conduct of Mr Justice Murphy derived from any document which is in the hands of the Commission or the staff of the Commission. As I have said, that will apply forever. There is no time limit on it as there is under the Archives Act for ordinary archival material. There are no limits and rules to enable documents to be released at any time under the Freedom of Information Act. There is no way in which anybody can claim these documents and have these matters judicially determined as there is under that other legislation. These documents are simply to be buried forever. Law enforcement authorities will never have access to them; nor will any research worker in the dim distant future have any right to them.

This action by the Government can be seen only as an attempt to promote Mr Justice Murphy in his lifetime to the pantheon of the Labor gods. That is the effect of it. Extraordinarily sensitive documents have been opened up after time. For example, the Petrov papers were opened up after 30 years. Highly sensitive defence and security documents--

TALK.START.PARA: —Just have a look at the amendment in front of you.

—How can I read an amendment when I am speaking? If there is an amendment to this legislation it just shows the disgraceful haste in which the Government has brought this thing forward. Instead of interjecting on me in my last two minutes, the Minister ought to be ashamed of himself for having introduced this legislation in this Parliament. If it were not for the Senate and for a free Press in this country-both of which I suppose the Minister wants to suppress, from the way he is going on-this disgraceful Bill would have become law yesterday. If the Government wants to amend it we will seriously look at what it proposes. But there is no honour and no claim to any reason or decency in the Minister saying: `Look at the amendment now'. I will certainly look at it when I get time.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Evans and his Government are to be judged on what they proposed and passed through the House of Representatives, not on something that may have been cooked up when members of the Government read this morning's Press. They would not accept the Opposition's complaints yesterday. They would not even give the Opposition time yesterday to prepare amendments. They will not put their tails between their legs, claim that they made an oversight and beg forgiveness. We will listen to and look at the Government's amendment, but its purposes are clear. They have been clear all along. The Government wants to suppress forever any information which may be relevant not only to the conduct of Mr Justice Murphy but also to that of other people. It wants to suppress documents and information prepared by the National Crime Authority. That is a disgraceful purpose for which those opposite should forever be ashamed.

Perhaps parts of the Bill can be fixed up with amendments. The Opposition will propose a number of amendments. I come back to the original point. The Opposition is opposed to the repeal of this Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry. The Opposition is opposed to winding it up because the circumstances which gave rise to it still stand. We recognise the problem that confronts everybody because of the illness of Mr Justice Murphy but until there is a clear decision about his future and as long as there is some intention on his and the Government's part that he should continue to work as a judge of the High Court of Australia the reasons for the Commission of Inquiry stand. It must be able to complete its work and report to the Parliament. Only then can any final decision properly be made about the future standing of Mr Justice Murphy as a justice of the High Court.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry (Repeal) Bill. Indeed, we only wish, first, that there had been no need for the legislation and, secondly, that it had contained the sorts of protective measures regarding the documents which the Opposition appears to think it has. Far from believing that this is a disgraceful Bill, our opinion was and still is that the original legislation establishing the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry was disgraceful. Prior to that two Senate select committees had inquired into the behaviour of Mr Justice Murphy and he had been through two trials, the second of which acquitted him of the charges laid. In my speech on the second reading of the Bill to establish the inquiry in the first place I said that the matter should have rested unless and until additional charges on which court action could be taken were laid.

SPEECH.PARA: We opposed the original inquiry, as I said, because the judge had been acquitted. We oppose the Opposition's arguments on this occasion because they are of no substance at all. As far as we are concerned the documents that the Opposition complains will be suppressed not only should have done to them what this Bill intended to do prior to the Government's mitigating amendment but also should be disposed of properly. They should be shredded, burned or anything else but they should not be left around so that somewhere down the track another government can repeal this legislation or clauses relating to access to the documents so that they can be dispersed around the community presumably for the salacious enjoyment of anybody who wants to see them. We have to remember that the documents about which we are talking consist entirely of a series of suspicions, allegations, assertions and suggestions about Mr Lionel Murphy.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you know about it? Have you got any evidence? What are you talking about?

—The honourable senator should read the Bill and he will see that `class A document' means a document referred to in sub-section (1) that contains material relating to the conduct of the Hon. Lionel Keith Murphy. If that does not mean that an assortment of people, with or without malice, around this country have forwarded to the Commission of Inquiry whatever ideas, suspicions, allegations assertions, and so on they have been able to dream up, I am not sure what Opposition senators think it means. Certainly and importantly, there has been no evidence taken on any of those allegations, and neither has the Commission of Inquiry come down with any determinations on it. As far as the class B documents are concerned relating to various lawyers' and others' arguments about what is the meaning of section 72 (ii) of the Constitution, those are merely academic documents that can be and have been produced at any time that anybody, with or without a legal mind, sees fit to do so. To consider that those sorts of allegations could be brought forward some time down the track, particularly following the very likely death of the person about whom the allegations have been made, is quite outrageous.
—What about allegations about others?

—Senator Walters raises a matter I was about to come to of allegations about other people. Presumably the authors of the documents classified as class A documents who made allegations about Mr Justice Murphy in those documents, and who presumably may have made allegations about other people, have not been stricken from the face of this earth. They should have already, I would have thought, and certainly still have the opportunity to pass on that information about other people to the relevant law enforcement agencies such as the Director of Public Prosecutions or any other law enforcement agency. Anybody who thinks that this is muzzling the opportunity people in this country have to pass on information about an assortment of other people is being quite ridiculous. Other things that have been raised with me over the last little while as problems in this legislation include the fact that there are penalties for unlawful disclosure, as if somehow this Bill were setting a precedent. I suggest that Opposition senators who think that $5,000 or imprisonment for six months, or both, for disclosure of information by a natural person is draconian ought to have a look at some of the penalties under the secrecy provisions of other pieces of legislation. The Census and Statistics Act 1905, for example, contains far more draconian penalties for disclosure than does this Bill.
—One hundred thousand dollars?
—For natural persons. I suggest that the honourable senator have another look-if he has had a look already-at sub-clause 8 (a) under `Penalty', which states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . where the defendant is a natural person-$5,000 or imprisonment for 6 months. . .

The Census and Statistics Act gives $5,000 or two years imprisonment, or both. The Income Tax Assessment Act provides for $5,000 or 12 months imprisonment, or both. Both of those provisions are stronger than the penalty applied in this legislation. The Crimes Act gives two years, the National Crime Authority Act provides for $5,000 or one year, and there is an assortment of other Acts ranging from the Human Rights Commission through to export market development grants Acts, for goodness sake, which contain penalties of a fine or a term of imprisonment, or both. So to carry on as if somehow these are not only draconian but unique indicates that some people in this place are not aware of the penalties that exist in other legislation. The bleeding about freedom of information, the denial of access and freedom of speech, and so on, by Opposition senators sits very strangely with their insistence that freedom of information legislation be used to protect, for example, sensitive commercial organisations in this country so that their competitors cannot use it against them. Either we talk about absolute freedom of speech and access to documents, or governments are entitled to be selective and protective of those areas where they think that is required.

Therefore, the Australian Democrats quite simply support this legislation on the grounds that we do not believe that the inquiry should have been set up in the first place. Had there not been that inquiry this accumulation of documents would not have occurred, the need for most of the provisions of this piece of legislation would not have occurred either, and the Bill itself would not have seen the light of day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a Bill for an Act to repeal the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry Act 1986. The Bill purports to do two things. It aims to put an end immediately to the work of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry, a commission set up by this Parliament and initiated by the Government. The Bill goes further than that. It sets out to protect virtually totally all the evidence, all the documents, that have been before that inquiry. Whether they apply to Mr Justice Lionel Murphy or to others, whether they implicate others, whether there may be criminal allegations of others, it seeks to prevent their use. Nothing that has ever been before this Parliament, or I believe before any other parliament, has ever equalled this in such flagrant breach of the principles of natural justice or the principles of democratic law. Nothing, I stress, has done this, and I want to examine that in detail.

SPEECH.PARA: Those of us who over the years have come to know Lionel Murphy, whether in this chamber or elsewhere, will be very sad that he has suffered such a grievous, serious illness. We sympathise with him and his family that this should be so. Tragically, it is the fate of one in four living human beings to achieve at some stage a malignancy which may be the terminal illness that results in their death. Sadly for him and his family, unfortunately he has arrived at such a situation. We would hope, and indeed wish, that there can be remission, that his life can be spared, that he can be denied pain, and that he can be given comfort in his journey in what we hope will be the months and even years ahead. No one can say how long the illness may last, how long the journey will be, or whether there will be remissions. The medical certificate that has been tabled today at first glance indicates that without further treatment the prognosis is three to nine months. Should chemotherapy be used there may be a limited-about 20 per cent-prospect of prolonging his survival. Let us hope that there is remission. Let us hope anyhow that he does not suffer and that his family will be spared the pain and anguish of the journey.

In doing that, we must not in any way harass the man or his family. On the other hand, we must not give to him-this is a basic principle of law-any privilege, any kind of protection, that is not given to the most ordinary citizen in the community. He must have exactly the legal privileges, the legal protections and the legal responsibilities that the humblest member of the community has. Indeed, I have heard the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) espouse that principle of others in the past. What is that principle? The fact is that there are many people who appear as defendants before courts of law, quasi-judicial or judicial inquiries who find in their journey, before a verdict is reached, that they are suffering from a serious or terminal illness. We ought to look at those procedures and follow them precisely in this case. Mr Justice Lionel Murphy should not be denied what is available to others. He should not be given anything in excess of that which is available to others.

What happens is that first of all the matter is left to the court of law. That is the principle of British justice. Courts of law continually face situations of people who are seriously or terminally ill and who are unable to come before them as witnesses. The court makes the judgment. In the general nature of things the court adjourns the hearing indefinitely on the basis that, first of all, it is hoped that the person may recover in health sufficiently to come before it. Who can say that that may not be so in the ordinary principle? The court knows that if in fact the defendant should die the action will automatically be terminated. Therefore, there are clear principles of British law to be followed. Those are the principles that should be available to Mr Justice Lionel Murphy. I repeat: They must be no different from the principles available to everyone else.

Those of us who are here today can think of the action proceeding in the New South Wales courts at the moment in regard to a defendant, indeed associated as a co-defendant with a former member of parliament, who is seriously ill. Does that mean that in that case one should seek a termination of that defendant's trial? After all, what lesser rights has that defendant in that trial than has Mr Justice Lionel Murphy? Indeed, if the former Attorney-General, the Minister for Resources and Energy, or any of his colleagues are seeking to give special rights they are doing terrible damage to the principle of British law. Their own reputations will remain totally in tatters.

What has happened? Tragically, this matter has always been a cover-up. How is it that two days have passed since the Commission submitted, on 19 August, a document to the Government, enclosing a special report and yet a debate has taken place in another place without the privilege of this report. The Australian Democrats have their case demolished by this report which I now hold in my hand. Three judges have made available to the Parliament-it was not available to the other place-a vitally important document. This is a document which gets right to the heart of the charges against Mr Justice Lionel Murphy. This document states that the three judges have looked at the interpretation of section 72 of the Constitution and reached a unanimous decision. Indeed, that decision, upon being reached, destroys the case of the Australian Democrats totally. Let it be made perfectly clear that the real people who must share the blame for this Bill and its journey are the Australian Democrats. The Australian Democrats have it within their capacity to prevent the Government from doing an unprecedented dastardly act. They have it within their capacity to do that but they are not doing it. All of Senator Haines's arguments today fall to the ground totally because of both this document and others. Let me remind the Senate what, in fact, the judges have said. I will read the comments of just one judge although each of the judges has reached the same verdict. Sir George Lush said:

Accordingly, my opinion is that the word `misbehaviour' in S.72 is used in its ordinary meaning, and not in the restricted sense of `misconduct in office'. It is not confined, either, to conduct of a criminal nature.

Let us bear in mind that this is the decision of three of the most distinguished former judges in Australia and that this is a decision of a Commission set up by the Government. We have that before us. Therefore, clearly before the Parliament is a series of facts which need to be examined. Of course, one does not need to look at procedures in courts of law at all. One needs to look at the evidence before one. When the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry Act was set up the explanatory memorandum stated:

The Commission will not call upon Mr Justice Murphy to give evidence unless the Commission is of the opinion that there is evidence of misbehaviour within the meaning of section 72 of the Constitution sufficient to require an answer and the Commission has given to Mr Justice Murphy particulars in writing of that evidence. The Commission is to base its findings on evidence admissible in a court of law.

Let us understand quite clearly what the Government has said and what the Commission is charged to do. The Commission will not call upon Mr Justice Murphy unless it is of the opinion that there is evidence of misbehaviour within the meaning of section 72 of the Constitution and if that evidence is sufficient to require an answer. That is precisely what the Commission did. The former judge, Sir George Lush, said in the opening paragraph of his statement:

By Thursday 17 July 1986 counsel assisting the Commission had cause to be delivered to those representing Mr Justice Murphy twelve documents each purporting to set out, a specific allegation of conduct by the Judge (Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry Act, S. 5 (2)). Two further such documents have been delivered.
In a former report to this Parliament the Commission said of the nature of that evidence:

Counsel assisting the Commission estimate that the hearing of evidence on all present allegations, including cross-examination, up to the stage at which the Judge might be called on to give evidence, (S. 6 (1)) would last at least four months, and possibly much longer. The Act fixes 30 September 1986 as the date for the making of the Commission's report, but under S. 8 (2) that time may be extended.

Therefore, we have before us a clear situation that three very eminent ex-judges have looked at the evidence so far and have said that it comes within the nature of that paragraph I read from the explanatory memorandum; that there appeared to be basic evidence and that they had written to counsel for Mr Justice Lionel Murphy saying that they wanted him to appear. At the time those judges wrote that it was clear that they themselves regarded that there was a very significant series of matters to be answered. However, the puzzlement about this is that throughout the whole of this situation Mr Justice Lionel Murphy has been emphatic in saying that he wants the Commission to continue so that he can clear his name. It is not he who is asking for this situation. He has not changed his mind on this at all. Some honourable senators may remember the dying words of Hamlet when he said to Horatio:
O, good Horatio, what a wounded name,
Things standing thus unknown, shall live behind me?

He made the plea that Horatio not let things lie in their confused state but let the evidence come out so that the facts be known. Of course, this is flying in the face of the whole of the situation. In fact, what the Government has done is to confuse this with Macbeth's statement:
If it were done, when 't is done, then 't were well
It were done quickly: If the assassination
Could trammel up the consequence, and catch,
With his surcease, success; that but this blow
Might be the be-all and the end-all here,
But here, upon this bank and shoal of time,
We'd jump the life to come-But in these cases,
We still have judgment here . . .

Let me remind honourable senators of that: He went on to say `in these cases we still have judgment here'. Teaching bloody execution returns to plague the inventor. This Bill has judgment here, and it will return to plague the inventor.

The judge himself, the defendant, has said: `I do not want the inquiry to stop; I want it to go on'. But let me go further. Sadly, if the terminal illness should take its course and Mr Justice Murphy should die, the protection of the ordinary libel laws does not function, as we have seen in many cases. Senator Grimes has been an exponent of this view in relation to a former Premier of New South Wales. Allegations may be made wildly and without substantial proof, but there is no protection after death for a defendant. Again I say:
. . . what a wounded name,
Things standing thus unknown, shall live behind me?

This Bill does not seek to protect Lionel Murphy. The fundamental error and cruelty of this Bill is that patently it seeks to protect those whose names are also contained in the documents, that is, those who were on the other end of the telephone. That in itself is the ugly shame for this Government. It knows that it cannot protect Mr Justice Murphy; it knows that the correct answer is to do what the judge has asked for-that is, let us clean it up; let us have this inquiry. It knows it cannot do that, but also it knows that fundamentally it is seeking to stop any inquiry about any other person or persons whose name or names may be contained in these documents and who might have committed acts which may require examination by Crown law authorities which may invoke prosecution.

How can any government, any former Attorney-General or anybody who poses as a lawyer seek to commit into perpetuity a denial of evidence? This is not a pursuit of Mr Justice Lionel Murphy. Tragically enough, that pursuit will go on without the protection of libel laws in the years ahead; that will go on, as the world knows. This is a protection of others. The Government should tell us why it is seeking to protect these other people. Even with this latter-day repentance of a few amendments, why should the Government, extraordinarily, put into the hands of the Presiding Officers decisions which are essentially for the Parliament to make? Why should the Presiding Officers have any right to make determinations in a matter of common law concerning human beings? More importantly, why should they be left with the terrible responsibility, and therefore the damage to their reputations? From now on are we to be able to insinuate that Madam Speaker and Mr President are holding documents which may contain this or which may not contain that? What kind of an utter mare's-nest has been set up?

Why is this being done? We come back to the whole purpose of this inquiry. The allegations against the judge did not arise from the Parliament; they did not arise at all from political parties. They arose fundamentally from a series of tapes that had been recorded by police officers who now have been shown to have acted in good faith and in all honesty to seek information about breaches of the law. Those tapes set about investigations which have gone on elsewhere. It is important to understand that Mr Justice Stewart of the Royal Commission of Inquiry Into Alleged Telephone Interceptions has validated those tapes. That is very important. Coincidentally, that validation was announced after the termination of the last trial of Mr Justice Murphy. I make no insidious inference from that. I simply say that following that trial and acquittal, it became known that the judge of the Royal Commission had said that the tapes were valid. Therefore, an entirely different responsibility is put upon this Commission, these judges who now face the situation that their duties are to be terminated.

These judges have said that they take note of the original Act and the injunction upon them that they must not call Mr Justice Lionel Murphy before them until they have been convinced that there is very significant evidence that an inquiry is needed. They have come to that conclusion, and in 14 cases they have put out this material. Now, despite Mr Justice Murphy saying that he does not want the inquiry to be terminated, some others obviously are influencing this Government to stop the inquiry because it is in their interests that it should not proceed. It cannot be in the interest of Mr Justice Lionel Murphy. It would have been in his interest for us to respect his request that it proceed and his belief that it would clear his name. That would be the fair thing to do for him. The stopping of the inquiry can only be in the interests of others. Let the Government tell us who are these other people whose interests are that this should be so.

Let me now come forcibly to the position of the Australian Democrats. In their homely phrase, they pose that they are here to keep the bastards honest. They have said that many times. They who take the cloak of honesty had better wear it here today, hair-shirt and all. The six members here are charged with carrying out their parliamentary responsibilities, specifically in relation to section 72 of the Constitution. I appeal to them to consider that their earlier stance has now been destroyed. Three very eminent retired judges have said that the basis of judgment of the meaning of `misbehaviour' involves an ordinary definition-a wider definition, and not a criminal one. Therefore it is for the Democrats, in the end, to find out what that evidence is and to act upon it. In other words, they have a responsibility and if they are not willing to discharge that responsibility, they should resign from this Parliament.

The Democrats' job is now quite clear. Under section 72 it is to seek what evidence there is whilst the defendant is alive and make a judgment inside this chamber. It is not to run away from it, nor to utter emotive words that become headlines, such as saying that the papers should be burnt. They are now saying that papers which may well contain evidence which could cause the Crown Solicitor or a similar law officer to act against a person who is believed to have committed a breach of the law should be burnt. But what emotive words Senator Haines used today. She said that all these things are just suspicions, allegations and assertions. I invite Senator Haines to reconsider her words, because quite clearly the Act which the Senate is now seeking to repeal made it very clear that the Commission would not simply summon Mr Justice Murphy before it if there were just some suspicions, allegations or assertions. The Act stated that the Commission would not call upon Mr Justice Murphy to give evidence unless the Commission was of the opinion that there was evidence of misbehaviour within the meaning of section 72 of the Constitution sufficient to require an answer. The Commission has given in writing to Mr Justice Murphy particulars of that evidence. The Commission has to base its findings on evidence that would be admissible in a court of law. We now know, as Senator Haines and her Democrats know, that Sir George Lush and his colleagues, in confirmation of that, have said that they have delivered 14 documents to the lawyers for Mr Justice Murphy in those terms-not suspicions, not allegations, not assertions, but an approach in the calm, common sense of law to seek out the truth.

It is no use the Democrats doing today what they have said they will do, hiding behind the fact that they said earlier that they did not believe that there ought to be a Commission; that there should not have been any trial or investigation of Mr Justice Murphy because everything was based on suspicions, allegations and assertions. That argument has now totally failed. The Democrats have before them today, in a document from the Commission, far more substantial evidence. They must stand up and be counted in making their final judgment. Therefore, they need before them the evidence of proven misbehaviour or otherwise. They cannot run away from that. I repeat: This Bill is the worst breach of natural justice I have ever seen in any parliament and can be regarded only as protection by the Government of persons other than Mr Justice Lionel Murphy because it cannot protect him. Only heaven and the course of time-and one hopes that it will be a gentle course of time-can protect him. He will stand his judgment in terms of the ebb and flow of the libel laws.

There is no end to this matter. No amount of suppression by the Government, no amount of trying to burn the papers to get rid of them or trying to pass the onus on to the Presiding Officers, will bring an end to this matter. What an ugly situation! The Government thinks: `We will stop the truth coming out; we will stop journalists from publishing the truth'. I have never seen before such an attempt to destroy the freedom of the Press. If there is a fundamental freedom of the Press, it is the right to probe, to find. After all, if the Press reports something and it is wrong, the full force of the libel laws is upon the Press. So it is not a question of stopping the Press because it may do harm. Any living individual has full recourse to the law if the Press publishes something that can be shown to be wrong. So the Government is not trying to stop the publication of unsubstantiated allegations. If that is so, the test must be applied to every individual and not simply to Mr Justice Lionel Murphy. That is the fundamental situation.

Mr Justice Lionel Murphy deserves sympathy for his illness, as does everyone who suffers such a serious and terminal illness. He deserves exactly the same protections as every other individual gets. He has exactly the same rights and responsibilities before the courts of law as every individual has, and not one tittle more. The fact is that Mr Justice Murphy has asked that the Commission continue, so this Bill does not relate to protecting him at all. The stopping of the Commission will be to protect others with whom the Australian Labor Party has some affinity or affection or self-interest. Who are they? If this Bill goes through, the Democrats will have connived at a situation whereby from now to eternity there will be inferences, allegations and insinuations made. It will be this person or that person the Government will be trying to protect. In other words, the Government will have created a monstrosity, the absolute perversion of law.

I appeal to the Government. More importantly, I appeal to those who believe that their job is to keep us honest. Physician, cure thyself. The Democrats should consider the present situation and not come to us and tell us what their decision was three months or six months ago. They should consider their decision today in terms of the three ex-judges and the decisions and recommendations those judges have made. When the Democrats do so they will have only one recourse- to reject this Bill totally because it is fundamentally wrong and a grave breach of every principle of British law.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Constitution of this nation places a very heavy burden on all parliamentarians, both members of the House of Representatives and members of the Senate, in relation to justices of the High Court of Australia and the other courts created by the Parliament. Section 72 (ii) of the Constitution says that those justices:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . shall not be removed except by the Governor-General in Council, on an address from both Houses of the Parliament in the same session, praying for such removal on the ground of proved misbehaviour or incapacity . . .

So if a justice of the High Court or of one of the other courts created by the Parliament is at any time to be removed from office there has to be an address from both Houses of the Parliament praying for that judge's removal on the ground of proved misbehaviour or incapacity. If the Parliament is at any time to make such a decision, then clearly it must make a decision as to what is proved misbehaviour or incapacity. For parliamentarians to make such a determination they would need every assistance they could have from legal advisers. We have had tabled in the Parliament today a series of documents which would be of enormous value to parliamentarians in determining those questions. We have a set of reasons by the Hon. Sir George Lush, who is Chairman of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry, which goes to ten pages; we have reasons by the Hon. Sir Richard Blackburn, OBE, another member of the Commission of Inquiry, which go to some 13 pages, and we have the reasons of the Hon. Andrew Wells, QC, the third member of the Commission of Inquiry, which go to some 36 pages-all of which deal with these fundamental constitutional provisions. Yet the Bill that we are debating in the Senate today would prohibit forever any person ever having access to these opinions, to the documents. I have them today--

TALK.START.PARA: —They are class B documents, and they are at the discretion of the Presiding Officers.

—That is what the Bill says. Senator Evans can scream to high heaven about people having discretions to do all sorts of things but the truth of the matter is that the Bill we are debating today prohibits access forever.
—Class B documents are at the discretion of the Presiding Officers, for God's sake.

—Senator Evans is producing amendments right at the last minute. One amendment was given to us half-way through Senator Sir John Carrick's speech. Do we have time to consider these amendments?
