We are half-way through this debate already, way into the third speaker's speech, and the Government is still trying to amend this legislation, which has already been dealt with by the House of Representatives. Yet we are expected to be able to understand all of these last minute amendments and changes of mind which this Government has because once again it has stupidly followed the advice of Senator Evans. Time after time since Senator Evans has had a job in this Parliament, he has given this Government bad advice. How the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) puts up with having him in his Ministry is absolutely beyond me.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me come back to the documents which we now have and go through parts of them as to the meaning of the word `misbehaviour' in the Constitution. What an invaluable set of documents they are because they give the total lie to the arguments being raised by Senator Janine Haines on behalf of the Australian Democrats as to why she and the Democrats are going to support the Government on this Bill. Senator Haines's argument is very simple. She says that His Honour went through the misery of having two Senate committees of inquiry into this matter. She does not say that the general opinion of those committees was that the matter ought to be looked at further. She just refers to the committees. Then she says that His Honour went through a trial. Again, she does not say that at that trial the jury convicted him. She does not mention that. His Honour then went through a second trial and at the conclusion of that trial the jury acquitted him. Senator Haines says: `That was the end of the matter'. That was the end of the matter as far as that conviction was concerned, there is no question about that. However, immediately after that conviction other matters were raised, the question of the judge's misbehaviour became a public issue, and this Government-not the Opposition-set up the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry. We have the report of the judges as to the meaning of the word `misbehaviour'. Do they agree with Senator Haines? Not on your life, they do not. Let me quote the opinions. Firstly, I quote the Chairman, Sir George Lush, a very distinguished Victorian judge in his time. He said in part, talking about when section 72 was put into the Constitution:

. . . in its original form it gave the sole power of removal to Parliament, to be exercised at will or, in other words, without the need to show cause. Then for the better protection of the independence of the judges it was amended so that a cause for dismissal had to be assigned and proved-a provision designed (a) to make impossible attempts to remove judges for purely political reasons and (b) to secure to the judge a right to defend himself.
The word chosen to describe the cause was `misbehaviour'. This was a word traditionally used in defining the tenure of an office . . .
Sir George Lush gave a lot of reasons and then stated:

Accordingly, my opinion is that the word `misbehaviour' in S. 72 is used in its ordinary meaning, and not in the restricted sense of `misconduct in office'. It is not confined, either, to conduct of a criminal nature.

I hope Senator Haines, who has left the chamber, having made her emotional diatribe about the people in this Parliament who want to bring this matter to some proper conclusion, is listening in her office because Sir George Lush quite clearly refutes everything she has said. Sir George Lush continued:
It is not confined, either, to conduct of a criminal nature.

This interpretation can be said to leave judges open to the investigative activities of the contemporary world, and so to expose them to pressures to which, in the interests of independence, they should not be exposed.
He then pointed out:
The other side of this is that, however S. 72 may be interpreted, judges are not immune from the activities to which I have referred-
he had referred to a number of activities-
though it may be that there is a higher incentive for the investigator if there is a possibility that he may procure a removal.

Of course, we thoroughly agree that there is a very important principle of law in relation to what Sir George Lush said about that matter. Let me now refer to the reasons given by the Hon. Sir Richard Blackburn, who on page 12 of his reasons states:

All the foregoing discussion relates to the question whether `proved misbehaviour' in Section 72 of the Constitution must, as a matter of construction, be limited as contended for by counsel for Murphy J. In my opinion the reverse is correct. The material available for solving this problem of construction suggests that `proved misbehaviour' means such misconduct, whether criminal or not, and whether or not displayed in the actual exercise of judicial functions, as, being morally wrong, demonstrates the unfitness for office of the judge in question.

Whether we are talking about Mr Justice Murphy or some future judge with whom this Parliament may have to deal, it is absolutely vital for those of us who are concerned about the interpretation of section 72 of the Constitution to understand the point he is making. Sir Richard Blackburn further states:

In my opinion the word `proved' in the section implies that Parliament may adopt such method of proof as it sees fit, but may not address arbitrarily or without adverting to the question of proof. In each case, Parliament must decide, first, whether there is proved misbehaviour, and secondly, whether bearing in mind the great importance, implied in the Constitution, of the independence of the judges, it should address for the removal of the judge.

That is exactly the point we have been putting repeatedly on behalf of the Opposition in relation to this matter. It is directly contrary to the opinions expressed by Senator Haines and also, I might say, by Senator Gareth Evans, who has some strong views on this matter which are quite contrary to these reasons. That is probably one of the reasons why he wishes to suppress this material.

I refer to the third member of the Parliamentary Commission, the Honourable Andrew Wells, QC. Let me say as an aside that these judges know that they are inquiring into the activities of a judge of the High Court of Australia. They are not giving some academic lecture in the halls of academia. They are not writing some article for the Australian Law Journal. They are not even standing up in Parliament and making a speech about the subject in general. They are dealing specifically with a judge of the High Court and they know how desperately important the whole subject is. The three of them have come out unanimously with the views which we in the Opposition parties have been expressing for some considerable time. The Honourable Andrew Wells, QC, stated:

The office of judge differs markedly from that of many other public officials. The performance of his duty calls on him to display, of a high order, the qualities of stability of temperament, moral and intellectual courage and integrity, and respect for the law. Those and other like qualities of character and fitness for office, if displayed by a judge in the exercise of his judicial function, are unlikely to be found wanting in his conduct when not acting in office. If they are said to be genuinely possessed and not feigned, they would stand uneasily with conduct in private affairs that testifies to their absence.

There are, however, other qualities that do not carry the same guarantee of stability, integrity, and respect for the law in private life. For example, a man may possess a profound learning, intellectual adroitness, and an accurate memory, and, by using them, adequately discharge the duties of many public offices, but, without more, he could not discharge the duties of judicial office.
In short, a man's moral worth, in general, pervades his life both in and out of office.
My final quote from the Hon. Andrew Wells states:

In my view, the construction of s.72 should be governed by the foregoing principles. Accordingly, the word `misbehaviour' must be held to extend to conduct of the judge in or beyond the execution of his judicial office, that represents so serious a departure from standards of proper behaviour by such a judge that it must be found to have destroyed public confidence that he will continue to do his duty under and pursuant to the constitution.

Those three opinions having been given, is it any wonder that the judges' advisers said: `We have to finish this Committee of Inquiry. We have to wrap it up and bury it forever'? The new Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Haines, would have all these documents pulped so that they would never be available to the historians of this country. What the Government has done by producing this legislation is to convict His Honour in his absence because he now has no chance in any way of clearing his name. This legislation terminates the inquiry; it finishes it for all time. It buries it and allows the rumour- mongers to start, and they have already started. I have heard rumours about all sorts of things which I will not mention. Three or four rumours have been passed to me about the reasons why the Government is burying this inquiry. It is an absolute nonsense for the Government to think that this inquiry and these documents will remain secret forever. Of course, they will not. Of course, there will be all sorts of peculiar leaks and people will find ways of trying to write about the matter and make some sort of reference to it. It is an absolute nonsense to think that it will not be released. The historians will now start to lobby, and they will lobby forever, so that at some stage in the future a sensible government will revoke this legislation and all of the material will become available. Of course, this Government, by way of this legislation, is making sure that when that happens-when the legislation is removed by a future government-it will attract massive headlines, books will be written about it and it will all make a great story. All of the kids at present in the public gallery may very well read about it. It probably will not happen in my time, but I hope that they enjoy it in their old age.

It is absolute nonsense for the Government to think that a matter of such vital importance could be kept secret forever. Of course, one wonders why? Once again the Australian Labor Party has demonstrated that it has no concern for democracy, no concern for freedom, no concern for the Parliament and no concern for the institutions of this great nation. Time after time, if it suits the Australian Labor Party, it rides roughshod over these fundamental principles which are of such vital importance to the people of this country. It does not care. It has never been able to care. Members of the Labor Party listen to advice from people such as Senator Gareth Evans, whose judgment has always failed. Biggles and his raid on Tasmania is a typical example of the sort of advice he keeps giving this Government. How the Government puts up with it is absolutely beyond me. The Bill of Rights, of course, is another of Senator Evans's absolute disasters. He was a disaster as Attorney-General. He has been a disaster as an adviser to the Government time after time. It is absolutely beyond me. I do not know how he seems to be able to get away with it. I suppose he smiles at them. Anyway, it is beyond me how the Government puts up with him as its adviser on these matters.

Why on earth does the Government want to bury this matter forever? The material before us indicates that His Honour will not be with us for much longer. Why does the Government want to bury forever all of the material which has been put before the Commission at this stage? One must ask whether Mr Wran is involved in it. Has it something to do with the Labor Party in New South Wales? This is the sort of thing that people are asking. What is the Government on about? It is not interested. The Petrov case was not sufficiently important. It had to be disclosed. What about matters relating to the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation? The Government is going to attempt to deny the public access to these matters forever. Let me again refer to the opening words of Sir George Lush, formerly a judge of the Victorian Supreme Court. He said:

By Thursday 17 July 1986 counsel assisting the Commission had caused to be delivered to those representing Mr Justice Murphy twelve documents each purporting to set out, a specific allegation of conduct by the Judge . . .
That is in accordance with section 5 (2) of the Act. He continues:
Two further such documents have since been delivered.

So far as we are able to ascertain, at this stage, there are 14 documents, each purporting to set out a specific allegation of conduct to be inquired into. For His Honour to say `I have not done anything wrong, the whole thing should come to and end', is, of course, a nonsense. It is absolute nonsense for the Government to adopt that view, as is disclosed in that first paragraph of the statement to the Speaker and the President by Sir George Lush. Paragraph 5 of the special report by the three members of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry states:

The Commission, through counsel assisting it, has considered a great quantity of materials which, in combination with further inquiries, has led to the drafting of `specific allegations made in precise terms' . . . Those completed have been delivered to the Judge. Some are still in preparation.

So all of these allegations clearly involve the material which the Commission had in front of it. That material will all be kept secret hereafter. There is great compassion for His Honour because of his illness. I do not deny that that is not unreasonable. But the Government, by its actions, has convicted him, because the presumption will be that he is guilty of these allegations. The Government is trying to hide it. That is precisely the view which will be adopted throughout the country. The Commission has made it perfectly clear that it understood that His Honour was not well. It could surely have been allowed to determine when it ought to report. But it will not be allowed to do that. The Government is stepping in at this stage.

I hear Government senators making accusations against me. Let me refer to some of the things that have been said by certain people. Perhaps they might be prepared to listen to the views of these people. Professor Colin Howard, Hearn Professor of Law at Melbourne University-who is, I might say, a person Senator Gareth Evans is frequently prepared to quote in regard to all sorts of constitutional matters-said he could not think of any law which went so far. He warned that it could be seen as a precedent. He stated:
As with all concealment of information it will be interpreted in the worst possible light.

That is all I am saying: It will be interpreted in the worst possible light. Of course, if the Government does not understand that, it is because, as I said, it has been listening to the ravings of Senator Evans, who does not seem to be able to understand the way in which ordinary people think. Mr George Winterton, a senior lecturer at the University of New South Wales, has stated that the secrecy provisions were outrageous. Mr John McMillan, a lecturer in law at the Australian National University, has said:

It is more than extraordinary, it seems to violate the basic archival principles that when individual reputations are not likely to be affected then the public and historians have a right to survey the material.

Of course, he is right. The public and historians have a right to survey the material. So far as the freedom of the Press is concerned, it is absolutely outrageous that the Government should say: `If you dare to publish any of this material, you will suffer these penalties'. We do not know what material is before the Commission of Inquiry. We do not know about the other secret inquiry carried out by Mr Justice Stewart. All of this material may involve other people. Does it mean that if a person is charged with a criminal offence at some future stage, because in some way or other Mr Justice Murphy was associated with the person, that person will not be able to be prosecuted as a result of this legislation being enacted by the Parliament? We do not know what the material contains. We do not know what other people are involved in the matter. It is an absolute disgrace to democratic principles for the Government to bring in such a wide, draconian measure to the effect that all of the material must be buried forever. The attitude of the Australian Democrats is a denial of their name of democrats. Hereafter, how could anyone call them democrats, having regard to the action that apparently they will take today and which I do not understand?

Is there to be a precedent so that, if at some stage a person can produce a medical certificate establishing that he has a terminal illness, the Crown will say: `We shall not proceed'? Is there any suggestion that the Crown will say to Trimbole: `You can come home and spend the rest of your years with your loved ones. We shall not prosecute because we understand that you have a terminal illness. You can come home if you can produce a medical certificate'? It is beyond comprehension that the Government should step in in that way.

It appears as though the Government has something else that it wants to hide or as though the Cabinet has been led by Senator Gareth Evans. From the word go, he has totally opposed any sort of investigation. Any other Attorney-General of the Commonwealth would have stepped in immediately and taken action as soon as the so-called Age tapes were revealed; but not Senator Gareth Evans. He has opposed any action that might bring out any of the facts. He has opposed taking action at every step on the way. It seems that he must have led Cabinet down the stupid path which it has taken on this evidence.

It is not fair to His Honour Mr Justice Murphy that the Commission of Inquiry is not to be allowed to go on investigating as far as it can. People will believe that the Government, by taking the action which it has taken has convicted His Honour in respect of some vague allegations but they will not really know what the allegations are. People have said to me: `Mr Justice Murphy must have committed some terrible criminal offence for you to act in this way'. I have said: `Not at all'. As far as I am aware, for example, it is not a criminal offence for him to approach a judge to ask for an early trial for a friend. But is it the proper action of a High Court judge? The Opposition has not been talking about criminal offences. But the perception of the people is that Mr Justice Murphy must have done something terrible and committed a criminal offence.

The issue will be hushed up. Rumours will fly and 99 per cent will be wrong. It will all be covered up and hidden and the real situation will not be revealed to the public. The steps that the Government has taken by introducing this legislation are disastrous.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is totally opposed to the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry (Repeal) Bill. In the name of protecting an individual's reputation, the Bill poses a very great assault on Parliament's privileges and the freedom of the Press, an assault which would do justice to some Third World dictatorship but which represents a total disgrace in any supposedly free society. The Bill is part of the culmination of a campaign that the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) has been running for years, predicated upon the necessity to bury the evidence of the Age tapes beyond public scrutiny and the pursuit of justice. We have seen from the former Attorney-General a consistent attack on the Age tapes and a consistent attempt to deny that they exist, are authentic, have meant anything or led anywhere-a campaign which he has vigorously pursued. When anyone has got in the way and when Mr Justice Athol Moffitt or anyone else has commented, Senator Gareth Evans has been the first to attack.

SPEECH.PARA: The beneficiary of this legislation, if passed in this form, will be not His Honour Mr Justice Murphy but all the grotty `little mates' in New South Wales, all the little spivs and shysters in the Australian Labor Party in New South Wales and all the criminals in New South Wales who receive under this legislation protection from disclosure of evidence which should be pursued. This motive cannot be said to be absent in view of the way in which the Government is proceeding with this shabby legislation. If anything, it exposes the Government's hypocrisy and the role of the Minister in charge of this legislation. In the same week in which the former Attorney-General complained and grizzled about the potential withdrawal of the so-called Bill of Rights, he has introduced a piece of legislation which, in terms of its assaults on Parliament's rights, on the right of people to see that justice is done and on the rights of a free Press, constitutes the gravest attempt to traduce rights that this Parliament has ever seen.

The former Attorney-General has been given support by the Australian Democrats. Senator Haines participated today in this debate in her first major contribution as Leader of the Australian Democrats. If that is to be her standard, she will indeed be like St Simon of Cyrene-condemned to carry the cross for the last few steps. Under that type of leadership and with that type of integrity brought to bear on legislation, once again the Australian Democrats stand exposed not only as the fourth wing of the Labor Party in this chamber but as a group which has no interest in seeing that justice is properly done and that people are properly pursued when they should be. It is not without significance that there is not one member of the Australian Democrats present now or prepared to participate in the rest of the debate.

I want to take up a number of matters in the second reading speech and the legislation and to return to a point which I made earlier about the legislation's attempt to cover up a great deal that would cause political embarrassment to the Australian Labor Party. The editorial in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald is headed:
Beyond Murphy a cover-up.
It states:

The Federal Government can be no more proud of its handling of the issues raised by the NSW Police tapes than the NSW Government can of its. Now, against the odds, Canberra has surpassed even that poor record. Whatever the merits of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry (Repeal) Bill, its provisions making it illegal to publish allegations derived from documents gathered by the commission are indefensible.
It continues:
While the commission was confined to considering Justice Murphy's fitness as a judge, its inquiry inevitably must have confronted broader issues.
The editorial concludes:

It will be recognised as yet another attempt to delay the full examination of questions concerning the health of basic institutions-the courts and Parliament-in NSW; questions which have demanded answers for almost three years since the NSW Police tapes first came to light.
During the whole period, Senator Evans and representatives of the Labor Party in New South Wales have sought to prevent public scrutiny of any of those matters.

I turn to the comments in the pathetic second reading speech. We are told that to continue the inquiry would be contrary to established practice and to natural justice. None of us disagrees with that. But what are the other principles of natural justice? One of them is that, when a criminal offence is disclosed and someone else is named in a situation that could lead to action being taken against him, the Government should not seek by legislation to suppress that material and prevent justice taking its course in relation to other persons. That is the effect of this legislation.

It goes on to say, quite correctly, that the Commission is not able to make any finding. That is fair enough, it has not been able to make any finding, but it has been able to gather and evaluate evidence which might well be of value to a Director of Public Prosecutions or a National Crime Authority in areas that they should be able to look at. The legislation puts into the hands of the Presiding Officers of this Parliament the power of censorship. The Presiding Officers of this Parliament, persons who, I remind you, Mr Acting Deputy President, unlike, say, the Speaker of the House of Commons, are persons who are part of the partisan party debate in these chambers, have had placed into their hands the power of censorship, because they are charged by this legislation with making a decision about the release or otherwise of documents. It is not just the current occupants of the respective chairs; if one looks at the amendment to clause 7, circulated on behalf of the Government, one sees that a class A document, even after 30 years, is not to be released except in accordance with the written authority of the Presiding Officers. Even in 30 years time the Presiding Officers of these two chambers will have the power to deny public access to that class A document.

What is going to be the situation if at some stage a chamber of the Parliament resolves that documents in the possession of its Presiding Officer are to be presented to it and the Presiding Officer says: `I am constrained by sub-section (6) from giving you that information because ``a person'' is defined to include a House of the Parliament'? In other words, for the first time we have a government attempting by legislation to say to one of the chambers of the freely and democratically elected parliament: `You no longer have the right to require the production of documents which it may be in the public interest to have produced'. No government has ever previously said to a parliament `You do not have the right to obtain and to examine material' because no government has had so much to cover up as this Government has arising from this particular inquiry and this piece of legislation.

I will not even attempt to get into the interesting debate about the attempt by Senator Gareth Evans, both in this legislation and in the Budget, to make sure that the Freedom of Information Act 1982 has no impact or effect-and that from a person who waxed so eloquent in this place about the freedom of information and who criticised Senator Durack and honourable senators on this side when in government, but is now part not only of denying access but also of making freedom of information a sick joke under a Labor administration.

I come now to the question of what this legislation does in relation to inquiries which are currently under way under State jurisdiction. Presumably under section 109 of the Constitution this will be taken as a piece of legislation overriding State legislation dealing with similar matters or, indeed, with the same matter. State legislation, to the extent that it is in conflict with the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry (Repeal) Act, will fall to the ground. In New South Wales material already under investigation by law enforcement authorities touches upon material which is in the hands of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry. For instance, evidence given on 15 November 1983 by a Mr Anderson before the select committee of the Legislative Assembly upon prostitution in Sydney related to a number of matters touching upon Morgan Ryan, Mr Sankey and allegations in relation to His Honour Mr Justice Murphy. That material was raised in the House of Representatives on 2 June by Mr Aldred in the debate on the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation legislation. At the end of that debate the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) invited Mr Aldred to submit the material to the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry if he thought it was that important, so Mr Aldred did. The matter was sent to the presiding member, Sir George Lush; and the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry, knowing that the material was also in the hands of the National Crime Authority, obtained the full details of in camera text relating to this matter.

Is this a document, in terms of its part A status, now to be suppressed? If anybody in the media publishes the details of this, are they to be liable for penalty and for prosecution? Why should there be a protection extended to the other persons? Why should the New South Wales police be put in jeopardy for pursuing a matter, having obtained material derived from a document received by the Commission-not a document which the Commission caused to come into being, but a document received by the Commission-when, under the terms of clause 8 of this legislation, the disclosure of that document-created outside the Commission, submitted to the Commission and received by the Commission-is now protected by this shabby piece of legislation?

What is to be the case if, for instance, matters laid before the Commission touch upon the national security of this country? What is to be the case if there is material before the Commission which touches upon Mr Justice Murphy's fitness to hold office by relating questions about the 1973 ASIO raid which might touch upon issues of real national security? Are those documents to be suppressed? Of course they are; and for what purpose, one may well ask. They are to be suppressed, even after the expiry of the 30-year rule, if one of the Presiding Officers so determines.

The effect of this legislation extends primarily to the protection of those who were on the other end of the telephone. If the allegations relating to the Greek conspiracy case, to Don Thomas, to the Sala case, to the New South Wales police tapes and to the Age tapes have been laid before the Commission of Inquiry, the people involved in those matters are going to be given protection under this legislation. I put it to honourable senators that this legislation has been introduced in this form for no purpose other than to suppress information. Had the Government fundamentally been concerned with the rights and privileges of His Honour Mr Justice Murphy, as it should have been, it could have terminated the inquiry. It would not have found massive opposition to the termination of the inquiry per se and it could have looked sensibly at what to do with the material. It could have said, for instance: `Let the material be sent to the National Crime Authority and let the National Crime Authority determine whether there is any- thing which it should pursue'. The Government could have said that it could be sent to the Director of Public Prosecutions, and the Director of Public Prosecutions, who has been traduced in this place by Senator Gareth Evans over the Murphy issue, clearly could have asked whether he was in a position to pursue further investigations in the matter.

We have a whole series of blanket exemptions put into this legislation. His Honour Mr Justice Murphy, who is deserving of the personal sympathy of all members of this Parliament for his personal predicament, will not be the only beneficiary of this exemption; he is being used shamefully by Senator Gareth Evans in order to extend a blanket protection from the proper operations of investigation and the laws in a way that tonight will cause many a champagne cork to pop in the organised crime syndicates around the city of Sydney.

This whole exercise undertaken by the Government has to be seen in precisely that fashion. Not only does it traduce the rights of the Parliament to obtain material, not only does it make the Presiding Officers of the Parliament censors of material, not only does it extend the most extraordinary draconian penalties against the free publication of information, but it goes to the extent, I put it to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, of making it a virtual impossibility actually to maintain the structure which is proposed. For instance, if any of the material comes into the hands of a member of parliament and he discloses it under privilege, can the Government take any action? No. If that disclosure made under privilege is reported in the newspapers, can the Government take any action? Maybe it can, but at least there will be some fine arguments about the qualified privilege of the media in reporting matters which are raised in the Parliament. How are the Government and the prosecution-the Crown-going to prove that material which is in the public domain has been derived `from a document received, obtained or prepared, or information received or obtained by the Commission, the staff of the Commission or counsel assisting the Commission' when, after all, it is going to be virtually impossible to prove under this legislation what material it is that the Commission holds anyway? How are they going to prove any mens rea or that that was derived from that source?

I put it to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that this is a nightmare piece of legislation because in seeking to do one thing, namely to extend a proper administration of justice in the case of Mr Justice Lionel Murphy, it has in fact done a great deal more. I put it to you that it has done a great deal more because it has been the consistent policy of the Labor Party in government federally, of the Labor Party in government in New South Wales and of Senator Gareth Evans in particular to make sure that certain information never becomes public. This is the purport of the Bill, going further than simply winding up the Commission of Inquiry and ensuring that the papers, the documents and material in the possession of that Commission are effectively used in relation to persons other than Mr Justice Murphy to ensure that natural justice and, indeed, justice in any form is properly done and properly rendered to the rest of the Australian community.

It is for those reasons that the Opposition is totally opposed to this piece of legislation, to this attempt to ensure that there is not full and open public debate on issues of public significance, and why this will stand as yet another monument to the way in which Senator Evans and the Government of which he is a member are unprepared to tackle the issue of organised crime and are prepared to do everything to protect their grubby little mates in New South Wales.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Opposition in its total opposition to this most draconian legislation that is before us today. At the outset I would like to say that I regret very much the state of health that Mr Justice Murphy finds himself in--
—More crocodile tears.

—Oh, just shut up. My own father died of carcinoma of the colon and I was with him for every day over a period which extended for nearly a year. It is an affliction that I would not want to wish on anyone. The state of health that Mr Justice Murphy suffers from is something that is quite different from the matter of the probity of Mr Justice Murphy's name and his integrity as a member of the High Court of Australia. Those two issues are quite divorced and quite separate.

SPEECH.PARA: In the parliamentary traditions that we observe we recognise the difference, indeed the total separation, between the legislature and he judiciary. We who make the laws do not interpret them. We do not administer justice. That is a principle to which we hold very strongly. At the same time, as legislators we must be vitally concerned with the quality of the administration of justice; with the integrity of the courts. It is absolutely fundamental to our existence here as a parliamentary democracy. If we, as legislators, are not concerned about the quality of the courts, their integrity and their freedom from suspicion in any way at all we might as well give up and hand over to some dictatorial regime.

Mr Justice Murphy must be allowed the opportunity to clear his name. He must be allowed that from a personal point of view. But more than that, for the institution of the courts of Australia he must be granted the opportunity to clear his name. We have this action of the Government today bringing in this Bill, the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry (Repeal) Bill, as part of a series of quite bizarre and extraordinary actions. We have the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) at the other end of the building and the Ministry behind him arguing that on the one hand Mr Justice Murphy is too sick to appear before the Commission of Inquiry, and therefore he should be excused. I think that is a relevant and pertinent argument. Yet at the same time they are defending his right to sit on the High Court. Those two assertions are contradictory; they cannot be argued together. I think there are good medical grounds why Mr Justice Murphy should not be sitting on the High Court. When someone is in the state of health he is in we cannot overrule the possibility that his judgment is affected. A human being is naturally preoccupied with his state of health when he knows that he has a terminal illness, as Mr Justice Murphy has, and I think there is a very good argument to be made that to deal with the matters of intellectual complexity that come before the High Court is beyond someone who knows that he will die possibly in a month or two.

The other problem with Mr Justice Murphy sitting on the Bench is the fact that he is probably under some sort of medication. Those of us who have operated in the medical and pharmacological fields know that the unpredictability of medication is well established. Studies have been made in history of the state of health of political leaders and the way it has affected their judgment. I believe there are good and solid reasons why Mr Justice Murphy should not be sitting on the High Court at the present time. But we have a Government that argues that it is quite proper for him to be sitting on the High Court; yet he is not well enough to appear before a commission.

Far more serious than that is the way in which Mr Justice Murphy attacked the Chief Justice in a public statement some weeks ago. That was a grossly unethical and unprofessional statement by Mr Justice Murphy. But the really scandalous thing was the way the Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia was left isolated and alone by the people who should have defended him-the Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans and other people in the Ministry. That portrayed a fundamental contempt for the rule of law that they profess to live under. Neither Mr Justice Murphy nor the Government by that action is entitled to our respect. They showed that they have nothing but contempt for the institution of the court in Australia. We have in the Chief Justice a person of impeccable character and probity. We have a man who is fully conscious of the high office he holds; yet he was left alone, isolated and unsupported when the very roots of his professional reputation were attacked by Mr Justice Murphy.

Looking at the legislation, we come to this extraordinary clause 8. We in this chamber have listened to endless diatribes on human rights by members of the Labor Party. Legislation which strips human rights from ordinary Australians has never before been moved through this Parliament. This takes away their rights and privileges because in clause 8 it takes the right of free speech away from them. Senator Puplick in his brilliant speech quoted from the Sydney Morning Herald editorial today. I will not repeat it, but editorials around Australia all virulently attack the Government on this move. I quote from the Hobart Mercury. Part of its editorial today, Thursday, 21 August, states:

The Government is seeking a degree of secrecy now not even accorded events which occurred during war time which cast national and military leaders in roles they would perhaps prefer to have avoided. Because of this the Government's actions are scandalous.

The action of the Government is scandalous in trying to suppress the information already before the Commission and in bringing in draconian penalties for anyone in the Press or the public who comments on them in the future. This really is the action of a Third World country, a banana republic. Since we have a Treasurer who comes from a banana republic, I suppose it is fitting that we have an Attorney-General and a Ministry who are of the same kidney.

Let us consider the morally bankrupt party, the Australian Democrats. The same day they move a notice of motion to guillotine the Bill of Rights, with all the crocodile tears associated with that, they throw their sycophantic support behind this Bill, which denies any form of human rights. The Commission of Inquiry goes to the heart of the probity and integrity of public administration in Australia. We have the very sinister feature of the Government coming in to suppress any comment that ordinary law-abiding citizens might make. I could understand, sympathise and support a government move to spare Mr Justice Murphy any mental duress in the final months of his life. If the Government wishes to protect Mr Justice Murphy in any way, I would support that; but in linking the legislation to free Mr Justice Murphy from the Commission of Inquiry with this draconian legislation to try to cover up all the scandals in public administration that are running through the community the Government has linked two unlinkable factors.

Why is the Government doing this? It cannot succeed, as Senator Lewis, Senator Sir John Carrick and Senator Puplick said. The Government will never be able to sustain the suppression of truth. This Government began by castrating the National Crime Authority. The Government turned it into a joke-an ineffectual organisation. Today we have the suppression of any information that has come before the Commission of Inquiry into Mr Justice Murphy. What will we have next week? Those opposite cannot keep plugging the holes when the tank is leaking as it is at present. The Government is not concerned primarily with protecting Mr Justice Murphy. It is concerned with the people who have been associated with him and with the Australian Labor Party and about whom evidence has been given before the Commission. This Bill ought to be withdrawn. We ought to let the laws of this country, which are perfectly adequate to deal with this situation, run their course. By so doing, truth and justice will prevail.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Allegations about Mr Justice Murphy started long before I entered this chamber. The Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry (Repeal) Bill 1986 effectively seeks to repeal the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry. The Bill to set up the inquiry was passed only in the last parliamentary session. Even those of us without long memories can recall the fiasco last session on what would happen to Mr Justice Murphy. Finally, the Government caved in, did what it should have done in the first place, and established this inquiry. But it did not give in willingly. Only after considerable time and considerable pressure was the Commission established. Many people around Australia saw the Commission as providing an opportunity to do two things: To settle the mystery that had surrounded Mr Justice Murphy and the allegations that some people had made; and to restore confidence in the High Court of Australia. We thought we could look forward to those two things happening if this Commission were able to run its full term and present Parliament with its findings.

SPEECH.PARA: What has happened since last session is very regrettable. As the second reading speech points out, Mr Justice Murphy is in a most regrettable position. He has a terminal illness which, in the absence of remission, will mean that he will not live very long. That is regrettable, but there is nothing we can do about that. We now see the Government seeking to take the opportunity to use that accident of history, if you like, to lock away the consequences of the material before the Commission. We heard a contribution this morning from Senator Haines, the newly elected leader of the Australian Democrats. In the brief time that I have been in this Parliament it is the most disgraceful contribution I have heard. Senator Haines basically said two things. First, she said, in effect, that she did not care whether all this material was burnt or shredded. As far as she was concerned, that could easily happen and she would not bat an eyelid.

TALK.START.PARA: —Irresponsible.

—That was an irresponsible and disgraceful contribution by Senator Haines. The reason she offered for this disgraceful point of view was that, to use my words, all the material could be thrown in the bin because as far as the Australian Democrats were concerned they had not agreed with the establishment of a commission of inquiry in the first place. By taking the line that all the material could be chucked in the bin because the Democrats did not think the Commission should have been set up in the first place, Senator Haines is saying that if one does not like the course of history and if one has the opportunity to erase the facts of history one should take that opportunity-just as Tricky Dickie Nixon supposedly did with the tapes. If one has the opportunity to wipe something from the record or lock it away, that is what one should do. Senator Haines now stands as the new queen of newspeak, as outlined in Orwell's 1984-a couple of years too late but nonetheless so. That is exactly what Senator Haines is saying. The Democrats did not want the Commission in the first place. So as far as they are concerned all the material can be locked away.

SPEECH.PARA: That ignores a number of matters. Firstly, it ignores the special report of which we have the benefit, and particularly the first paragraph of the report in which the three judges indicate that they found 14 allegations they would deal with which had been presented to the judge. Those were not simply 14 rumours or scandal-mongering snippets of information dragged up from the gutter, which is what Senator Haines would have us believe, but 14 specific allegations that had been formulated by three eminent legal personalities. The contribution from the Democrats seeks to ignore that. They would like to believe that it has not happened and that it can be disposed of.

Secondly, Senator Haines's disgraceful contribution, in addition to ignoring the report of which we now have the benefit, seems to ignore completely the needs of historians and future parliamentarians. Thirdly, it ignores the value most Australians put on the High Court and their desire to have this Murphy mystery resolved. It will not be resolved by following the Government's proposed course of action. To lock the information away from the eyes of future parliamentarians and historians is an attempt to doctor history in a time-warped sort of way and thereby to undermine the integrity of some of our institutions. It is not a satisfactory course of action and it is one that each of us, to the greatest extent possible, should ensure does not proceed.

Some points made in the debate this morning bear repeating. In my view the first point which bears repeating is that Justice Lionel Murphy should be treated in the same manner as every other citizen who finds himself in this position. He should have the same rights and responsibilities, and no more. No explanation has been offered, that I have heard, that justifies this information, effectively, being locked away. As has been pointed out, if the course of Mr Justice Murphy's regrettable illness is a brief one, the situation of the libel laws will change and there will be no protection for him. So one has to ask, as other speakers have: Who will be protected by this information being locked away? If we accept that Mr Justice Murphy's illness is terminal and that the libel laws will then be free, one has to ask: Who will be protected? That has not been answered, and it should be answered.

Another point I wish to make is in respect of Mr Justice Murphy's illness. As the second reading speech says, in the absence of a remission he will not live very long. One then wonders, given the second reading speech makes it quite clear that there is the possibility of remission, what the Government will do if Mr Justice Murphy is one of the very few-there are such people alive today, very lucky people-who find themselves the beneficiaries of a substantial remission. If this Bill is passed we will have crossed a bridge and it will be very difficult to return. I would like to hear a response from the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) as to why the Commission cannot continue and decide for itself when it has exhausted all possible opportunities of reporting to this Parliament.

A further point I would like to make is that some of the speakers in this debate-particularly people in the Press-would like to portray the Commission's continuing as the pursuit of a dying man and an attempt to darken further his reputation. I disagree with that version of the facts and I believe that it should be looked upon as a pursuit to unravel a mystery. The mystery has darkened his reputation and in my view has darkened the reputation of the High Court of Australia. Therefore, we should be doing everything we can to ensure that Mr Justice Murphy's name is cleared and that the reputation of the High Court is restored to what it was before this ugly business reared its head. One of the most important things we should be considering is the restriction that this Bill places on the primary source material for future historians. Surely the Democrats would not advocate, for example, politicians and historians of today not having access to the Warren Commission material for the Kennedy assassination. One could go on and give further examples of where matters have been resolved years and years down the track. Obviously this matter will not be resolved now, but locking the information away prevents the resolution at a later time. Senator Evans would do well to advise the chamber of whether he would have advocated that files and evidence relating to the British nuclear tests should have been suppressed and destroyed by previous governments. That is similar to what the Government is now attempting to do with respect to the Commission of Inquiry.

I conclude by saying that as a South Australian I regret the disgraceful contribution made this morning by Senator Haines. I agree with Senator Sir John Carrick that for the Democrats to continue to say that they are here to keep the bastards honest is nothing less than a joke. The cartoon in the Canberra Times this morning was very amusing. It does not relate to this matter, I know, but it gives an indication of the views people are beginning to hold of the Democrats. They are beginning to see them for exactly what they are, the greatest bunch of opportunists that this Parliament has ever seen. I repeat that as a South Australian I am ashamed of the contribution Senator Haines made. In my view it shows no respect for Mr Justice Murphy and for the opportunity he may have to clear his reputation. It shows no respect for the High Court and the restoration of its reputation. I dissociate myself completely from any remarks Senator Haines may have made and associate myself with the remarks of my colleagues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —As an ex-journalist I am particularly concerned about the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry Bill. It seems to me that particular clauses of the Bill have some inhibiting factors on the capacity of some matters to be raised in the future, matters which need not necessarily impinge on the status or the standing of Mr Justice Murphy. The matter that particularly concerns me is a matter to which the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) addressed himself in the other place last night. He said that there was a capacity for people who had made submissions to the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry to get those submissions back from the Commission, and in that way refer them themselves to any other law enforcement agencies or any other such bodies.
—Yes.

—I notice that the Minister representing the Attorney-General says yes. This appears to solve part of the problem to which some people have been addressing themselves today. However, what concerns me is that if the Commission ceases to exist after the passage of this legislation, how can this material be handed back to the people by the Commission when the Commission is not there? That seems to me to be an insuperable problem unless Opposition amendments relating to the continuation of the Commission for certain purposes should proceed. It is evident that this sort of problem will continue. Mr Lionel Bowen addressed himself to this problem at some length on page 298 of yesterday's House of Representatives Hansard. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . if a request were made the material would be handed back.
He further said:
Does the honourable member think the Commission would not have done that-
that is, convey the information to appropriate authorities-
or would not do it even now if that were the position?
But the point is the Commission will not have the capacity to hand it on.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you give me five minutes before the break I will answer these questions fully, right now.
—That is all very well. The clear point is that the Attorney-General has made statements--

—And they are right. The Commission fully intends to hand back every document submitted to it by the individual to that individual or agency under section 18 (2) of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry Act. It will do so before the Commission's authority ceases, before this repeal Bill is assented to. Equally, the Commission proposes, under section 34 (2), to give to appropriate law enforcement agencies any material of a kind which is colourable and which has attracted so much attention this morning. The Government will allow it the capacity to do so. There has been so much misconstruction of the legislation.

—This is absolutely incredible. At this stage of the debate Government members have had opportunities to participate, to clarify things and to give assurances that this Senate should have received before we debated this matter. It is a matter of major moment, a matter not properly addressed in Mr Lionel Bowen's response last night. He made a general position without the assurance that the Minister has now given by way of interjection rather than by way of substantive statement in the other place. We have been treated with contempt by this Government. Yesterday, the Government sought to railroad this through, in as brief a time as possible, so that matters such as this would not be properly debated. It was a deliberate attempt by this Government to misdirect this place, and not to give us the opportunity in a second reading debate to reply to these particular matters. It is absolutely disgraceful that by way of interjection the Minister for Resources and Energy has now provided what he claims is a total and substantive response to a matter which, I must say, I hope we will have the opportunity to deal with at some length subsequently. This displays the approach of the Government to the whole matter. There is a suggestion by way of interjection that in fact the points being made by the Opposition have no substance. I do not in fact believe that there is anything in the legislation which supports the Minister's proposition. If the Minister is simply giving his personal undertaking-without any comment on him-I need to say only that the Senate should not be prepared to accept, on the basis of that personal undertaking, which I understand he has given, an assurance on a matter of major substance relating to the legislation and for which there is no statement in writing and no amendment. It seems to me incredible that the Minister could hope to get away with this style of management in regard to a matter of such immense significance.
—It is not being broadcast.

—It may well be, as the honourable senator has said, that because the proceedings are not being broadcast today the Minister thinks he can get away with this kind of rubbish. The reality is that amendments have been formulated by the Opposition because it is seeking to make certain that this kind of situation, about which it is concerned, cannot obtain. Of course, that is another reason why the amendments are so absolutely vital. We simply cannot rely on an interjected assurance by the Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: As I had started to say before this incredible interlude, as an ex-journalist I am absolutely appalled at the attempts, which now appear to be unnecessary in the legislation, to impose enormous penalties and burdens on journalists and any other element of the media that seek to reveal matters that clearly are matters of major substance-matters not simply affecting the standing or status of Mr Justice Lionel Murphy. I must say that I have the greatest feelings of sympathy for Mr Justice Lionel Murphy, with whom, I might also say, I enjoyed a very friendly personal relationship some 20 to 25 years ago when we were both members of a dining club at university.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sanctimonious fool!

—I thank the Minister for that interjection. I am overjoyed to have it recorded. The only response to matters of major significance in this place is that kind of personal abuse by a Minister whose own standing cannot bear thorough examination in this place and whose intention it is to scurry from the Senate as soon as possible.
—Order! I ask the honourable senator to direct his remarks through the Chair.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I was addressing you. I was saying that the Minister seeks to scurry from this Senate because in fact the heat in the kitchen is too great.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order--
—What is the point of order?
—Order! There is no point of order. I ask Senator Baume to continue.

—Exactly. What concerns me are the attempts to censor the media, in particular, and to impose incredible penalties on the media for releasing information which, as I say, need not necessarily bear any relevance at all to the standing or status of Mr Justice Lionel Murphy but which may be very solidly indeed on the level of corruption in the State of New South Wales-a level of corruption with which it appears from much evidence, printed and other, and certainly on various tapes, that the New South Wales machine of the Australian Labor Party is very closely involved.
—Where were you in the Askin years?
—I think that there are three clear concerns which we can examine. Why on earth, if in fact there is no problem-
—Where were you in the Askin years, with your colleague next to you? What party were you in? What were you doing about it? You were doing nothing all those years.

—I must say, Mr Acting Deputy President, that I hope that those interjections are being recorded in Hansard and that they serve to reveal the nature of the Minister for Community Services, who is at the table. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Grimes) agreed to:
That, unless otherwise ordered, till 2 p.m. this day, matters of public interest may be discussed by Senators, provided that no Senator shall speak for more than 15 minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, after the conclusion of tomorrow's sitting the two Houses of this Parliament will be in recess for three weeks. This is unprecedented, as I understand it. The reason, I think, ought to be clearly stated. It is normal when a Budget has been brought down, and more urgently so because of the nature of this Budget, that the two Houses of Parliament should meet to debate in detail the Budget and its nature and to expose its aspects to the people of Australia. So frightened is the Government of the nature of this Budget that, in fact, it has deliberately closed down the Parliament for three weeks. Let it be understood that the measure of its mistrust in this Budget is the recess that will follow.

SPEECH.PARA: The right place to deal with money matters, the right place to deal with Budgets, is in this Parliament; that is the purpose for which it exists. It is no good the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the somewhat soiled Treasurer (Mr Keating) now saying that they are going out to sell it to the public. Their first duty is to explain the Budget to this Parliament and to stand up and be counted. On that point I want to take some time of the Senate at this lunchtime since we are not to be allowed to do so in the three weeks ahead.

The public must come to understand that an enormous confidence trick has been played upon them. For three years, day after day, week after week, the Hawke Government and all its Ministers told the public that things were getting better, that indeed they had never had it better, that the Hawke Government had the whole of the economy under control and the economy was getting stronger. Then, by an inadvertent remark of the Treasurer that we were approaching a banana republic, a series of chain events happened. Those chain events happened day by day by day revealing that everything that the Government had said in the past by way of confidence in the economy was wrong, that the economy was in fact moving towards that of a banana republic; that, in fact, the living standards of the people of Australia were falling and would continue to fall.

Against that background a sudden change of tune occurred with the Government and the people of Australia were told that they would have to have a Budget which would be harsh and the effect of which would be to move to restore the economy. I want to point out what has happened with this Budget. The fact is that the Government has said that the cause of all this recession is off-shore, it is overseas, it is due to the relationship of our balance of trade; and indeed our trade has fallen 3 per cent in real terms and therefore the living standards of the Australian people must fall in real terms that way. That, in itself, is a confidence trick because the balance of trade is brought about by the residue as between exports and imports-the money earned by exports and the costs of imports.

Under this Government, imports in volume and cost have risen day by day. Australia has been flooded with imports to the great detriment of our ordinary working people because the imports have provided employment opportunities for people overseas to the detriment of the 8 or 9 per cent of the unemployed in Australia, and particularly the young. Steadily over the years of this Government employment in manufacturing has fallen year by year. Investment has fallen year by year and therefore the opportunity to bring about import replacement has disappeared and the jobs for our young have fallen. So that the truth of the matter does not lie with--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a load of rubbish and you know it.

—I suggest you go back to Robe River and look at the load of rubbish there. Senator Coleman has interjected that it is a load of rubbish to say that in fact imports have risen over recent years, that investment has fallen in manufacturing, that in fact the numbers of people in manufacturing have fallen. They are the things that I have said and they have fallen steadily over the years.
—Where did they fall?

—Let me tell you why they fell. I am delighted to be asked that. I have the figures here so I am glad to be able to tell why, in fact, manufacturing fell, because it was a very spectacular period. In that period of 18 months beginning in 1973 under Mr Hawke as President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions and under the Whitlam Labor Party wages rose in Australia a record 37 per cent, and 52 per cent in the three-year period. A cut in tariffs occurred of 25 per cent and in one year 110,000 people went out of manufacturing. That started the real run, the real drain in manufacturing. Now, do we say rubbish or should I incorporate these figures?
—Come on, tell us about 1981-82.

—Thank you very much. The Minister asks about 1981 and 1982. I will give these figures because they are very interesting indeed. In the three years of the McMahon Government average weekly earnings rose 30.5 per cent. In the three subsequent years of the Whitlam Government they rose 55.2 per cent. In the next three years of the Fraser Government they dropped back to 30.7 per cent, a fall from 50 per cent, and then a man named Hawke, as the President of the ACTU, talked up a massive wage rise in 1981-82 as he did before.
—Order! I remind the honourable senator that this is a non-controversial debate. I ask that the interjections on my right cease and remind the Senate that it is a non-controversial debate.

—On a point of order: It was intended to be a non-controversial debate. There was that intention when these new sitting hours were first set. However, that has gone by the board, I am afraid. You are not aware of that. It is a time for debate of matters of special interest. People can raise whatever matters they like. The non-controversial nature of the debate was, of course, upheld always by people on this side but it has gone by the board since people on that side decided that that was not sufficient.

—The expression `non-controversial' has been totally misrepresented in this place. The position was that there was agreement that there should be debate which would not give rise to divisions or quorums. The term `non-controversial', certainly in the understanding of the Opposition, was that it was debate that would not lead to senators who were availing themselves of the lunch time for the civilised practice of having some lunch being brought back to the chamber by the bells ringing. It was never the view of the Opposition that this debate could not be on very contentious matters like nuclear disarmament and many others. I do not wish to take Senator Sir John Carrick's time and I am sorry for eating into it but I think the record should be clear on that. As far as the Opposition is concerned any matter can be debated. We should not take action which would lead to a division.
—The Chair accepts the explanation by the Manager of Government Business and the Leader of the Opposition.

—I was attempting to say that it was a disgraceful thing that the Government should lift the Houses of Parliament in the three weeks immediately following the Budget and therefore prevent a discussion on the Budget in that time. I am taking, as is my absolute right, this time to discuss that. I want to point out that the Government has said that the country is in recession and living standards have fallen; therefore we must have a hard Budget. What has happened is extraordinary. We have heard why we have got to have it and now we look at the Budget to see what it contains.

SPEECH.PARA: The Budget, in fact, says that the balance of trade will be as bad at the end of the financial year as at the beginning so there will be no improvement on the salient facts. The Budget says that business investment will fall so that things will get worse. The Budget says that primary industry will get lower prices and probably more difficulty in getting volumes so that it will be worse off. The Budget says that unemployment will rise over the course of this year and uses an exchange rate figure of 52c to indicate for its costing of all its figures what it says the exchange rate will be through the year.

The Government, having said that it must do everything to stop this declining exchange rate and, presumably, to improve it, has put in a figure that is at its present lowest depths; and it has predicated for the rest of this year that the exchange rate will be judged by the people of the world at its present miserable level or, indeed, worse. These are facts. They are not controversial. I am using the Budget Papers. The Budget itself does a lot of pretence in that regard. It says it is giving a one per cent real increase in expenditure to the Defence Department, and then shows that by the impact of the fringe benefits tax and the impact of the exchange the real purchasing power of the Defence Department will be less. So one must look very hard at it.

The Budget says we have to do a number of things. We have to lower living standards, and certainly that is demonstrable, and we have therefore to increase taxes. It is the highest taxing Budget on record, with the highest taxing Treasurer on record. It has done a number of absolute confidence tricks. It has slid the tax cuts for three months to December and has slid the pension rises for six weeks; that helps it to get an improved final deficit. But the fact is that it cannot slide that past the next Budget and what it is building up will be quite an impossibility in the next Budget. The tax cuts and the pension rises will all be part of the then cost situation.

I rose because I wanted to point out first of all that the basic flaw in the Government's argument that the balance of trade on the falling export prices of primary products and minerals was the fundamental factor. I wanted to point out the importance of the fact that our internal cost structure is such that we cannot, in fact, compete overseas and because that cost structure is so high we are losing jobs in the whole of our employment range, particularly amongst our young. The truth is that under this Government costs of production have been indexed to be uncompetitive deliberately with the rest of the trading partners of the world. In other words, by indexing wages and inflation we have maintained the gap between the competitiveness of our opponents and ourselves and that has gone on.

We are coming in this Budget to another situation where inflation, which the Government said would be reduced, is going to remain as high, or higher. The Government is very good at blaming others, and particularly former governments. It is well to remind this Senate, Mr Acting Deputy President, that in the last year of the Whitlam Government inflation was, on statutory consumer price index figures, 17 1/2 per cent, running to 20 per cent. It was halved over a period by the Fraser Government. It is now on the rise again.

The figures that are shown in the Budget, of course, take no account of the huge extra taxes that are going to be imposed by the States and local governments on the people. So that pensioners, fixed income people and lower income people have to pay. It would be good if in fact the sacrifice were worth while, but it is important to understand that the Budget says that at the end of this financial year things will be worse than at the beginning. We will do all these kinds of things, all this cost cutting and saving, all this extra taxing, and we will find that inflation will be as high or higher. Unemployment will be substantially higher. Primary industry will be worse off. Our trade will still be in grave imbalance and yet we will have paid the sacrifice that has been asked in the Budget.

The sacrifice is important and it should be shared, but at least it ought to be directed towards a goal. Today I have used the Government's figures and the Government has condemned itself in its own Budget Papers. It has said, in fact, that things will be worse after this Budget is implemented.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to refer briefly to the specific disadvantages that the Illawarra region in general and the city of Wollongong in particular appear to be suffering as a result of this Budget. I am not getting up here to say that there should not have been expenditure cuts in the Budget; on the contrary my strong view is that the expenditure cuts were totally inadequate to cope with the disaster which is now befalling the Australian economy largely as a result of incredible and inappropriate governmental policies. The Budget we are now seeing should have been, at least in outline, introduced at least a year ago, but, of course, that is only an outline because in specifics it simply is not doing, as my friend and colleague Senator Sir John Carrick said, the job which is needed.

SPEECH.PARA: Nonetheless, when one looks at what is being done one sees an extraordinary emphasis on hitting areas such as Wollongong which are already severely depressed, largely as a result of governmental policies so far. In particular, for example, there is the decision to close the Wollongong office of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. This is despite the fact that there is something like a 30 per cent migrant content in the population of the Illawarra region and despite the fact that there were something like 25,000 telephone inquiries and about 20,000 office inquiries of the Department in Wollongong last year. Something like 500 new arrivals came to Wollongong last year and with an office staff of something like 10 permanent officers servicing this enormous region with this very, very large migrant population requiring services, it does seem to be extraordinary that the Government should have made this decision if in fact there is no significant saving of expenditure involved.

This is the issue, because one will need to be convinced that there is any saving whatsoever in this mean-minded decision to close the Wollongong office of the Immigration Department. It is evident, of course, if there is any burden on the Government, that it will transfer that burden to the people of the Illawarra region who need the services of the Immigration Department. It is clear that for the Government to justify this quaint decision it will have to establish what are the gross and net savings; that is, after taking into account costs of servicing from Sydney the 62,000 migrants who live in the Wollongong area.

We will want to know what are the gross and net savings involved in closing the office; and not simply in a full year, but what the cost savings will be this year. This is supposed to be the crisis year. This is the year we are in the bunker because it is war-like, according to the Prime Minister. What savings will there be this year? Of course, in making its announcement the Government ducked the issue. It did not say what the savings would be this year, let alone in a full year.

I have been advised that under the criteria applied by the Department this office is described as cost-efficient. I would like to know from the Government-and I think the Government has a duty to tell the people of Wollongong, who are so consistently misled on this matter and so many other matters-whether or not this office would have made a profit in the current financial year because its services to the public are, in fact, all chargeable. Fees are paid by the public for the services provided by the Immigration Department. If this office was in fact going to make a profit it would be very interesting to see how the Government justifies closing it. I wonder what the figures really are. It would be a good idea if the Government came clean.

No doubt the Government's attitude to Wollongong is, as the seats in and around it are safe for Labor, that it does not have to worry about looking after the people of Wollongong or making justifications for absurd, unfair and unreasonable decisions adversely affecting that region. I want to know: Will there be any cuts in employment staff levels in the Department as a result of closing this office? What are they, if any? For how long is the lease of the premises it presently occupies? I understand that there is still two years to go of the lease. What is to be the cost, if any, of terminating that lease or will another government instrumentality occupy it? If so, what will be the cost of its giving up whatever other area it had?

I go even further. As I understand it, it had been planned that the Department of Immigration would occupy part of the $17m Commonwealth offices that the Government had announced were to be built in Wollongong and expenditure for which was supposed to be undertaken this year. It appears from the fine print of the Budget Papers that that will not proceed. We have seen no announcement, of course. The Government has not `fessed up'. The Government has not had the honesty to tell the people of Wollongong that that office is not proceeding. All that one sees when one looks at the Commonwealth-approved capital works program for 1986-87 is that the Wollongong new Commonwealth offices estimated cost is $17m, unexpended balance at 30 June 1986 is $17m, and estimated expenditure in 1986-87 is nil. That is the way the Government announces that it has deferred its $17m new office program for Wollongong. That shows great honesty and integrity, does it not?

There is a great fanfare when it is announced. It goes to water and there is no comment; nothing but a single line in the back pages of a backup document circulated by, of all people, the Hon. Stewart West, Minister for Housing and Construction and the member for Cunningham. He is the member who is supposed to represent Wollongong's best interests. What a brave man! I did not see his Press release announcing this in the Illawarra Mercury today or yesterday. We have a remarkable situation. What is to happen to all those people who are supposed to be moving into this office? If in fact it is not cost-efficient to proceed with building the Wollongong Commonwealth offices, the Government has every right not to proceed. The thing it does not have the right to do is to fudge it, to sneak it through, to pretend it is not happening. I simply wonder whether in fact this building is to proceed. Will the Government in fact say so? Will it tell us when? It might also tell us who is going to occupy the space in it that the Department of Immigration had been to occupy.

We also I guess could wonder what on earth is happening to the Commonwealth Police who have been threatened with departure from their offices in Wollongong. The threat of closure has been hanging over them for about four months or so, despite the fact that Port Kembla is clearly a serious area for drugs and for the possible importation of drugs, apart from the questions of social security fraud, immigration fraud and so on, that the Commonwealth Police have to look after. There is a suggestion that in fact it is not cost-efficient to maintain the Commonwealth Police in Wollongong. Let us see the figures. Let us see how cost-efficient it is. This Government is hot and strong on veneer, but very weak on presenting details.

We have also got, of course, the farce in Wollongong of the office of the Department of Social Security for which the Government has been paying lease rentals for something like two years; but there is still no Social Security public servant in that office even now. They should have moved in a month or so ago but there is a fight going on. After all the renovations that have been done in that place by the Government, there is a fight going on about whether there is some asbestos in the ceiling. Surely that could have been found out while they were doing the renovations. Overall and generally there is a continuing attack on Wollongong. As to the great steel regions program of assistance to the steel industries, I notice in the details of transport expenditure and revenue that assistance to the steel regions is to be cut in half this year. This may well be-and I must say I am not certain of this year; I have not had a chance to check it-in accordance with the original statements; I am unaware of that.
