I had not thought that there was to be such a diminution but it certainly is to be cut in half in respect of roads. Roads assistance for steel regions is going down from $1.85m to $982,000. All this adds up, it seems to me, to sneaky attacks on a region which already has some of the worst unemployment in Australia, and which has been subject to non-stop propaganda from the Government about how it is looking after it when in reality the goodies that have been offered to it have subsequently been taken away.

I make one final point about buildings: There has been interesting continuation of the works program in places such as the Australian Capital Territory, of course, where Commonwealth offices are proceeding with great enthusiasm. For example, modifications to the Cameron Offices are going on. If one looks through the list one will see enormous volumes of expenditure relating to Commonwealth offices within the Australian Capital Territory. I wonder why the Australian Capital Territory is more deserving of expenditure on Commonwealth offices than an area of major unemployment such as the Illawarra region where there surely would be a greater social cost-benefit than exists in continuing to expand the office situation here or even improving some obviously outdated, outmoded and poor quality offices in Canberra.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can tell you about the Cameron Offices.

—It is important when one can afford it to fix up a lot of these Canberra offices and even to expand them, but if there is a choice between doing something in the Illawarra region with a massive unemployment rate and fixing up Canberra offices-no matter what Senator Reid might say about the appalling nature of some of those offices and I take her point about the Cameron Offices in particular-surely the choice would be to do it where one gets the best social return and that social return is in Wollongong, not in the Australian Capital Territory. One of the reasons we have this enormous pressure in the Australian Capital Territory is the incredible increase in the number of public servants and the consequence of that, it can be seen by looking at the Budget Papers, is the increase in rent being paid by this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: When the previous Government lost office rentals took up about $100m a year. Rents for Commonwealth buildings have almost trebled under this Government, to $285m. The property management and services division cost $70m under the previous Government; it has now doubled to $145m. The construction of Commonwealth offices or work on them has gone up 94 per cent this year-this great year of restraint-to $90m but, of course, Wollongong does not have a sufficiently high priority to participate in that.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I was seeking to illustrate that if the burden is to be shared, as it is according to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating), shared throughout Australia, how about getting off Wollongong's back and giving Wollongong a fair go.
Sitting suspended from 1.15 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer the Minister to assurances that he has given that the textile, clothing and footwear plan will continue without alteration until the end of 1988 and that there should not be any dramatic and unduly disruptive reduction in assistance to those industries. I refer also to the Budget decision to cut bounty assistance by 20 per cent across the board, which by any description is a very dramatic reduction in assistance. As the Minister has supported the need for a consistent industry policy and in light of the assurances to which I have referred I ask the Minister: How does he justify the Budget action?

—The Budget action is justified in terms of the Government's macro- economic policies and the need to reduce outlays. The bounty assistance was cut by 20 per cent across a wide range of industries, based on that fact, and that fact alone. In respect of some industries the benefits of the devaluation have been so significant that the question of bounty assistance had to be assessed in that light, but I would not offer that in any sense as a reason for the decision which was made. It was made on the basis of reducing government outlays and expenditure.

—I thank the Minister for that answer but I have a supplementary question. As the decision was not made for industry policy reasons, I ask: Will the Minister examine the impact on particular industries to see the extent to which the change will do any serious damage to the industries concerned? That question is asked in light of the significant employment and growth problems that we have at the moment and in light of the fact that this is a broadbrush revenue saving measure which may impact very negatively on some employment sectors.

—I must say that from an industry policy point of view, as Senator Chaney rightly points out in his question, I have always been concerned about continuity. In some degree this is an interruption of continuity in respect of bounty payments. I am quite happy to undertake an examination of the impact on various sectors. To some extent that has been done already and it is in that light that I--
—You exempted shipbuilding.

—Senator Chaney interjected and said that we exempted shipbuilding. No, we did not. There is a significant reduction, I think, in the shipbuilding bounty overall. There will be a further announcement in relation to the shipbuilding bounty in the not too distant future.

—I refer the Minister for Education to the administrative charge which will be payable by all tertiary students and which was announced in the Budget. Will any students be exempt from this charge? Have arrangements been made for institutions to spread the charge over a full year rather than collect it in a lump sum?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome Senator Elstob's question because there has been a great deal of misunderstanding and misinterpretation about the nature and purpose of the charge and the students who will be affected by it. The charge will not be applied to all tertiary students. Technical and further education students, for example, will not pay the charge. Higher education students, that is, students in universities and colleges, will pay the charge. However, there is a very large list of exemptions from the charge, or persons who will not be affected by it. Any student who is in receipt of a tertiary education assistance scheme payment at any level will be compensated for, and will not be affected by, the change. Aboriginal students and overseas students will not be affected by it. Pensioner students will not be affected by the charge if they are on a supporting mother's pension, widow's pension or carer's allowance.

ANSWER.PARA: It can be seen very clearly that low income, higher education students will not be affected by the charge. So the suggestion which is coming from some organisations and which is being repeated in some parts of the media that the charge of $250 will be an obstacle to low income students represents simply a misunderstanding. Given that all identifiable groups of low income students are to be exempted from the charge, that is simply not true. Those students who will pay the $250 are in a position to do so. However, if students have difficulty paying the charge we have asked institutions to direct them to loans or grants that are available through the special student assistance scheme.

Honourable senators may not be aware that by next year we will have put $11m into a student assistance scheme to which every university and college has access. The students may borrow their $250 from that scheme and repay it on terms negotiated with the student committee that operates that scheme. If institutions which have the responsibility for collecting the charge wish to make the charge payable in two or three lots during the year, we will encourage them to do so. So it is very easy for those of us who are serious about understanding this matter to see that it is a low charge, that it is not to be imposed on low income students and that any students who are liable to pay the charge but who have difficulty paying it will easily be able to get a loan or enter some sort of time payment arrangement to assist them in paying what is, after all, a fair and quite modest contribution to the administrative costs of providing higher education in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which also is directed to the Minister for Education, refers to the Budget decision to reintroduce tertiary education fees. Is this not a direct denial of emphatic pre-election undertakings made by the Labor Government and often paraded by the Minister? The Minister should not tell us that for the first time the Government is trying to sustain a distinction between a charge and a fee or between tuition and the administration of tuition. Will not the proposed higher education administration charge shortchange institutions by allowing only $87m in new revenue collections to cover three factors: Firstly, the $77m in new cuts to direct grants on this account; secondly, the cost to institutions of collection, including defaulting and deferred payments; and, thirdly, the requirement for institutions on this account to lift from 2,000 to 3,000 the additional higher education places to be provided? Finally, in light of the relevant legislation that was introduced this week not providing for a pro rata fee for part time students, how does the Minister justify that the same $250 charge is being inflexibly and inequitably required from full time and part time students alike?
—Before the Minister answers, I draw the attention of honourable senators to the length of their questions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I am grateful for your drawing the attention of honourable senators to that-not only to the length of Senator Teague's question but also to the total confusion in which it was phrased. Senator Teague may not be able to understand what I have just explained, but the fact is that the charge that is being introduced is not a tuition fee. Let me explain to Senator Teague how that is the case. Firstly, Senator Teague may be aware, as he takes some interest in education matters, that the current States Grants (Tertiary Assistance) Act and associated Acts specifically prohibit the charging of tuition fees by universities. That specific prohibition will remain. There will be no removal of it until the unlikely event of a Liberal government which, of course, we know will immediately set about imposing full-cost tuition fees. But in our case there is no removal of that prohibition. As I have just explained in some detail in answer to Senator Elstob's question, the charge is an administration one.

ANSWER.PARA: Further-even Senator Teague could be expected to understand this-if any government were to set about charging tuition fees, it would be charging between $6,000 and $14,000 a year because those are the figures that represent the full cost of university and some college of advanced education places. Any attempt to say that there is no difference between a $250 administration charge and a charge of $6,000 or $8,000 or $12,000 a year for a university or college course is simply failing to face up to reality.

Senator Teague expresses some concern about the effect of this measure on the institutions. Let me make it quite clear that the institutions will collect the charge and will keep all the revenue they collect. Their grants will be adjusted downwards by 90 per cent so that they will be 10 per cent ahead of where they would have been had there been no charge. In other words, the institutions come out about $9.7m ahead. So there is something in this measure for the institutions. There is something in it for all those students who are doing their Higher School Certificate this year and who wish to get one of the scarce places in higher education. At least an extra 3,000 higher education places will be available next year and revenue from the charge will contribute to that. In addition-I want to make this perfectly clear-the Government will net $57m to revenue. That is the contribution which will be made by this advantaged sector of the community to the cost saving expenditure reduction exercise in which we have been involved.

Senator Teague may think it is unfair to ask people who are in the advantaged position of having a higher education place worth $6,000 or $14,000 a year to make such a contribution. We do not think it is unfair. We think it is fair and that is why we have proceeded. But it is a charge. It in no way undermines our position on tuition fees. As Senator Teague would know, institutions themselves have been collecting charges of various kinds from students over the years-union fees, service fees and things of that kind. No one has ever said that they were tuition fees. This charge is in the same sort of category as the fees that institutions have been collecting. The Commonwealth is collecting and disbursing this charge, however, so that we can ensure that it contributes to equity in terms of more places and in terms of a contribution to the cost saving exercise in which this Government has been engaged.

Another verification of my claim that the charge is related to administration and not to tuition is that it is being levied on part time and external students as well as full time students. There is quite a degree of administration involved with part time and external students. The degree of enrolment, course advice and so forth that is involved with a part time student is very often equivalent to, or it could even be greater than, that involved with a full time student. The administration costs of part time and full time students are not significantly different and therefore the charge is the same for all of them. Had the fee been, as Senator Teague suggests, a tuition-related fee there would have been a different charge for different courses, but because the charge is related to the administrative effort of enrolling, supervising and placing students in courses and so on it is clearly an administration charge. It will not be levied on low income students and there will be benefits both to institutions and to those students who will get the extra 3,000 places next year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I have drawn the attention of honourable senators to the length of their questions. I draw the same attention to Ministers' responses to those questions.

—I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer: Has his attention been drawn to statements in the Queensland Press made by Senator Parer in relation to the Moura Widows Fund? Senator Parer claimed that `the Federal Taxation Office had saved the Labor Government embarrassment by making a snap ruling to exempt the Moura Widows Fund from fringe benefits tax'. He further claimed that `Theiss Damper Mitsui would have to pay $115,000 for its relief contributions'. I ask the Minister: Are these statements correct? If not, will the Minister state the true position in relation to advice received from the Australian Taxation Office and the standing of the Moura Widows Fund regarding the fringe benefits tax?

—I have seen a number of such articles. An article headed `Moura Widows Tax Row' appeared in the Brisbane Daily Sun. Another headed `Snap Ruling on Widows Moneys' appeared in the Rockhampton Bulletin, I think it is, another in the Gladstone Observer, and so on. I was very surprised to see them because previously I had regarded Senator Parer as being one of the handful of people in the Liberal Party who had some intellectual integrity and who did not feed false information to the public. In this instance I regret to say that that is precisely what he has done. He has indulged in a cynical exercise of the type in which so many Opposition members have indulged to misinform the public about the fringe benefits tax in a very shady attempt to discredit it. This is one of the worst examples of that sort of activity, I say with some regret. Senator Parer's claim that the Taxation Office had made a snap ruling to exempt the Moura Widows Fund from the fringe benefits tax to save the Government embarrassment is a further indication that he has lost interest in the facts, if not in preserving an element of self-control. Contributions by Theiss Damper Mitsui to the disaster relief fund have never been subject to any fringe benefits tax liability.
—Why not? Tell us why not.

—Because they are not. If this Opposition had any integrity at all it would check things out with the Taxation Office before assorted members of it go public, deliberately feeding misinformation to the public. I am aware of only one comparably bad example which came, I regret, from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. One Peter Couchman asserted on that crummy show the ABC runs, the 7.30 Report, that protective clothing such as boots, goggles and so on provided to workers would be subject to the fringe benefits tax. He was challenged by a former member of my staff after my former staff member checked out the facts and asked where he got the information. Peter Couchman said: `Oh, some bloke in Queensland gave it to me'. He was then asked whether he had checked the information with the Tax Office or with Treasury and he said no. I wondered then why on earth the public should continue to fund completely the public broadcaster which is so bereft of any sort of journalistic ethics or professionalism and which dedicates five minutes of what it regards as one of its flagship programs to spreading disinformation about the fact because it cannot even be bothered checking with the Taxation Office or anybody in authority. So I regret to say that both Senator Parer and the ABC, or at least the people associated with that program, have descended to the level of professionalism which one more commonly associates with the Sydney tabloids.

—I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to Budget Statement No. 2, which states that the 1986-87 Budget estimates have been based on a trade weighted index of 52. On Budget day the trade weighted index was 51.5, so the Budget is based on a slight strengthening of the Australian dollar. Yesterday it closed at 50.5. I ask the Minister whether it is a fact that in his Budget Speech the Treasurer forecast inflation at 8 per cent in 1986-87, which is at least four times higher than that of our major trading partners, and that there will be no improvement and perhaps a further worsening in our current account deficit in 1986-87. In view of this, does the trade weighted index estimate of 52 mean that the Government expects a further massive increase in the already record high level of real interest rates? If not, how does the Government expect the value of the Australian dollar to be maintained and what are the implications for the whole Budget strategy if it is not maintained?
—Order! I ask honourable senators again to consider the length of their questions.

—I guess that if anybody associated with the Budget knew for certain where the exchange rate would be three months, six months or 12 months hence and was interested in making a lot of money he would not be in government or the bureaucracy; he would be out there speculating on the dollar. So there is an element of judgment involved. Senator Short said that the trade weighted index was, I think, 51.5 at the time the Budget was delivered or immediately before and later the figure fell a bit. At one stage yesterday it fell quite considerably in what Albert Smith described in today's Australian Financial Review as the post-lunch claret run. It later recovered somewhat. Obviously, only time will tell whether the Budget assumption is correct but I think it is an assumption that the Government was entitled to make if only for this reason: With one exception nobody, either in the money market or in the financial Press such as it is, had predicted a Budget deficit as low as that which was produced nor, as far as I can recall, had anybody predicted zero real growth in outlays. For both of those reasons, which were clearly more stringent than most people who speculate and comment publicly had anticipated, I think the Government was entitled to make the assumptions that it has built into the Budget.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. In the light of an extraordinary campaign of deceit and misinformation by the Opposition in recent days, can the Minister inform the Senate what the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry into the conduct of Mr Justice Murphy is doing in relation to material passed to it by law enforcement agencies or material which may be of interest to such agencies? Is it the case that informants to the Commission are to be prevented from taking any allegations they wish to make to any law enforcement agency or, if relevant, to the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation if security is alleged to be involved and that accordingly, after the winding up of the Commission, such allegations will remain for ever buried?

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Standing order 99 refers to questions relating to debates in the current session. Although normally you allow a fair degree of latitude with respect to that standing order, at the moment the Senate is in the middle of a debate and it will shortly, no doubt, be getting a lengthy reply from Senator Evans. I suggest to you that it is an abuse of Question Time to be taking up this matter at this stage. I ask that the question be ruled out of order.

—Mr President, on the point of order I simply indicate that the question relates, on its face and in fact substantively, to what is happening to the administration of a current Act of Parliament. It may well be an Act of Parliament which is in the process of being repealed by another Bill before the Parliament but what we are talking about is the powers, the capacity and what is happening under a present Act of Parliament. That is unquestionably within Standing Orders quite apart from any flexibility. I know that honourable senators do not want to hear the truth.

—On the point of order that has been taken by Senator Chaney, I will allow the Minister to respond to the question on the basis that he has put in responding to the point of order. However, before the Minister answers I draw his attention to the fact that the Committee stage of the Bill has yet to take place and he should bear in mind the consequences of what he might say in his answer to the debate that might take place in the Committee stage.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr President. There has been a massive amount of misrepresentation from the Opposition and the Press over the last couple of days about alleged cover-ups of material that may have emerged during the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry. Some of that misrepresentation has manifestly been based on an inability to read the plain terms of existing and proposed legislation. Some of it is clearly based on an unwillingness to listen to what the Attorney-General said in the Parliament yesterday on this very question. I suspect most of it has to do with pure malice of the kind that we have seen so often during the whole conduct of this affair. I am not surprised that Senator Chaney should want to stop my speaking on the question.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Minister representing the Attorney-General has really made it clear in his answer that he is anticipating discussion on an order of the day which we are in the middle of dealing with. He referred to the debate in the other place yesterday on that very Bill. The issues which were raised in this question by the honourable senator from New South Wales were the subject of debate and indeed interjection from Senator Evans just prior to the suspension of the sitting for lunch. I think this is clearly a situation in which the Minister is anticipating discussion and he should be ruled out of order and asked to desist.

—Order! I draw attention to the earlier ruling I gave on the matter that the Minister is entitled to refer to the administration of the Parliamentary Commission but he should not relate his remarks directly or indirectly to the Bill presently before the Parliament. If he does that I will have to rule him out of order. Having said that, I ask the Minister to respond to Senator Richardson.

—The first part of the question was: What is the Commission doing about material that may have been supplied to it by law enforcement agencies or material which may be of interest to such agencies? The short answer is this: I am advised that the Commission is currently in the process of returning materials made available to it by law enforcement agencies. It is under a positive obligation to do so if requested by virtue of the terms of section 18 (2) of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry Act.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Minister is not correctly quoting the section of the Act and the limitations on it and that is what I was protesting about.
—Order! There is no point of order.
—I am very happy to quote the terms of the--
—I ask the Minister representing the Attorney-General to respond to Senator Richardson's question concerning the administration of the Commission.

—The honourable senator can read the terms of the legislation for himself; I will not waste further time in doing that but the answer to Senator Durack's interjection is self-evident. Copies of such material that is given back to agencies in this way can be used.
—When? When is it supposed to be given back?
—Order, Senator Chaney! There are far too many interjections.

—Mr President, I will respond to that interjection but it is difficult to do so without adverting to another matter. I will simply say this: It is not the intention of the Executive Government to arrange for assent to be given to any piece of legislation that might conceivably be debated by this Parliament in the next few hours until the middle of next week. We are advised that that time frame will be entirely sufficient for the Commission to complete its dealing with the documents in question as it thinks appropriate in the way I have mentioned. To complete the sentence I was in the middle of before I was rudely interrupted, if copies of such material returned to such agencies can be used by them in any way they deem appropriate, nothing in any piece of legislation that might conceivably be dealt with by the Parliament in some imminent future, will bear upon that question.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. This answer is clearly debating--
—You do not want to know the truth, do you? You just want to wallow in your own stinking prejudice.
—Order! The House will come to order. I am trying to hear a point of order taken by Senator Durack and he is entitled to be heard.

—The Minister is clearly debating the meaning of certain provisions of a Bill the Committee stage of which we will be debating this afternoon. Furthermore the Minister's views on it, even though he believes that everything he thinks is absolutely correct about everything, are challengeable and are challenged by many people. So clearly what this Bill means is a matter for debate in this Parliament later in the day.
—Order! At the moment the Minister is walking a fine tightrope. He has not fallen off it yet but I remind him to relate his remarks to the question of administration of the Parliamentary Commission.

—With pleasure, Mr President. As regards the second category of material which has attracted attention, that is, material which may have been received by the Commission other than from law enforcement agencies-that is individuals, organisations and no doubt newspapers-but which may contain material which is or may be of interest to law reform agencies, what is the Commission doing about that? It is doing this: Section 34 of the existing Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry Act authorises the Commission, if it thinks it appropriate to do so, to communicate information or evidence it has which relates, or may relate, to the commission of an offence to any one of a number of specified law enforcement agencies, including State or Commonwealth Attorneys-General, police forces and the National Crime Authority.

ANSWER.PARA: Section 34 therefore allows the Commission to pass information concerning offences by third parties to such law reform agencies. It is my understanding that the Commission is in the course of providing information of that character, at least to the National Crime Authority, pursuant to section 34. I am not sure of the position with any other law enforcement agencies. As I said in response to an interjection, the Commission will have ample opportunity to conclude dealing with such material in the way it wants by the middle of next week, before assent is given. As to the second question, is it the case that informants to the Commission are to be prevented from taking allegations to a law enforcement agency of some kind or to the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation if it is thought to bear on national security, as someone suggested on another occasion? Are informants of that kind to be prohibited, irrespective of what the Commission chooses to do? The short answer is no. To explain that, I would need to trespass on Standing Orders. I shall not, accordingly, bear upon your patience, Mr President.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is the Government aware of an apparent desire by the United States Government to rewrite its anti-ballistic missile treaty with the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics in ways that would gravely reduce its effectiveness? Is it the Government's understanding that the motive for this rewriting is to expedite the United States strategic defence initiative, or Star Wars, program? What is the Government's view of the ABM treaty's importance? Will the Government exert any influence it has to retain, refine and improve that treaty?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As far as the Government is aware, the United States has no current interest in rewriting the ABM treaty. We are aware that, in October 1985, President Reagan accepted as valid a legal interpretation of the ABM treaty to the effect that, for ballistic missile defence systems based on new physical principles, the treaty precluded only deployment-not research, development and testing. At the same time, President Reagan said that the United States would continue to conduct the SDI research program in accordance with a restrictive interpretation of its obligations under the ABM treaty. I think that Senator Mason was referring to that.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government attaches importance to President Reagan's undertaking to observe a restrictive or traditional interpretation of the ABM treaty. The Government attaches major importance to full and demonstrable compliance with all existing arms control agreements. The ABM treaty has special significance in that it lies at the heart of the prevailing deterrent relationship between the two super-powers. In the Government's view, the integrity of the ABM treaty is of decisive importance to the vital task of concluding new agreements for radical reductions in the nuclear arsenals-an objective to which President Reagan and Secretary-General Gorbachev are committed. The Government has forcefully articulated that view at every available opportunity, including its bilateral consultations with the United States and the Soviet Union, the two parties to the treaty.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. May I take it that the Government does not accept the United States interpretation of the treaty as expressed by President Reagan on that occasion?

—Senator Mason might have misunderstood my first paragraph. I said that, in October 1985, President Reagan accepted as valid an interpretation that was quite limited in its view of what the ABM treaty would preclude. At the same time as he accepted that interpretation, he said that the United States would continue to conduct its research program for SDI in accordance with a restrictive interpretation of its obligations under the ABM treaty.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery of a former distinguished senator from New South Wales, Sir Robert Cotton. On behalf of all honourable senators, I extend to Sir Robert a warm and friendly welcome on his return to Canberra.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Is it a fact that the Prime Minister has said that Australia is facing the greatest crisis since World War II? Has not the Treasurer pointed out that the immediate cause of this economic crisis is the collapse of our overseas trade? If the collapse of our overseas trade can so imperil our economy, could not an enemy which can interrupt and destroy our trade at sea bring enormous pressure to bear on our country without having to contemplate invading it? What has the Government done to address this question, which is so vital to Australia's future?
—I call the Minister representing the Minister for Defence.
—It is an important question which I think should be taken on notice.
—May I raise the question again, because the Minister did not hear it? Is it a fact that the Prime Minister--
—Order! The Minister asked that the question be placed on notice.
—Mr President, that is an insult to the chamber.
—I shall answer the question.
—Order! The Minister now withdraws his request. I ask Senator Harradine to repeat his question.

—It would be questions without answers in those circumstances. Is it a fact that the Prime Minister has described the crisis facing Australia as the greatest since World War II? Has not the Treasurer pointed out that the immediate cause of this economic crisis is the collapse of our overseas trade? If the collapse of our overseas trade can so imperil our economy, could not an enemy which can interrupt and destroy that trade at sea bring enormous pressure to bear on our country without having to contemplate invading it? What has the Government done to address this question, which is so vital to Australia's future.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —After that preamble, I could be forgiven for switching off, Mr President. The short answer is that the Government commissioned the Dibb report. It has received that report, which squarely addresses itself to that issue among a number of related issues related to ensuring our domestic security. The Government has now embarked on preparing a White Paper, which will be a public statement of Government policy on these matters. Of course, one argument which must be addressed and which is central to the whole defence debate is about the protection of sea lanes and trade lanes and the type of defence structure and set of relationships which are necessary to achieve that. That depends on two sides of the equation-assessment of the threats and assessment of the type of resources needed to cope with a variety of threats.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Harradine will be well aware that the basic thrust of the Dibb report is to discount as the type of problem about which Australia need worry, or would ever be able to do anything about even if it did worry, the protection of sea lanes by a far-flung force of the kind about which the honourable senator, Santamaria and the rest of the boys are so keen. There will be ample opportunity for much debate on this issue, which is manifestly of extreme national importance. The debate has been conducted at a higher level of intellectual rigour than any similar debate under previous Administrations. The Government will bring all the intellectual rigour which it has in ample abundance to bear in resolving the issue, no doubt never to Senator Harradine's satisfaction but, I believe, to the satisfaction of the Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a supplementary question, Mr President. My question was not about what Dibb had said about this matter-he devoted, inadequately, only one of the 179 pages of his report to this matter-but about what the Government has done about a crisis which could arise and which has been described by the Prime Minister as the greatest since World War II.
—I have nothing further to add to my reply.

—Does the Minister for Finance have any reason to doubt the statement made on Budget night by Mr Julian Disney, the President of the Australian Council of Social Service, that almost all pensioners and beneficiaries are going to suffer at least a 1 per cent or 2 per cent loss of income, which will range from a few dollars up to $30 a week? If that is the case, what set of social priorities has guided the Government in determining that that group of Australians-pensioners and beneficiaries-should be targeted in this way in the Budget?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure that I heard all of that question correctly but, if I did, Senator Peter Baume said that Julian Disney, or somebody, had said that some pensioners would lose up to $30 a week. As a question of fact, that is not so. The implication of Senator Peter Baume's question is that in its Budget the Government should have increased the amount of money that will be paid, certainly to pensioners, if not to social security recipients more generally. I find it very difficult to reconcile that pious belief with the things that the Leader of the Opposition is talking about, saying that there should be further reductions in government expenditure. He has failed to identify any of the specific existing areas of expenditure where outlays ought to be reduced, but runs around the country promising to increase them by a full $2 billion in satisfying the ragbag collection of client groups that the Liberal and National parties between them have collected.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the question, it is an inescapable fact that because of the adverse movement-the falls in the prices of the things that Australia sells overseas-which has taken place, there is no alternative to a reduction in average living standards or the accumulation of foreign debt at a higher rate, or some mixture of those two. The Government has decided that average living standards must be reduced for the short term while the economic restructuring takes place that will enable Australians to get back on the path of rising per capita incomes.

It is correct, of course, that the increases in pension payments will be delayed for three payment periods, in both November and May. Mr Disney can call that a de facto discount if he wants to, I suppose, but it is not formally a discount because it does not affect the rate, only the timing. Wage earners have already taken a significant discount in wages and, as the Treasurer's statement made very clear, Government policy is that there should be a further decline in real wages at the January wage case and possibly at the one thereafter. Indeed, if one compares the decline in real wages which wage earners have already accepted with those that the Government believes should be accepted in the future, one finds that a far heavier burden has been borne by some wage earners than by pensioners. I am sorry that I do not have the precise figures with me, but if the further wage reductions that the Government is seeking take place on 1 January the standard pension payment, as a proportion of average weekly earnings, will increase by something like a full one per cent between the middle of 1985 and the beginning of 1987. I do not have that precise figure, but I will try to get it in time for Question Time tomorrow and make it available.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Education, who would be aware of my concern about the Bicentenary, which is to be celebrated in this country in a couple of years time. I ask: Can the Minister advise whether the cuts announced to the programs for the Australian Bicentennial Authority will mean the termination of the successful program on Australian studies at the tertiary level?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate Senator Coleman's concern that programs of importance and lasting value to the Australian people will be able to proceed in the bicentennial year and I am happy to assure her that the tertiary Australian studies project has not been cut. In fact, the Chairman of the Bicentennial Authority and I have agreed today that there will be an additional $1m for new work in the Australian studies area. That is a very important area because, for the first time, there has been a thorough review of all aspects of tertiary education. The Australian studies project is the first comprehensive review of the extent to which our Australian tertiary education institutions have taken into account Australian scholarship, Australian invention, Australian trade training and the general contribution made by Australians during the 200 years in areas such as law, engineering, trades, environment studies and so on. Of course, there have been many outstanding contributions over the 200 years to all major areas of learning, and I think it is the case that, up till now, that enormous contribution by Australians has not been recognised.

ANSWER.PARA: As a result of the Australian studies project, all such major contributions will be recognised and documented. As a result of the outstanding work of the Australian studies committee we expect that all Australian tertiary education institutions will be better able to incorporate into curriculum research and teaching approaches the experience and achievements of 200 years of Australian scholarship research and learning.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Defence aware of media coverage concerning the alleged $400m order through Hong Kong for the manufacture and supply of a military rifle and a sporting rifle from a firm called Armtech? Has the Minister noted that, coincidentally, since this publicity the market price of the shares in that company has risen substantially? Can the Minister say whether the Defence Force has evaluated this rifle? If it has, what were the conclusions of the Defence Force trials? In particular, how does the military version of the Armtech rifle compare with the Steyr weapons family which the Army has selected to replace the existing Service rifle?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the specific questions about the evaluation of the rifle by the Defence Force, the answer provided to me is as follows: No, the Department of Defence has not evaluated the Armtech ART30 rifle as it has had no opportunity to do so. It is understood that there is still only one prototype of the weapon in existence. The Defence Force would require as a minimum 12 rifles selected at random from a production run to undertake a full evaluation. At the time of the Defence trials that resulted in the selection of the Steyr, no production-run rifles had been produced.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the last question as to how the military version of the Armtech rifle compares with the Steyr weapons family which the Army has selected to replace the existing service rifle, the Department says that it has not been provided with information on the specifications or performance of any of the Armtech rifles and is unable, accordingly, to make a judgment.

There is a bit more to this story in terms of what has been going on in the stock exchange, share values and re-evaluation of assets and so on which might add a little more to the explanation of the course of events than the purely technical information that I have given about the evaluation of the rifle. I am happy to provide to Senator Jessop such information as I possess in this respect.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a front-page article in this morning's Courier-Mail pointing out the double-dip provisions under Queensland's parliamentary superannuation scheme? Can the Minister confirm that apparently specific provisions exist in that scheme which discriminate in favour of certain National Party Government Cabinet Ministers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Courier-Mail headline says `MPs, public servants get ``super'' boost' and `Minister will get $550,000', among other things. It is a report of an extensive review of superannuation arrangements for Queensland public servants, I think statutory authority employees, and also members of parliament. The major point made in the report, so far as it applies to members of parliament, is that a Mr Wharton, who is the Minister for Works and Housing and who is due to retire when the present parliamentary term in Queensland expires, will pick up $550,000 as a lump sum. The report goes on to say that under the double-dip provisions in the scheme, should Mr Wharton predecease his wife, she would be entitled to an additional $30,000 a year, indexed to the consumer price index. In other words, the pension entitlement Mr Wharton has will be fully commuted to a lump sum, which, particularly for somebody who accrued it over the period he did, is virtually tax free as well. Then if he croaks, his spouse will pick up a pension related to the pension to which he was entitled but which he had already commuted to a lump sum. In other words, it is a clear double-dipping provision.

ANSWER.PARA: Similar provisions were introduced into the Commonwealth parliamentary pension scheme by the Fraser-Howard combination in, I think, 1979 or 1980. Those provisions were amended by the present Government in 1983 in two ways: Firstly, no more than 50 per cent of the pension entitlement may be commuted into a lump sum; secondly, should the spouse of a retired parliamentarian outlive the pensioner, five-eighths of whatever pension is actually being received will be paid to that spouse. There is, of course, absolutely no double-dipping in that.

Given that the Queensland Government is making major amendments to superannuation arrangements in general, I find it almost unbelievable that even the red-necked National Party Government of Queensland should continue to pick its taxpayers' pockets for the benefit of National Party Ministers to the extent that it does. In a period when the tory parties, if one could call them that generally, are calling for restraint on wages, pensions and that sort of thing, although clearly the National Party Ministers of the Queensland Government have no inner moral compulsion to do this, I hope that sufficient pressure will be brought on them by public opinion in Queensland to follow the example the Federal Government set in 1983 under much less stringent economic circumstances and eliminate the double-dipping provisions in the Queensland parliamentary pension scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. In response to a question from Senator Jones the Minister said that ex gratia payments were not subject to fringe benefits tax. The reason he gave, if I heard him correctly, was because they are not. Does the Minister mean that any company which makes an ex gratia payment to an employee or an associate is not liable for fringe benefits tax, nor is the benefit taxed in the hands of the beneficiary? Will the Minister point to that part of the Act which provides that exemption? Would it not have been more honest to state that an eventuality such as the Moura Widows Fund was not envisaged when framing the Act and that in cases such as this an exemption would be made to the company contribution?

—I did not say anything about ex gratia payments in that answer, as I remember it. What I did say was that the donation to the Moura Widows Fund by the company would not be subject to fringe benefits tax. I suggest that before Senator Parer goes public next time in a way that misinforms the people, he should contact the Commissioner of Taxation or somebody else in a position of authority and establish the facts. One obvious reason why that donation to the Widows Fund was not subject to fringe benefits tax-I will see whether the Treasurer or the Commissioner of Taxation has anything to add to this-was that it was paid in cash. Fringe benefits, by definition, are not paid in cash.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy, relates to his Press statement of 19 August on the resumption of uranium sales to France. The Minister stated:

QUESTION.PARA: Australian uranium has not been used in the past, and will not be used in the future, in French nuclear weapons.

Will he explain to the Senate exactly what happens to Australia's uranium when it reaches France, and in particular how it is separated through the whole nuclear fuel cycle from uranium imported from Canada, Niger, Gabon, Namibia and other supply countries with few, if any, safeguards, so as to ensure, in his words, `that there is no possibility that Australian uranium can be used in the French nuclear weapons program'? Will he also tell the Senate which uranium France uses for nuclear weapons and which it does not, how the uranium imports are separated on arrival, and how many uranium enrichment plants France has where it can separate the uranium for nuclear weapons from that for peaceful purposes? Will he finally explain how the French Government separates all the uranium it imports to comply with different safeguards conditions imposed by different suppliers, ranging from Niger, with no safeguards, to Australia, which allegedly has the strictest safeguards in the world?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As usual, Senator Vallentine's questions are so many and so detailed that it is impossible, as well as being inappropriate, to answer them all here. I am happy to provide full written answers to her. I simply say this: Our uranium is supplied to France and dealt with by France in exactly the same way in practice as it is to other countries with which we have safeguards agreements, or which other countries are parties to multilateral safeguards agreements, and in the case of France there is both. The safeguards are extremely stringent in terms of the conditions that Australia imposes as to the non-use of Australian material for other than strictly peaceful purposes. The application of those safeguards is ensured not only by our reliance on the good faith of the French electricity utilities and the French Government in that respect but also, of course, by the system of inspections which exists internationally to enforce safeguards regimes.

ANSWER.PARA: In terms of the more detailed questions about how we ensure that Australian molecules do not get jostled up with molecules from Gabon and Niger as continuous flow processes operate, I simply draw Senator Vallentine's attention to the principle of equivalence, which I have had occasion to draw to the attention of the Australian Democrats on numerous previous occasions-it seems to require a lot of explanation. We cannot always be sure that any particular atom can be followed all the way through the machinery--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right. That is the whole point of the question.

—Of course we cannot. I have made that perfectly clear and there is no hint of dissimulation about it. What we can ensure, and ensure with very great precision through the nuclear accounting systems to which we are party, is that no amount of Australian uranium that goes into the system will be dealt with otherwise than in accordance with Australian safeguards regimes.

—I ask a supplementary question. Am I to take it from the Minister's answer that he is not able to provide the proof that is required by the Australian community at the moment, which is in dismay over the resumption of Australian uranium sales to France, that Australian uranium will not end up in nuclear weapons to be tested in the South Pacific? I think his statement that we rely on the good faith of the French Government leaves a lot to be desired. It is the same French Government which imposed state terrorism in the South Pacific.
—Order! The honourable senator is out of order. That portion of the question relating to a supplementary question may be answered by the Minister for Resources and Energy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the problems with the anti-nuclear movement is that it demonstrates a triumph of heart over head, of emotion over reason, of extravagant response over rational appreciation.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I have got enough to put up with this week without having that sort of yowling, mewling and puling going on over there in the corner.
—Order! I ask the Minister to respond to Senator Vallentine or I will ask him to resume his seat. There are still people who wish to ask questions.

—The short response, shorn of all my emotion, is that we can be sure that no amount of Australian uranium put into the French system is dealt with by that system otherwise than for peaceful purposes. We are not relying on good faith alone; we are relying on a system that is highly sophisticated and highly developed. I would be delighted to give Senator Vallentine a long and comprehensive answer. I just wish that in the future when I give her such answers she would use them.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Given the benefit of hindsight could the Minister now confirm his answer to a recent question on the fringe benefits tax that cash payments are not subject to fringe benefits tax even though they are paid to or on behalf of an employee or a former employee or associates?

—I do not know what the honourable senator is talking about. If he is talking about the answer I gave to Senator Parer, I said that this was a donation. One of the things which distinguished it from a fringe benefit was that it was paid in cash and fringe benefits are not paid in cash.

—I ask a supplementary question. Does that mean that companies can now make donations in cash to or on behalf of employees for certain specified benefits and no longer attract the fringe benefits tax? I thought that that cut across the whole purpose of the legislation.

—Of course, that is not so because that would be something paid to an employee because of the relationship which exists between the employer and the employee-that is, that the person is, by definition, an employee. I am looking at a note that has been supplied by the Treasurer's office. It says that employer donations to such relief funds are not subject to the fringe benefits tax. I am not surprised that the minds of those in the Liberal Party are very well tuned to trying to devise ways to cheat the tax system-half the members of the finance committee in Western Australia were up to their ears in bottom of the harbour tax evasion schemes-
—Order! The Minister is clearly debating the matter. I ask him to get back to the supplementary answer.

—Certainly, Mr President. It does not surprise me that members of the Liberal Party are putting their brains into overdrive-whatever brains they have-in an attempt to devise ways to cheat the tax system on the fringe benefits tax in the way that they have become accustomed to cheating the tax system in every way they could think of for the last 10 or 20 years.
