TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a ministerial statement on the London meeting on South Africa and to incorporate the statement and the meeting communique in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

I wish to report on the Prime Minister's involvement in the meeting in London from 3 to 5 August of Heads of Government of seven Commonwealth countries on the issue of South Africa. I seek leave to table the communique of the meeting.
The meeting brought together the Heads of Government of Australia, the Bahamas, Britain, Canada, India, Zambia and Zimbabwe. It was a crucial meeting from three points of view.

First, it came against the background of a rapidly deteriorating situation in South Africa. That country has been experiencing the most wide-spread and destructive unrest in its post-war history. In the past two years more than 2,200 people have lost their lives, many in clashes with the security forces. Thousands have been injured. Since the Government declared a new State of Emergency in June at least 8,551 people have been detained on a long term basis, according to the Government's own figures. These include leaders of political parties, trade unions, student groups, human rights organisations, churches and many others opposed to apartheid. The meeting in London was therefore required to formulate a firm response to the deepening tragedy.

Second, the meeting came at a time of heightened tensions within the Commonwealth, tensions potentially capable of fracturing this longstanding organisation. The boycott of the Commonwealth Games and threats to leave the Commonwealth were symptoms of deep concern and frustration. The London meeting therefore had an important role in preserving the credibility and integrity of the Commonwealth. Southern African issues have been a dominant theme in the Commonwealth over the years and we should not forget that South Africa was a founding member of the Commonwealth and that its departure was decided by the white minority government.

Third, the meeting was timely in terms of consideration of South Africa underway in other major countries. In June the leaders of the European Community agreed to consider measures against South Africa in three months time if South Africa failed to take certain political steps. In London the meeting was therefore conscious of the important decisions the European Community would be taking in September. It was also conscious of the development in the United States Congress of new measures against South Africa. The London meeting provided the opportunity to give an important international lead.

This was no ad hoc gathering, hastily convened as some knee jerk response to the appalling situation in South Africa. It was a step in a process already delineated with great care by all Commonwealth Heads of Government. The Commonwealth Accord on Southern Africa agreed at Nassau in 1985 embodied a clear strategy. This involved the Australian initiative to establish a Group of Eminent Persons (EPG) to try to achieve negotiation and peaceful change. It involved the definition of clear benchmarks against which to judge the South African Government's willingness or otherwise to initiate change. It involved a graduated approach to measures against South Africa comprising a first tranche of measures to be taken immediately, consideration of a second tranche six months after Nassau if adequate progress had not been made, and possible further measures should the first and second tranches fail to produce results in a reasonable period. It involved the pursuit of this program jointly.

What was addressed, then, was not a strategy which gave the South African Government no chance to change. It was not a strategy of lashing out at South Africa in a fit of pique. It was a strategy which very deliberately gave South Africa time to show that it was prepared to move towards a non-racial and representative government; which would take advantage of the opportunity offered by the EPG to facilitate negotiations with black South African leaders; and which made the adoption of sanctions totally contingent on the decisions of the South African Government itself.

The Nassau Accord established the mandate for the meeting in London. The first part of our mandate was to review the situation in South Africa and provide an opinion whether adequate progress had been made towards the objectives stated in the Accord. The meeting conducted this review in London at length and in detail. It had the benefit not only of the report of the EPG but of first hand accounts by the two Co-chairmen of the Group-Mr Malcolm Fraser of Australia and General Obasanjo of Nigeria-and by the British Foreign Secretary, Sir Geoffrey Howe, who had undertaken a mission to South Africa on behalf of the European Community.

The report of the EPG was crucial to the review. The Prime Minister emphasised that the group performed a very difficult task with great determination and integrity. The role played by Mr Fraser reflects great credit upon him. All members have access to the report and it is suggested that no objective reader could find it other than a powerful and compelling account of the daily agony of apartheid for the majority of South Africans.

The EPG put forward a creative negotiating concept but this was rejected by the South African Government. The response revealed an unwillingness on the part of the Government to make fundamental changes and to negotiate the creation of a genuinely democratic system. The Government remained wedded to the concept of political rights being granted on a group rather than an individual basis, which implies that race classification will remain in place, and to the retention of the so called independent homelands. The Government has flatly ruled out a political system based on one-person one-vote in a unitary state. The EPG was left no alternative but to conclude, and I quote, ``the Government of South Africa at the end made it impossible for us to proceed any further''. This was their unanimous view.

It was striking at the London meeting that the impressions conveyed by Sir Geoffrey Howe coincided in essential respects with those of the two Co-chairmen of the EPG. Moreover, in terms of the benchmarks specified in the Commonwealth Accord, the facts spoke for themselves. Not one of the benchmarks had been reached by the South African Government. Specific and meaningful action has not been taken to dismantle apartheid. A new State of Emergency has been introduced. Nelson Mandela and other detainees are still in gaol. Political freedom does not exist and the bans on the African National Congress and other political parties have not been lifted. No process of dialogue for non-racial and representative government is underway.

Worse than this, spiralling violence and repression in South Africa, and military attacks by South Africa on Harare, Lusaka and Gaborone in May, demonstrated to those in London that the situation in South Africa had gone backwards. As the communique attests this was the unanimous judgement of the seven Heads of Government.

The second part of the mandate under the Nassau Accord, was to consider further measures against South Africa. Here there was a division of opinion between Britain and the other six participants. Perfectly properly, the meeting did not seek to camouflage or disguise this in the communique.

Australia, the Bahamas, Canada, India, Zambia and Zimbabwe adopted a range of further measures, including those defined in the second tranche of the Nassau Accord. Britain was unwilling to take all the steps and the six regarded this, in the language of the communique, with both concern and regret. That having been said, the three undertakings the British Prime Minister gave were, of course, welcome as far as they went and will help the prospects of action by the European Community as a whole.

As the Prime Minister said to his colleagues in London, he wanted if possible a united but above all credible and effective approach. Better that those ready to act should do so rather than settle for some transparently ineffectual compromise. The willingness of the six to adopt strong measures was because the Commonwealth and its international leadership role on southern African issues have been preserved.
Below are the measures which Australia has accepted and which are listed in the communique. These measures will be brought into effect as soon as possible.

(A) A ban on air links with South Africa. For Australia this principally involves terminating South African Airways services. The Government is now giving further consideration to the means of implementing this measure taking into account the provisions of the Australia-South Africa Air Services Agreement.

(B) A ban on new investment or reinvestment of profits earned in South Africa. The reference to reinvestment concerns reinvestment of repat- riated profits, given the problems of applying extraterritorially a ban on reinvestment of profits which remain in South Africa. The Government has decided that in the first instance this measure will be effected through a call on Australian investors to refrain from such investment.

(C) A ban on the import of agricultural products from South Africa. The Government has decided that provision will be made for prospective implementation of this measure 180 days after the necessary customs negotiations have been promulgated. This will obviate problems for importers who have existing commitments. The Government will shortly be considering certain definitional matters related to this measure.
(D) The termination of double taxation agreements with South Africa. Australia has no such agreement with South Africa.

(E) The termination of all Government assistance to investment in, and trade with, South Africa. The Government has already taken substantial action in this area. It has now decided to terminate all remaining Commonwealth Government assistance through the Export Market Development Grants Scheme, the Export Finance Insurance Group and the Overseas Projects Unit of Austrade to Australian firms dealing with South Africa. This will be done consistent with legislative requirements and the honouring of insurance contracts entered into prior to the date of implementation.
(F) A ban on all Government procurement in South Africa. Australia has already introduced this measure save for the procurement necessary to maintain our diplomatic missions.
(G) A ban on Government contracts with majority-owned South African companies. This measure has also already been introduced.

(H) A ban on the promotion of tourism to South Africa. The Government will terminate the temporary residence authority of South Africa based officials of the South African Tourist Commission in Sydney. The Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism will be bringing forward proposals concerning other means of implementing this ban.

These eight measures comprise the second tranche identified in the Nassau Accord. The following three additional measures decided upon in London take into account the movement which has occurred on sanctions in both the United States and the European Community since Nassau.
(i) A ban on all new bank loans to South Africa, whether to the public or private sectors. The Government has already called on banks to refrain from such loans.

(j) A ban on the import of uranium, coal, iron and steel from South Africa. Again this will be introduced prospectively 180 days after the introduction of regulations. The Government will shortly be considering certain definitional matters related to this measure.

(k) The withdrawal of all consular facilities in South Africa except for our own nationals and nationals of those countries to whom we render consular services. This relates principally to visa issuing in South Africa. The Government is considering how broadly the withdrawal of visa issuing facilities should be applied and this matter will be the subject of a separate announcement.

The Government has decided to reduce South African representation in Australia through withdrawal of temporary residence authority for South African Trade Officers at the South African Trade Commissioner's office in Melbourne and for the Commercial Vice-Consul in Sydney. Australia withdrew its Trade Commissioner from South Africa in 1985.

In addition there is the provision in the budget for a new $5 million assistance program for Southern Africa over a five year period. This will, in particular, provide humanitarian assistance for black South Africans, Namibians and black South African refugees in the areas of education and training.
It is the purpose today to report on the London meeting rather than engage in broad debate on the issue of sanctions. But there are several points which are absolutely central.

First, it is a characteristic of the debate about sanctions that those opposed to them prefer to set up straw men rather than address the real rationale for such measures. One such straw man is that negotiation and dialogue are to be preferred to sanctions. In fact it is a fundamental fallacy to see negotiation and dialogue on the one hand and sanctions on the other as somehow contradictory. The purpose of sanctions is precisely to bring home to the South African Government that its present posture, a repressive defence of the status quo, entails costs and that a change of course would bring benefits. The London communique is explicit that if Pretoria responds positively we all stand ready to review the situation and to rescind the measures which have been adopted.

Those who oppose the sanctions do so frequently on the purported grounds that they will hurt the black community. The Government rejects this as patronising and offensive to those representative black leaders such as Bishop Tutu, leaders of the African National Congress and the United Democratic Front, leaders of the Front Line States, and black trade union leaders such as those met in London by the Prime Minister, who have made it clear that the black community of South Africa is already suffering immeasurably under apartheid and believes the price of sanctions is one it is prepared to pay.

Another straw man is that sanctions are ineffective because they will not destroy the South African economy or bring down the South African Government. Neither of these things is the real rationale for sanctions and people who argue this way are either too obtuse or lacking the intellectual honesty to address the much more complex calculations involved. The object, as Mr Hayden has eloquently said, is not to bring South Africa to its knees but to bring it to its senses. The object is not to bring down a government but to change the political dynamics of South Africa in a more progressive direction. The key point is that history shows that to the extent South Africa has changed it has done so in response to a changing internal dynamic which has drawn support and encouragement from external pressure. History also shows that in the absence of such pressures South Africa will prevaricate and delay indefinitely. Since inaction means delay and delay means a downwards spiral into violence those opposed to action bear a grave responsibility.

Third, concrete measures are the only way to fulfil our moral obligation as liberal democracies serious about the values of individual liberty and democratic rights. Apartheid is universally deplored but repugnance alone is not sufficient for its elimination. Vocal opposition without tangible measures is hollow.

Fourth, and very importantly, the self-interest of the West requires action. Make no mistake, change will come about one day in South Africa and it is a question of vital importance how it comes. The political, economic and strategic interests of the West will be dealt a tremendous blow if the process is a violent one which throws up a radical successor regime which regards the West as hostile. The purpose of sanctions is to bring home to the South African Government and its domestic constituency the need for peaceful change, and to send a signal to those moderate black leaders striving for change by non-violent means that they are not alone.

In fact the cost of adopting measures now-whether to Australia, Britain, Canada, the United States, the European Community or Japan-will be nothing compared to the cost if South Africa plunges into conflict. It is for this reason, and also because a great moral issue is involved, that Western countries cannot afford to take decisions about sanctions on the basis of some narrow short-term calculation in dollars and cents. The Prime Minister did not do so in associating Australia with the measures agreed at London.

Nor does the Government shirk from, or apologise for, the fact that the measures could be at some cost to Australia. This depends upon many imponderables, including the extent to which the measures are adopted by other countries, including particularly South Africa's major economic partners. No definitive tally can be given. Certainly there is a potential cost given that our policy deliberately constrains us from developing lucrative commercial relations with the largest economy on the African continent. Any costs would be harder to bear should others stand by and perhaps benefit from the principled stand now being taken by an ever-growing section of the world's community. The point, as stated in the communique, is that such measures have become a moral and political imperative which can no longer be deferred.

The London decisions do not constitute only a recommendation to the Commonwealth as a whole. They usher in a period of intensive consultations within the international community with emphasis on those countries that presently sustain a significant level of economic relations with South Africa.

The Prime Minister has sent messages to the Heads of Government of the European Community countries conveying the Government's views and urging that action be taken. He has written in the same terms to President Reagan and to Prime Minister Nakasone. The visit to Australia next week of the Chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee of the United States Senate, Richard Lugar, will provide a further valuable opportunity to follow up the London decisions.

The Western world is beginning to move on this vital international issue. On 15 August the United States Senate voted 84 to 14 in favour of strong measures, further evidence that there is solid bipartisan support for action in the United States. As noted earlier, the European Community will consider measures in September and movement by Britain at the London meeting should facilitate agreement. The indications are that Japan would be prepared to be part of a position concerted with other major Western powers.

The Government, in taking the decisions it has, has therefore aligned Australia with the emerging international consensus. But we have done more. We have played a major part in helping to shape that consensus. This is a role of which Australians can be proud.
COMMONWEALTH HEADS OF GOVERNMENT REVIEW MEETING
LONDON, 3-5 AUGUST 1986
COMMUNIQUE

As agreed at Nassau last October, our Meeting was held in the special context of the crisis in Southern Africa. At the outset of our discussions we specifically reaffirmed our commitment to the Commonwealth Accord on Southern Africa which, with our other colleagues, we had concluded at Nassau. We reaffirmed, in particular, the united belief we expressed in the Accord that ``apartheid must be dismantled now if a greater tragedy is to be averted, and that concerted pressure must be brought to bear to achieve that end''.

2. At our request the Co-Chairmen of the Commonwealth Group of Eminent Persons (EPG), General Olusegun Obasanjo and Mr Malcolm Fraser, introduced the Report of the EPG and answered the many questions we put to them. Sir Geoffrey Howe, the British Foreign Secretary, who undertook a mission to Southern Africa in his capacity as President of the Council of Ministers of the EEC, also briefed us on the results of his mission.

3. The Report of the EPG, Mission to South Africa, was the central document at our discussions. That unanimous Report has commanded attention worldwide as pointing the way forward for South Africa and for the world in relation to South Africa. We warmly commend the Group's work which has made a positive and enduring contribution to the efforts to end apartheid and establish a non-racial and representative government in South Africa. We particularly commend the EPG's `negotiating concept' and deeply regret its rejection by the South African Government.

4. At Nassau, the Commonwealth unanimously adopted a common programme of action which included a number of economic measures against South Africa. It was our collective hope that those measures and the efforts of the EPG to promote a process of dialogue in South Africa would, within six months, bring about concrete progress towards our objectives of seeing apartheid dismantled and the structures of democracy erected in South Africa.

5. As envisaged in the Accord, we have reviewed the situation. We are profoundly disappointed that the authorities in Pretoria have taken none of the five steps which at Nassau we called on them to take ``in a genuine manner and as a matter of urgency''. Nelson Mandela and other political leaders remain in prison. A new and more widely repressive emergency has been imposed and political freedom more rigorously curtailed; the ANC and other political parties are still banned. Beyond these, however, it has been a matter of deep concern to us that the EPG after its most patient efforts has been forced to conclude that ``at present there is no genuine intention on the part of the South African Government to dismantle apartheid and no present prospect of a process of dialogue leading to the establishment of a non-racial and representative government''. We had looked at Nassau for the initiation by Pretoria of a process of dialogue in the context of a suspension of violence on all sides. Instead, as the EPG found, the cycle of violence and counter-violence has spiralled.

6. We receive the Group's findings with disappointment, and deplore the conduct of the South African Government whose actions, including the raids on neighbouring countries at a crucial moment of the EPG's work, terminated its efforts for peaceful change. We continue to believe with the EPG that the cycle of violence in South Africa must end. It is clearly established that the situation in South Africa constitutes a serious threat to regional peace and security.
7. It is thus clear to us that since our meeting in Nassau there has not been the adequate concrete progress that we looked for there. Indeed, the situation has deteriorated.

8. Accordingly, in the light of our review and of our agreement at Nassau, we have considered the adoption of further measures against the background of the EPG's conclusion that the absence of effective economic pressure on South Africa and the belief of the South African authorities that it need not be feared are actually deferring change. We acknowledge that the Commonwealth cannot stand by and allow the cycle of violence to spiral, but must take effective concerted action.

9. We are agreed that one element of such action must be the adoption of further measures to impress on the authorities in Pretoria the compelling urgency of dismantling apartheid and erecting the structures of democracy in South Africa.

10. In doing so, we have looked particularly at the measures listed in para. 7 of the Accord which some of us at Nassau had already indicated a willingness to include in any consideration of further measures. But we have looked as well to other measures under consideration elsewhere. In deciding on the adoption of further measures, we recognise that if they are to have maximum effect they should be part of a wider programme of international action.
11. The British Government's position is set out in paragraph 12. The rest of us have agreed as follows:
(a) The adoption of further substantial economic measures against South Africa is a moral and political imperative to which a positive response can no longer be deferred.
(b) We ourselves will therefore adopt the following measures and commend them to the rest of the Commonwealth and the wider international community for urgent adoption and implementation:
(i) all the measures listed in paragraph 7 of the Nassau Accord, namely:
(a) a ban on air links with South Africa,
(b) a ban on new investment or reinvestment of profits earned in South Africa.
(c) a ban on the import of agricultural products from South Africa,
(d) the termination of double taxation agreements with South Africa,
(e) the termination of all government assistance to investment in, and trade with South Africa,
(f) a ban on all government procurement in South Africa,
(g) a ban on government contracts with majority-owned South African companies, and
(h) a ban on the promotion of tourism to South Africa, and
(ii) the following additional measures:
(i) a ban on all new bank loans to South Africa, whether to the public or private sectors,
(j) a ban on the import of uranium, coal, iron and steel from South Africa, and
(k) the withdrawal of all consular facilities in South Africa except for our own nationals and nationals of third countries to whom we render consular services.
(c) While expressing both concern and regret that the British Government does not join in our agreement, we note its intention to proceed with the measures mentioned in paragraph 12 below.

(d) We feel, however, that we must do more. We look beyond the Commonwealth to the wider international community. We will, therefore, immediately embark on intensive consultations within the international community with a view to securing concerted international action in the coming months, our emphasis being on those countries that presently sustain a significant level of economic relations with South Africa.
12. The British Government, while taking a different view on the likely impact of economic sanctions, declared that it will:
(i) put a voluntary ban on new investment in South Africa,
(ii) put a voluntary ban on the promotion of tourism to South Africa, and
(iii) accept and implement any EEC decision to ban the import of coal, iron, and steel and of gold coins from South Africa.

13. As a further element of our collective commitment to effective action, we have requested the Secretary-General, with assistance from our Governments, to co-ordinate the implementation of the agreed measures and to identify such adjustment as may be necessary in Commonwealth countries affected by them.

14. We renew the call we made at Nassau on the authorities in Pretoria to initiate, in the context of a suspension of violence on all sides, a process of dialogue across lines of colour, politics and religion with a view to establishing a non-racial and representative government in a united and non-fragmented South Africa. If Pretoria responds positively to this call and takes the other steps for which we called in paragraph 2 of the Nassau Accord, we stand ready to review the situation and to rescind the measures we have adopted if appropriate; and to contribute, in all ways open to us, to an orderly transition to social, economic and political justice in South Africa and to peace and stability in Southern Africa as a whole.

15. On the other hand, we are equally mindful of our further commitment at Nassau that if in a reasonable time even these further measures have not had the desired effect, still further effective measures will have to be considered. We trust that the authorities in Pretoria will recognise the seriousness of our resolve. Acts of economic or other agression against neighbouring states by way of retaliation or otherwise will activate that resolve.

16. Regretting the absence of full agreement but recognising that the potential for united Commonwealth action still exists, we agree that the seven Governments will keep the situation under review with the view to advising whether any further collective Commonwealth action, including a full Heads of Government Meeting, is desirable. We are conscious that the situation in South Africa may evolve rapidly and dangerously. We believe the Commonwealth must retain its capacity to help to advance the objectives of the Nassau Accord and be ready to use all the means at its disposal to do so.

17. Meeting in London at a time of heightened strains within our association, we take the opportunity to renew our own firm commitment to the future of the Commonwealth and to the aims and objectives which have guided it over the years. We are fortified in this renewal by the spirit of frankness in friendship which characterised our discussions and our belief that they have helped to light a common path towards fulfilment of our common purpose, namely, the dismantling of apartheid and the establishment of a non-racial and representative government in South Africa as a matter of compelling urgency.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Second Report 1986 on Financing the Australian Capital Territory

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The Government has used the Commonwealth Grants Commission to suggest that the Australian Capital Territory is over-financed compared with other States. The Government underplays the regional and national role of Canberra. Canberrans are right to be worried about the financial arrangements that are involved in the Australian Capital Territory self-government proposals-if we ever do get self-government under the current Parliament! I wish to say a few things about the importance of the Commonwealth Grants Commission which has done a very workman-like job in looking at the grants necessary, in the ACT particularly. So much do I believe that its influence should be continued in the allocation of money to Canberra that in the Bill that I will present tomorrow I have incorporated the Commonwealth Grants Commission as the organisation which would determine the financial allocations to the Australian Capital Territory or would advise the Government on that.

It is extremely important that when the Government gives guidelines to the Commonwealth Grants Commission as to what money should be granted to the Australian Capital Territory it should take into account the fact not only that Canberra is our national capital and requires an enormous amount of extra funds to handle the-should I say-pomp and circumstance of the Parliamentary Triangle, the gardens and facilities that are associated with a national capital, but also that Canberra is a very important regional centre for areas around it in New South Wales. This fact always seems to be missed out in estimating the role that Canberra plays and the amount of money that is necessary for operating municipal functions within Canberra.

One of the problems that has come out of the Budget is that the Minister has said that Canberra has been molly-coddled and that people in Canberra have had a much higher level of funding than have people in the rest of the country. We must realise that Canberra has a growth rate greater than almost any other area. The need for new infrastructure and new facilities is extremely important. The Australian Democrats will make certain that this is not forgotten during the forthcoming debates on funding for our national capital. The Government has left the new self-governing body-if it ever comes into effect-with a real problem by selling its main fee-earning section. It sold the Belconnen Mall which actually made a profit. The Government has not even given Canberra the advantage of lease sale revenues in its proposal for self-government. Planning and leases have been left under Federal jurisdiction. We cannot afford a starved national capital and even as temporary Canberrans we cannot afford to put up with the Government trying to squeeze the people of Canberra because the Government has not taken into account a number of the features which Canberra offers both to the local region and to the national capital as well as the local municipal function.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The tabling of the 1985-86 annual report of the Export Development Grants Board should be seen in the context of Australia's precarious economic position and the 1986-87 Budget, which the Government hopes will contribute to resolving our economic problems. There is little doubt that the major problems in the Australian economy today relate to trade; yet in the Budget there was no trade statement. In a nutshell, we have borrowed too much, we are importing too much, and we do not export enough. We are living beyond our means internationally. There is very little solace in the Budget, which seems to look only inwards. One particular problem is that the Government is not putting sufficient money and effort into schemes such as the export development grants scheme. That is quite obvious from looking at the report.

The 1985-86 Budget was predicated on the assumption that the devaluation of the Australian dollar then experienced would lead to an increase in exports and a reduction in imports. It is because this has not happened that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) this year were forced to tell Australians that we are really living beyond our means, and introduce a Budget which pandered to the perceived economic wisdom of the Treasury. There are so many people in the Treasury whose minds are set in stone, or set by Stone. I know Mr Stone has left but his influence lives on in a number of clones within that Department who are looking at pandering to international traders, international bankers and the international money market. It is a pity that these speculators have not rewarded the Government with the praise it wanted after the Budget. It is an even greater pity that the international traders have voted with their pockets to push the Australian dollar down after the Budget. We have had this reported quite widely in the Press.

The Export Development Grants Board report should remind us that there is an alternative to solving our trade problems. That alternative is to get aggressively into exporting and promote our industries as export industries instead of just trying to solve the problems by twiddling the wrong knobs. I repeat an analogy I made before. I believe the Government is currently like a driver in a runaway car fiddling with the cigarette lighter and the ash-tray. The Government is not handling the right things.

The export development grants scheme could be an extremely important way to push exports. It is very important that we get on to this aggressive approach to the export of our products in almost the same way, but not quite as ruthlessly, as the European Economic Community and the United States of America. We have to use quantitative restrictions and other barriers to reduce imports, to protect ourselves against dumping. If the Government had opted for a bigger deficit I expect that the dollar would still be where it is now. However, the extra money could have been used to promote and subsidise the sale of existing Australian exports which are suffering because the EEC and the US are subsidising their exports.

I doubt that the devaluation is enough to significantly increase Australia's exports in the short run. We will still be waiting for the J-curve many months hence. Australia's economic problems are in fact its trade problems, and until we have effective schemes which go way beyond the current export market development grants scheme we will not have an effective way of solving our trade problems and of getting ourselves out of the current economic mess into which successive government policies have put us.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

Again, we have had the spectacle of the Remuneration Tribunal's review determinations being upset by Executive government decision. This leads one to consider whether the money expended on keeping the Remuneration Tribunal in existence is worth while. If the Remuneration Tribunal is charged with considering matters affecting the entitlements of members of parliament on an independent basis and nobody accepts the umpire's decision, of course one wonders whether it is properly established, whether it is properly doing its job, or whether it is worth while at all.

One could understand some action being taken in the Parliament to overturn provisions of the Remuneration Tribunal where those provisions are not accompanied by a judgment, by a well developed logical argument in support of the provisions of those determinations. One such provision is that enabling members of parliament to take de factos overseas at government expense. This provision was inserted at the request of the Executive Government. The Remuneration Tribunal included it in the determination without giving any reason whatsoever. That might have been all right had it been a minor matter, but by giving a de facto relationship the same status as a bona fide marriage relationship it has acted as a legislative pace-setter. It included it in its determination in a manner which effectively denied to Parliament its right to exercise untrammelled scrutiny and control over delegated legislation. The Senate will know the history of the attempts of this Parliament to address itself to that matter of great principle.

Obviously, as members of parliament will know, the Tribunal knew that we, as members of parliament, could do nothing about that-unless we tipped over the whole of the Tribunal's recommendations and the Tribunal's decision-except by substantive legislation. That substantive legislation has been brought forward by the Government, not in respect of this de facto matter but in a vain gesture to upset the Tribunal's recommendations on the salary of members of parliament. Of course, I have also utilised this opportunity to overturn the Tribunal's recommendation in respect of the de facto issue. I understand that the amendment moved by the Opposition has gone back to the House of Representatives, which has rejected that amendment. The matter will come back to this chamber. Therefore, if a Minister in this place then moves that the amendment not be insisted upon, I certainly will seek to amend that motion to reinstate my amendment to amend the Tribunal's determination relating to de factos.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: ELECTION FUNDING AND FINANCIAL DISCLOSURE: ELECTIONS 1984

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The Senate will no doubt have a greater opportunity to canvass the issues contained in this report on election funding and financial disclosure when the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Electoral Reform brings down its report, presumably subsequently this year. I want to say something very short and sharp in relation to this report. I believe that the method of election funding for political parties and political candidates has acted against the best interests of democracy in Australia. If a test for democracy is to allow equality of opportunity and fairness to individual candidates, then the funding proposals contained in this conciliation and arbitration fail that test. The taxpayers' funding of election candidates and political parties in this country together with the new list system in the Senate put paid to the chances of almost all candidates who dare to stand as independents for this chamber or for the House of Representatives rather than standing as members of political parties. I said `almost', because naturally one would want to be sanguine about the outcome of the next election. I will just give honourable senators one example of what I consider to be unfair in this system. In the last Senate election in 1984 the Australian Labor Party in my State expended-as I assess it-almost three times the amount of taxpayers' money provided under the provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act which the Senator Brian Harradine Group candidate spent. This money was spent on advertisements specifically directed at that candidate. I ask the Senate whether that is fair? Is it fair or proper for a political party to use taxpayers' funds to mount a media campaign specifically directed against an individual candidate? Is it fair that the cost of that Labor Party campaign was virtually three times the amount of money that was able to be expended in relation to that independent candidate's campaign?

It appears to me that these provisions entrench the party political system to the disadvantage of independent candidates. I think that that is a real problem, particularly as it relates to the Senate, which is supposed to be a States House. If there is an independent candidate from a particular State and that candidate is to get a fair go, then he or she should not be faced with the prospect of the utilisation of massive amounts of taxpayers' funds to be directed specifically against him or her-substantially in excess of the amount of money that the candidate has available for expenditure in that election.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act, I present the report relating to the provision of 50 replacement houses at Woomera.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The proposal is for the construction of 50 replacement houses at Woomera in South Australia. The Committee found this inquiry both unique and challenging-unique because Woomera is located in an isolated part of South Australia with a climate that would tax even the most even-tempered resident, and challenging because of Woomera's retreat from its heyday when it enjoyed a population of 6,000, resulting from the activities of the United Kingdom-Australia joint project, to a present population of about 1,900. This circumstance has generated a view in some places that Woomera is in a state of continuing decline and that, as a consequence, further investment by way of housing would be unsustainable. The Committee paid particular attention to this aspect and was thoroughly satisfied by cross-examination of witnesses that there would be a Defence commitment for at least the next 15 years and that therefore it would be financially prudent and socially responsible for the existing houses at Woomera to be replaced. They are old and have reached the end of their economic lives. Refurbishment of the housing to an acceptable level would not be cost effective; indeed, refurbishment would exceed the cost of replacement houses.

SPEECH.PARA: Against this background and in the context of negotiations between the Commonwealth and the South Australian Government about normalising Woomera, the Committee has concluded that there is a need to provide 50 replacement houses. The Committee has recommended, however, that the houses should be of a higher standard than that proposed. The Committee further proposes that other instrumentalities or bodies that are obliged to provide accommodation for their employees or personnel should, on the basis of cost benefit, seek to incorporate their housing needs with the Defence proposal that is contained within this reference. The Committee's report contains recommendations about the process of normalisation, the need for other Commonwealth departments and statutory authorities to rectify housing that is allocated to their employees and a number of other matters related to the construction of the houses. The Committee believes these recommendations should be examined carefully by the Government before any decisions are taken about proceeding with the work.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 August, on motion by Senator Vigor:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Industries Assistance Commission has recommended an across the board tariff of 20 per cent for the power electronics equipment industry, except for power controllers which are closely related to computers which will, because of this, attract a bounty of 25 per cent. I believe this is a real problem. This is why I have chosen this paper from a number of papers that are being presented in this area to illustrate the problem with the Government's import-export policy, which is why we are in such a mess with trade.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to start by looking at the structure of the industry. The manufacturers of core products in this industry are dominated by five larger firms which are mainly subsidiaries or affiliates of overseas companies and which also make a wide range of related equipment. There are, however, about 30 small local firms which make specialty products, often on short runs or an individual jobbing basis, assembling components or products from the main manufacturers. Tariffs are basically a part of an import replacement program rather than a dynamic export program. The only way in which we can justify an industry in power electronics in Australia is really by trying to move ourselves to some extent into an export area.

The IAC reports that most of the components used in the production of power electronics equipment are imported. On the other hand, very little of the production is exported, and most exports are of secondary systems incorporating value added mainly in the form of design, engineering, software and support. The industry is a moderate growth industry, mainly because of the changing technologies leading, in Australia, to a much wider use of control systems in manufacturing on a local basis. There are enormous export prospects, but we are not making any effort to move into these areas.

I must examine why the prospects for such exports remain poor in the foreseeable future and list some of the impediments to exports. Firstly, we are very distant from the major markets for these products; we do not have a large local market for them. Import competition and off-shore manufacturing mean that countries just to our north which have much lower labour rates can assemble products much more cheaply than we can. Trade barriers which operate overseas make it very difficult for us to compete in these areas. It seems that the more barriers one puts up the less competitive everybody is around the world. We should be looking very closely at getting back into a good round of trade negotiations to lower tariffs rather than to raise them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Lower them for South Australian whitegoods?

—Indeed there are a lot of things that we could do to help the South Australian industry. We also need to improve the quality and our backup support for these products. Currently we have no understanding of that area.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia is very dependent on licensing arrangements for technological know-how in power and electronics. In Australia we are currently using out of date technology that is at least one generation behind the state of the art. There is an enormous cost of research and development in this area, but very little money is expended here. Thus Australia has no export markets to protect; all components are imported, and products themselves are used as components in larger systems.

Why should we have tariffs at all? I believe the policy in this area is in a mess. If we have across the board tariffs on components and products alike, is there any wonder that Australian manufacturers cannot export products at attractive prices? There is a better solution; it is through bounties. However, in this Budget the Government has cut bounties by $42m; in the IAC reports tabled here yesterday are a whole series of tariff measures, and I believe that is a real problem. We need a strong bounty system for helping industries which we know will export. This is the only way in which we will keep ourselves afloat in the very, very turbulent sea of international trade. I support a strong independent Australia, and the only way in which we are going to do this is by being a strong exporter of quality products. This policy does not help.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend this report to the Senate. The Australian National University continues to serve well the people of Australia and those of our region, with an increasing number of students, both undergraduate and graduate, in spite of continued financial pressures. I congratulate the university on its entrepreneurial success in attracting external supporting funds which have come to it in recognition of the university's contribution in many fields of endeavour and research. I beg the Government to reconsider its policy of squeezing the very life-blood of our future capacity for innovation and, possibly, survival. Education and research are assets for the Australian people which we cannot afford to run down if ever we hope to compete on an equal basis internationally.

SPEECH.PARA: I also commend the university on its practical program of visiting fellowships, which contributes in a major way to the intellectual climate in Australia. I commend the inclusion of distinguished retired members of staff who continue actively to pursue their scholarly interests within the university. I suggest that the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation could consider a similar program, rather than simply having a very expensive program of pensioning off a large number of research staff under the projected early retirement scheme. Indeed, there could be co-operation between CSIRO and the university in using some of the staff to supervise Master of Science and other post-graduate programs in a very much more effective way than currently happens. I believe that this would lead to those people who had retired from an active life in research keeping up their research interests and being a real resource for Australia.

The Australian National University has a unique role in foreign affairs. Its Research School of Pacific Studies has done much to focus Australian attention on Pacific countries and to increase our understanding of and identity with our regional neighbours. This, I believe, could lead to a wonderful system of co-operation if we are willing to listen to people within the university who support the idea of a Pacific cultural and economic community. The Peace Research Centre within the Research School of Pacific Studies holds the promise of educating a new generation in positive attitudes towards peace in our region and in the world. I am very pleased to note the appointment of Mr John Mack from South Australia as its first Head.

In view of the university's central role in liaising with overseas countries and people, I find the moves by the Government to restrict the number of overseas students most disturbing. It is through personal contact that a natural friendship can develop between the people of various countries and that understanding can be built up. Many of the people currently holding high office in neighbouring countries were educated in Australia through the Colombo Plan and retain affectionate ties with us as a consequence, hence leading to increased peace and stability within the region.

The imposition of fees on overseas students is another example of shortsightedness on the Government's part. Support for students who show sufficient initiative to come to Australia to study at great expense and sacrifice must be given. It must be looked at as a long term investment in peace and co-operation with our region. It is a pity that the Australian National University is being forced to turn away overseas students next year from the Faculty of Economics and Commerce because that faculty has exceeded its quota.

I conclude by congratulating the John Curtin School of Medical Research, which I visited on its open day, for its fascinating and highly informative displays. I commend the university for that and for the Questacon Science Centre, which is soon to become the National Science Centre. It is vital to speed up the integration of new technological ideas into the community in order to hasten our advance towards a strong, independent Australia working in close co-operation with our regional neighbours.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Chaney, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate condemns the Hawke Government for its failure to provide an economic framework which will encourage the new investment vital to improving the prospects and living standards of all Australians.

Australia is at the crossroads. We have the resources and we have the people, but we do not have a government which is capable of harnessing those assets in order to give Australia a vibrant future, and that is where the tragedy is. The motion we are debating, of which Senator Chaney gave notice yesterday, condemns the Hawke Labor Government for its failure to provide an economic framework which will encourage the new investment vital to improving the prospects and living standards of all Australians. On Tuesday evening in Treasurer Keating's Budget Speech he said that the 1986-87 Budget provided the changes needed for a more robust, aggressive economy which could stay competitive with the rest of the world. That was supposed to be the framework, we presumed; but while it was fine rhetoric, it was hollow when one looked at the substance. The newspapers and all the other commentators have not given their judgment. The dollar is down and interest rates are rising. That is not surprising, because what does the Budget predict? It predicts higher unemployment, less investment-particularly business investment-less housing, and a continuation of balance of payments problems. In fact, this Budget is a short term strategy Budget. That is unfortunate.

The Government had the opportunity last year, but it lost it. This year the Government is getting the benefit of a higher taxation revenue but it is delaying payment to pensioners. It is delaying tax relief and creating for itself an impossible situation regarding the framing of a Budget for 1987-88. In the words of our Leader, John Howard, the Australian Labor Party is now becoming a party of despair, a party of betrayed expectations, a party of sacrifice without hope. The people of Australia have now shown-it is demonstrated by the opinion polls-that because of Labor's increasing taxation they are now looking for leadership. They are looking for a party that provides hope, choice and incentive. We might well ask where the Labor Party has gone wrong. The answer lies in too much spending, particularly in the wrong direction, too much taxation, too much borrowing, and too much interference.

As the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has said, such a crisis of our time requires a new policy direction. I believe that only the Liberal-National Party coalition can provide that new direction. We must overcome the perception of overseas investors and Australian business leaders that Australia today is an unattractive place in which to do business, as a capital destination, other than for lending at high interest rates. A Liberal-National Party coalition will reduce and restructure taxation, reduce government spending and reduce the regulation of business activity. It will restore the rule of law in industrial action and move towards a more flexible labour market. It will encourage a vigorous control and reduction of business impact costs, especially government costs and charges. The Government must create a climate in which business will invest. This is what the Labor Party has failed to deliver in its Budget. In 1985-86 business fixed investments declined and the outlook remains bleak. Increased investment demands confidence in the future, a confidence that the improved competitiveness, which is supposed to come from a depreciation of the dollar, will be sustained and that there is an adequate real rate of return to offset the risks involved.

Studies by the Economic Planning Advisory Council show that the real rates of return are currently well below the levels of the 1960s and 1970s. The Hawke Government's accord with the Australian Council of Trade Unions has given Australia higher inflation, higher labour costs and higher interest rates than those of our overseas competitors. To compound these sorts of problems we now have in place some new anti-business taxes-the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax-and an increase in the company tax rate from 46 to 49 per cent. While there are people who have millions of dollars they want to invest in Australia they are unwilling to move it out of the banks of Asia, America and Europe because while our company tax rates are rising overseas company tax rates are falling. Our company tax rates will rise three percentage points. The business outcome is that overseas money is not directed to Australian fixed business investment where it should be because there is a reduced expectation of an after-tax return. There is a further erosion of international competitiveness and that is why money is not coming into Australia.

The Liberal Party will provide recovery because it seeks higher productivity. Studies around the world have demonstrated that low wages of themselves do not increase competitiveness. A good example is Indonesia, where low wages have not led to the increased competitiveness of that country. Indonesia's labour productivity is only 25 per cent of that of South Korea. What we need in Australia is not low wages and this is where the Labor Party is misconstruing the Liberal Party's philosophy. The Labor Party is trying to say: `You are the Party of low wages'. We are the Party of high living standards but what that demands is more flexible work practices with employees and employers working in unison towards common goals.

Some of the revelations of the recent Robe River dispute have given some indication of the sorts of difficulties that manufacturers and mining operators and others are facing. Let me look at one or two of those difficulties because some work practices are absolutely ludicrous. Water trucks are used to suppress dust on roads and the union demands that even when it is raining these water trucks must continue operating. The berthing of a ship was delayed by unions and this cost the company $42,000. The reason for the delay was that only nine people said that six litres of milk for their shift was insufficient so they held up the ship and this cost the company $42,000. Unions have insisted that five employees must be available on site for the operation of a rail surfacing machine designed to be operated by only two people. The fee to replace a discharged fire extinguisher after hours cost the company $80 because the employee called out had to be paid for four hours at double time. Improvements in efficiency have been hampered by unions at Robe River in numerous areas. For example, blasting efficiency was held up for 18 months because the company required holes to be drilled nine metres, rather than seven metres, apart. This was something the unions could only agree to if their shift system was changed and they got increased penalty rates.

Australia's lack of trading reliability is another impediment to increased trade. It always damages our country's image as a reliable supplier when shipments do not arrive, when orders are delivered late and ships are left off-shore at enormous cost. What does that do? It adds substantially to the cost of inventory holding. Our customers simply will not tolerate sloppy management and incompetent and irresponsible trade unions. Internal strikes discourage foreign investment and leave the Australian dollar less sought after in international monetary markets. Unreliability and the inadequacy of rolling stock, lack of consultation, rail strikes, coal strikes, waterfront strikes and an uncommercial approach by rail and port authorities are all examples of what problems exporters have to face.

Our manufacturing industries are languishing. Manufacturers contribute only 20 per cent of our export income whereas in most developed countries they contribute about 60 per cent or more. Some of the biggest gains in reducing manufacturing costs are not to be found in the 10 per cent of direct factory employees who are in the value added category but in the 90 per cent of those costs which are in the indirect, administrative and follow on areas. No matter how efficient the direct factory processing costs might be, while we have inefficiencies in areas of moving and holding goods that result in costs of idle and slow moving inventory, Australian manufacturing will be in trouble.

Australian goods do not always have to be cheaper but they have to be better in design and quality. Of course competitiveness is the degree to which a nation, under a free and fair market, can produce goods and services that must meet the rest of the international markets while simultaneously maintaining and expanding the real incomes of its citizens. Living standards are falling in Australia. The Hawke Government in its Budget has not provided the framework to lift living standards so we must all suffer. This is the theme: There is no hope; there is no choice. Unfortunately, the Hawke Labor Government identifies two economies within Australia-the domestic economy, for which it has its prescription of the accord, and the export economy, about which it says the nasty competitors, the manipulators and the money managers, cannot be controlled. This is where the Labor Party has gone wrong. Both economies are inextricably linked because all wage rises feed through this centralised wage system and affect export costs.

Australia has dropped in international competitiveness with the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries from twelfth to sixteenth and this ultimately finds its way through to lower standards of living. We have been locked into a scenario which is not all that different from what happened a few years ago in the Argentine. What did that country do? It fell into the trap of taxing its export industries to finance its non-exporting industries which are largely city based. Those industries were favoured by trade unions with ruinous results. It appears that Australia is now heading down the same rocky path.

Unfortunately, in the last 30 years Australia has slipped from eighth to twenty-third on the world export ladder. Countries such as South Korea, Hong Kong, Singapore and Brazil are now overtaking us. What is more, over the last decade our penetration of these markets has declined and our share of markets in the western Pacific region has fallen from 7 per cent to about 4 per cent. This is the area of greatest hope; this is the area in which Australia should be moving with its export industries but we are losing opportunities. Our rich national resources often guaranteed us a high international standard of living. However, the terms of trade have been moving against Australia in favour of exporters of high value-added manufactured goods. This is the area to which we have to devote a lot more attention.

What is Labor's prescription? It is new and higher taxes. The legislation for this taxation is inadequate, with anomalies and inequities. During Question Time this afternoon, there was yet another example of Ministers giving advice contrary to that given by Taxation Office officials. The Government is imposing taxes on industries which are vital to Australia's future. As we all know, the farm-in and farm-out operations are mechanisms whereby mineral and oil explorers can minimise exploration costs. They are now subject to heinous capital gains taxes. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has said: `That is not a problem because of their essentially low market values'. That opinion is contrary to that of the Taxation Office. This anti-business approach occurs in many respects.

It is strange that, at a time of high unemployment when it is necessary to move resources from one area to another and when there is little labour mobility, the Labor Government has imposed a tax that discourages people from moving from one area to another. The fringe benefits tax is one example. When an employee is transferred, that tax is incurred in respect of his personal effects and luggage. Such taxes are against ordinary people. We are advised that, for example, an employer must pay a fringe benefits tax when he has to send a poor guy whose legs are crushed by a dozer to Darwin by air. That is disgraceful.

Some Ministers have expressed sympathy and said that something will be done, but the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) has said that there will be no changes to this tax, implying that no matter how outrageous the tax and no matter how much it is against business and the welfare of ordinary people, the taxation laws will not be amended. The Government should think again in the interests of the ordinary people whom it is supposed to represent. Much of the thrust of the Government's taxation legislation will be felt by pensioners in Labor-held electorates. Labor representatives are betraying the very people who elected them to Parliament. I support the motion, which was initiated by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney), that the Government has failed to provide the framework whereby Australia can move ahead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion that the Labor Party's policies have failed to provide a framework to encourage new investment. What we have is the end point of Labor doctrine or dogma that all that is needed to run a country is the ability to distribute income, not the ability to create it or create capital. That overlooks the fundamental point that this distribution is finite-we can only take so much. When we reach the end of the road, the chest will be empty. That is all there is to it. That is the situation that Australia has reached.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall now attack two themes of Government propaganda. First, we have repeatedly had statements on television, in the papers and in this chamber, particularly by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, that we are at the end of 20 long years of problems. That is not true. The other theme which supports the 20-year inevitability theory is that it is not really our fault; it is the fault of everyone else in the world. It is not the fault of Australians and particularly not that of the Australian Government. No one can be blamed for our mess but the Hawke socialist Government with its big-spending, big-borrowing and high-taxing programs. It has failed to appreciate the signals manifest for the past two years, particularly in the overseas commodity markets. During the past 12 months, the United States State Department in particular told the Government that there would be an attack on the Common Market through the farm subsidy Bills and other measures and that Australia would be involved and would inevitably suffer. The Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin, failed to appreciate what was going on. Senator Button failed also to read the signals, which were spelt out in plain language. The Government was either not able to understand the signals or too lazy or negligent to do anything about them. That is why we are in our present mess with respect to United States wheat sales and various other matters. We have failed to respond to what the Americans told us. It does us no good, once United States legislation is passed, to wring our hands, appeal to the United States President and do the other things that the Hawke Government has done. The horse has bolted by then. Given the information that the Government had, it should have moved diplomatically to intercede and to prevent the present situation. It was possible to do so.

The purpose of the motion is to condemn the Government for its failure to provide an economic framework which will encourage the new investment vital to improving the prospects and living standards of all Australians. We could talk for days about that topic because the Government's faults are legion, but I want to confine my argument to two aspects-industrial relations and the Government's financial policies. The fundamental point is that, until we break the monopoly on the supply of labour by the union movement, this country will keep on going downhill until we are bankrupt and are taken over by other nations. We must break the unions' monopoly on the supply of labour. No other country gives the union movement such power and dominance and a monopoly. Like all monopolies, that monopoly is abused to the detriment of the community. We must allow competition between union and non-union labour. We must get rid of the de facto compulsory unionism which all Federal and State governments have practised. We must allow competition to arise as it does in the United States of America between union and non-union labour. We must move to a system of genuine voluntary unionism.

We must bring the unions under the rule of law. We must maintain and strengthen sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act in respect of secondary boycotts. Most importantly, we must make unions responsible for their actions. If people in a union withhold services and physical or financial injury is caused to other members of the community, the injured parties must have the right to recover damages before the courts. I recognise that that can be an attractive concept, but for one point. A safety net must be provided. Any reform of industrial legislation that seeks to remove the unions' monopoly control and reduce their powers without putting something in their place to protect the employee against unprincipled employers will fail. The great majority of unionists would probably prefer not to be members of a union. They are responsible people but they maintain their union membership because they know that, at some time, that union will provide in some way an insurance policy against the unprincipled employers who always exist. In putting forward these changes in industrial relations as measures which must take place, I recognise the necessity of putting in place something that guarantees protection for the average employee against an unprincipled employer.

We must get rid of the centralised wage fixing system. A centralised wage fixing system will not work for a country as vast as Australia with its varied commercial activities. Briefly, these changes can never be attacked, let alone dealt with, by a Labor government which is the creature of the union movement. So long as we have a Labor government in power in Australia federally, we are going to have the insoluble problems we have with our labour relationships and we will continue to go further and further downhill.

The financial policies of the Government have resulted in the Australian dollar coming down from when it was worth $1.25 against $US1.00 under the Fraser regime to where it is now worth 60c. It will be worth 50c soon. The average person in the street does not appreciate yet what a huge shift has taken place and he does not relate it to his personal affairs, but everyone in Australia is going to suffer a fall in standard of living because our dollar is now worth only about 60c. This fall in the value of the currency is very much a result of the judgment by the international monetary community of the policies followed by the Labor Government. What is the benefit? There is no benefit in the depreciation of the price of the dollar for the average Australian. We have taken a cut in our standard of living and, unless we do something about it, that standard of living is going to go down and down.

The only people who have benefited under the Labor Government have been the currency speculators and the takeover merchants. The Labor Party has pursued with ideological fervour the belief in the floating of the dollar. We have had all this doctrinal purity and ideological nonsense about letting the market forces decide the value of the dollar. The fact is that market forces do not operate absolutely with the float of the currency that has taken place in Australia. The value of the dollar has come down in broad terms simply because the overseas community does not have any confidence in the way that the Labor Government is managing the economy. It sees the high rates of taxation, the high interest rates and, above all, the crippling high rates of inflation we have suffered under Labor. The judgment of the overseas community is that the dollar is worth only 60c.

On that broad background, we have had very wide fluctuations in the short term where the smart operators and the speculators have got in, and those speculators have done a great disservice to the Australian community. In one day this month we had a variation of 10 per cent in the price of our currency. If the currency is moving through a band of 10 per cent, as it was in the first week in August this year, no one has any confidence in the currency abroad. They are not prepared to invest and they are not prepared to get into commercial agreements when it is such an unstable currency. However, the Government has maintained this business of having a free market for the currency. In reality it is not a free market, it is being manipulated on the one hand by the short term speculators trying to make a profit on a daily basis, and successfully doing so, and on the other hand we have had a covert operation by the Reserve Bank of Australia trying to prop up the currency. The activities of the Reserve Bank have only been admitted to by the Government in the last couple of weeks. In fact, we have some sort of semi-controlled float or a dirty float going on. The smart thing to do is to get back to the method we had under the Fraser Government of a controlled system which moves in line with the value of the currency as it stands in the international market-place, but getting rid of the daily swings, particularly the swings of up to 10 per cent which have caused so much trouble.

While I am talking about the confidence that people have in the dollar, it is interesting to see that Australians do not have much confidence in the dollar either. There were some figures in the Australian Financial Review recently which went back two years and which showed that the value of stocks and shares that Australians held overseas amounted to $217m. At the end of June this year the value was $2,361m, an increase of 1,800 per cent in the value of stocks and shares held by Australians overseas. The same article instanced the fact that while two years ago the money that Australians lent abroad was $424m, today it is $2,561m. So it is very clear that people in Australia with surplus funds have no confidence in leaving them in Australia for these people to mess around with.

One of the consequences of this 60c dollar is that Australia is for sale at half price at present. It is very ironic that the ALP, which all my life has whined about the multinational corporations and the rip-off merchants in Geneva and New York, and all the rest of it, has followed policies which have brought about the situation where we are selling off the farm at a fast rate. As I said, Australia is now for sale at half price for anyone with the funds who wants to come in. It really is a bargain basement sale.

One of the other great failings of the Labor Party is that its taxation policies have sent all the wrong signals to the commercial world. Whether it did this intentionally so that its friends could make money or whether it did it out of stupidity, I do not know. I am only concerned about the end result. In a country that is critically short of capital, we tax the accretion of it through things like the capital gains tax. We have the fringe benefits tax, which is a tax on entrepreneurs, private industry and small business. The fringe benefits tax in no way at all gets the big fish who are not paying income tax. They are evading it. We have a tax system which favours the takeover merchants. The ALP, of course, is very closely identified with most of the takeover merchants in Australia. A majority of those takeover merchants are just simply asset strippers. They live their lives on treadmills where they have to keep taking over companies and stripping the assets to pay the interest on their borrowings.

When one looks at the Bond takeover of Castlemaine Perkins in Queensland, Mr Deputy President, a product I am sure you have had a passing acquaintance with, we had a company there which was extremely well managed. It did not have an overdraft at all. It was very profitable and it paid company tax on all its earnings. Very interestingly, it applied to take over the Swan Brewery Co. Ltd. some months before it, in turn, was taken over by the Swan Brewery. The Government blocked Castlemaine Perkins taking over Swan because it was not in the national interest, yet surprisingly, when Swan tried to take it over, it was in the national interest and Swan went ahead without any difficulty.

To get back to the point, someone came along and borrowed all the money overseas to buy out the shareholders of Castlemaine, and Castlemaine will now have so many deductions in the form of interest payments that it will not pay one cent in company tax for many years to come. What is the benefit of this for Australia? Not one extra job has been created as a result of this takeover. Not one extra can of beer has been sold overseas. I had as much confidence in the former Board being able to sell Castlemaine-XXXX overseas as I have in the present bunch being able to do so. The former Board was actively developing overseas markets, but at the end of the day where have we got? We have not gained anything at all. This is the pattern of commercial life under the Labor Party. It is the takeover merchants and asset strippers who are doing very well.

We are moving towards a new feudal society in Australia where we will have a collection of maybe 100 or so super rich people and the rest of us, with our savings completely valueless because of the high inflation rate and the devaluation of the currency as a result of Labor policies, will be just living on handouts. That sort of formula will inevitably create social instability and in the end, quite simply, that is the material of which revolutions are made. I do not want to see that happen to my country.

The combination of these restrictive labour practices that the Labor Party in no way is attempting to cope with-indeed, it does not have the ability or the will to cope with them-and the economic policies that it is following which lead to high interest rates, high inflation and high taxation, have the consequence that no one is prepared to invest in Australia. The end point of this negative philosophy is the redistribution of income instead of the creation of income and the creation of capital. The tragedy is that Australia need not suffer that fate. It is all unnecessary.
