If the Government had a few intelligent and informed people making its policies, the suffering the Australian people are undergoing now and the suffering they are certainly going to experience in the years ahead, as the country goes deeper and deeper into bankruptcy, could be avoided. What do we get from Senator Walsh? What do we get from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)? What do we get from the Treasurer (Mr Keating)? What do we get from Senator Button? We get exhortations that Australia must lower its sights. They tell us: `You must have a lower standard of living'. There is nothing positive, no hope that we can get on top of the problems. All we get from this Government is: `You must lower your sights, Australia. You must accept a lower standard of living today than you had yesterday, and that is all we can offer you in the future'. That is not the fate of Australia that any of us on this side of the chamber want to see. It is not our inevitable fate at all, but it is very much our fate under the present policies of this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Government has not attempted to find a solution to our investment problems in this Budget. It has not tried to address any of the serious structural problems hindering industry's development in Australia. This country is headed for disaster unless there is an immediate and dramatic change of government policy. The radical free marketeers have dominated the thinking of the Australian Labor Party, a party that is supposed to represent the worker and the interests of all Australians. Its free marketeer policies, its market forces policies, have brought this country to the brink of bankruptcy, but unfortunately the Government does not understand this. Just the other day I asked Senator Walsh whether he was interested in protecting Australian industry from foreign takeovers by retaining the Foreign Investment Review Board. Not only did he fail to answer that question, which bodes ill for Australian ownership, but he launched into a tirade and accused the Australian Democrats of being against foreign capital of any kind coming into this country. Senator Walsh's outburst points to the malaise of the Government's economic thinking. It is absolutely incapable of seeing any distinction between productive and unproductive investment.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats have stridently opposed the funding of takeovers through the medium of foreign overseas debt. The change of ownership of a company does not necessarily make it more productive, nor does it earn us extra export income. What it does do is decrease the level of tax paid by the company concerned. Senator MacGibbon touched on that point, and I agree with much of what he said. The change of ownership very often, through the medium of foreign debt, increases the burden of servicing that debt on the community as a whole. We have to earn the foreign exchange to pay the interest on that money. This process is doing nothing but benefiting the few corporate raiders and market speculators.

A very interesting study was done recently by Dr Marzouk of the Macquarie University. He investigated investment patterns in Australia and divided these investments into two areas: Productive investments, that is, investments in machinery and productive equipment; and what he called financial investments, or investments in the stock market and investments in paper profits. His findings showed that the ratio of gross domestic product to funds used for real as opposed to paper transactions had fallen from 50 per cent in 1960 to 35 per cent in 1973, to 18.3 per cent in 1984.

I suggest at this point that we need look no further to see what is the real trouble in this country. It is much easier now to make money out of money than it is to make money out of investing in productive resources. This, of course, is the inevitable result of the market forces approach to economic management. For a start, if we have a market forces approach inevitably we have to have high interest rates. If we have high interest rates, and at the moment they are running at 15, 16 or 17 per cent, this means that any investment has to earn something like 20 per cent before interest and before tax to be more attractive than putting money in the bank. It is very hard to find investments that can earn 20 per cent before interest and tax. That limits the investment incentive in this country for a start. While we do have a market forces philosophy operating, we will be lumbered with high interest rates.

The Democrats are not saying that foreign debt or debt financing is inherently evil. What we are saying is that it is imperative that foreign borrowings be used to restructure our economy to provide more jobs, to earn us more export income and to help us escape from the boom and bust cycles that dependence on primary exports necessarily brings. Until we face up to the problem that we are short of capital and that the capital we can attract legitimately from overseas should be directed to productive areas rather than to making money out of stock market speculations, the long term interests of the Australian people will continue to be second to the needs of a few speculators who are expanding their fortunes enormously.

We have only to turn to what has happened in investments in the takeover field over the last few years to see this. In 1984, $1.2 billion was invested in takeovers; in 1985, the figure was $4.5 billion; and so far in 1986-this calendar year-$7.7 billion has been invested in defending and attacking the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd alone. Goodness knows how the year will finish up, but it will be a dramatic increase on anything we have seen before. That $7.7 billion invested in the speculation around BHP shares has not added one iota of productive capacity to this country, nor will the takeover of Nicholas Kiwi (Pacific) Pty Ltd by foreign interests, nor has the takeover of Repco, nor has the attempted takeover of Australian Consolidated Industries. They will not do anything to improve the productive capacity of Australia. Most of these takeovers have been funded by foreign money, and all Australians are now going to be asked to meet the interest commitments on that foreign borrowing. We cannot go on doing this. If we keep attracting money into the country with high interest rates we inevitably have to service that money. No overseas investor will invest in Australia unless he can see that there is a reasonable chance of getting his money back within about three years, in the present climate.

So it is a very short term policy. We attract money but within three years we not only have to pay all that money back but for the rest of all time we have to meet the interest commitment, or the servicing commitment, on that investment in this country. In other words, foreign owned companies send dividends outside the country, they do not put money into circulation within Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —What would have happened to the Australian dollar if the money had not come in?

—The Australian dollar was held at reasonable levels until quite recently. As a matter of fact, Senator MacGibbon made a very cogent point on this. Our Australian assets are now for sale at half price, and now the Government is presumably going to disband the Foreign Investment Review Board. The Government is saying: `We have a low dollar but please come in, please bring your capital in here and buy up whatever of the farm is left. We could not care less. We must have foreign capital at any cost'.
—You are genuinely fair dinkum? You really don't understand?

—I am simply saying that while we have a market forces economy investment will flow into areas that are unproductive, and we cannot afford to have that happen. It is not foreign to Liberal Party philosophy for governments to interfere in the way the economy should be managed. The economy was managed very effectively by the Menzies Government in 1952. Our fundamental problem today is not that the economy is not working well internally; our problem is the current account, in that we are not able to pay for the imports flowing into the country. What has the Government done? It has brought down an austerity Budget which will squeeze the whole economy and will inevitably send the economy into a tailspin, simply to solve a problem which relates purely to our balance of trade. There are other ways of solving that problem. We could restrict imports by whatever means is appropriate; that is, handle the problem directly. If we wanted to, we could manage the Australian dollar. It was managed successfully for many years. Why should we allow international speculators to do what they like with our currency? It we wish, we can regulate to some degree the flows of capital in and out of this country by a variety of mechanisms. I am suggesting simply that the Government should manage the economy.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the big myths about the market forces economy is that it is essential to cut back on Government expenditure to make room for private sector investment. That is exactly what the Government is trying to do right now. If we look at the figures, we find something very interesting. The Government debt right now is very low by historical comparisons. In the 1920s, 1930s, 1940s and 1950s the total Government debt in Australia was equal to well over 100 per cent of our gross domestic product and today it is down to about 44 per cent of our gross domestic product. So the problem is not Government expenditure; the problem is that the private investment is going into unproductive areas which means that it is not giving a return to the Australian people.

By and large it seems to me that we have to change direction and we have to do it very quickly if we are to avoid an absolute disaster in this country. This disaster will not be avoided until the Government drops its free market ideology and takes responsibility for the development of industry. The Government must put in place the mechanisms to encourage productive investment and to discourage speculation. Until that is done Australia will continue to decline and our problems will only become worse and worse. We have to attack the fundamental problem. For many years we have been attracting foreign capital to Australia and have been selling out the farm, but that has not worked so there has to be a change of direction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion of the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney), which states:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate condemns the Hawke Government for its failure to provide an economic framework which will encourage the new investment vital to improving the prospects and living standards of all Australians.

Before proceeding to deal with that motion in detail, I will deal with one point made by Senator Siddons in his very old-fashioned, interventionist, father knows best, playing God approach to the Australian economy. Senator Siddons appears to forget that when we are running a current account deficit of $14 billion a year we have to pay for it. Money has to come from somewhere and do something. It is all very well saying that if that money comes in for some specific purposes it is somehow disgraceful that interest should have to be paid on it, but that omits to recognise the vital point that that money has to come in anyway and do something and someone will have to pay interest on it. We are running such a massive debt and have such a huge imbalance and are structurally in bad shape mainly as a result of inappropriate Government big spending policies at a time when the Government should have been cutting back and we were warning it that it should have been cutting back. For example, this Budget, at least in terms of its paper result, should have been the Budget of one or two years ago, as we were recommending, rather than the Budget of this year. It is now too little too late and too phoney.

It is distressing that Senator Siddons, in his argument against the free flow of market forces allowing this money to come in for whatever purpose, omitted to mention that that money would have had to come in anyway and do something and have interest paid on it simply to pay for the current account deficit we are running. Where does Senator Siddons think the money will come from and go to? When we have the structural imbalance that has been created by this incompetent and irresponsible Government, we have to have money coming in to service it.

TALK.START.PARA: —We could start buying less overseas. That would be a start, wouldn't it?
—What was the current account deficit in 1981-82, Patrick?

—As Senator Siddons said, it could be controlled. That brings me to the essential point, rather than the matter being raised by the Minister for gutters. The essential point is that if we start imposing controls, as Senator Siddons wants to do, we will in fact do exactly what we are concerned about in this motion; that is, we will destroy the environment for investment. Let us look at what is seen by the Government to be the sort of thing that should happen. I quote from the Budget Speech of the Minister for bananas. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) said--
—He does not even know what's in his own legislation.
—That is right. The Treasurer said:

SPEECH.PARA: As a nation . . . we need to invest more and consume less.
That is the strong, exciting rallying cry from the Treasurer. He said:
In other words, we must save for the future rather than spend for the present.

As usual, the rhetoric is magnificent but the performance is appalling. We need to invest more and consume less. What will happen as a result of this Budget? Are we going to invest more? Not on your nelly, not according to the Treasury in statement No. 2, which states that investment will fall this year as a result of this so-called dynamic, efficient and effective Budget. This Budget is a hoax. On the very fundamentals, the vital things the Treasurer himself says must happen-we need to invest more-there will be a fall in investment. In fact, we will invest less. The Treasurer said that we must save for the future rather than spend for the present. What in fact will happen to saving? The savings ratio will fall this year. Strike two to the world's greatest Treasurer. On his own criteria this Budget is a failure, but it is a failure on far stronger grounds than that. We cannot really take the world's greatest Treasurer to be an authority on these matters any more.

Let us look at three essential points which will indicate what will happen to us in the future. We have seen already that there will be falling investment this year. In other words, our capacity to replace imports by investing in new plant and equipment and to provide new jobs for people will fall as a result of this Budget. If one were a foreign lender would one be enthralled about lending more money to Australia when one knows that investment will be down and Australia's capacity to get itself out of trouble will be diminished? If we do not invest and produce more, what are our prospects of resolving the fundamental problems, the fundamental hole that the Government has pushed us into? What will happen to inflation rates as a result of this Budget? Let us look at comparative inflation rates. Inflation rates are the essential element in terms of us maintaining any competitive advantage we tried to get from devaluation which Mr Keating said would flow through the J-curve. He is pretty quiet about the J-curve. It is not even an L-curve now, it is an ever declining straight line.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not even an S-bend.

—It is not even an S-bend, it is going straight down the gurgle hole. Australia has the highest inflation rate, approximately four times that of most of our major trading partners and eight times that of our more sophisticated trading partners. We are going steadily downhill following this `great', `wonderful' Budget which is supposed to fix things. We are presenting an even worse environment for investment in Australia because our inflation rate will steadily erode the competitive benefits bought at the extraordinarily huge cost of continuing devaluations which are due to this Government's incompetence.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the last of the three disasters affecting the investment climate-the continuing disaster on our current account. It looks like being even more than this year's adjusted $13.7 billion deficit-a rate, by the way, of about $26,000 a minute. Under this Government, Australia has been going broke at the rate of $26,000 a minute as this Government has fiddled and come up with a phoney budget at a time when we are in real crisis. It will be worse next year according to the Budget Papers. What on earth would encourage either Australians to invest or foreigners to invest in Australia when the three fundamental elements on which our recovery-if any-must be based are steadily going bad, with no sign this year of improvement and with this Budget admitting that the Government is pushing Australia into recession because it has not responded quickly enough? Because of the Government's activities the atmosphere and the environment for investment have obviously been damaged-one hopes not beyond repair, but they have been damaged massively.

It is clear that the Government got something like the right deficit number to try to provide some incentive for people to invest, for foreigners to bring their money here, for Australians to invest here and for the Australian economy to rise again from the ashes into which the fiddling of the Government opposite and the burning of Rome have led us. The Government got the right number, but in the wrong way. It got the right deficit number of about $3.5 billion, but not by cutting its spending. The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), as usual, was monumentally incompetent. There is no cut in real terms this year in government spending. It will increase despite all the hype and propaganda. After government spending this year is adjusted for inflation, it is higher than it was last year. In money terms it is up about 6.9 per cent, and it is slightly up in real terms after adjustment for inflation.

We have not seen that fact in the headlines around the place. So `efficient' and `effective' were the Minister for Finance's cuts that government spending is still higher than it was last year. If we had had genuine spending cuts, this Budget would have been far more effective. It would have created a better environment for recovery. Instead, we have had a Budget that adds to the costs of the one sector that can save us-the business sector-the investment sector, the productive sector, the sector which has to try to replace imports or try to invest to produce greater exports. Instead of providing assistance the Government has added $1.5 billion in new taxes mainly to this very sector on which our recovery depends.

That is the way to provide incentives for investment! It is the level of the intelligent approach that this Government has to solving our fundamental problems. The reality is that taxes are now being lifted by $6.5 billion overall. That is an 11 per cent increase in taxes, of which $1.5 billion is in totally new taxes that are deliberately belting the productive sector. The fuel excise hits farmers who are desperately struggling to export. It hits all productive areas, particularly the costs of transporting items to market to try to sell them. It affects the whole cost structure.

As I said, these taxes are up by 11 per cent to their highest level ever. At 25.5 per cent of gross domestic product that also forms a record, as does total revenue. Mr Keating is maintaining at least one record and that is of being Australia's highest taxing Treasurer ever. We have a Treasurer who, even when presenting the rhetoric of restraint, the appearance of rectitude, the hype and propaganda of cuts, is increasing both spending and taxing. We can say: `Yes, but the result has been that he has solved the public sector borrowing requirement problem. He has cut the demand that the Government will have on supply of funds for the private sector'. That is quite true. Demand by the Government will be minimal this year. It is very fortunate that it should be. There should not be excessive governmental pressure on interest rates or any scramble in the market for money to provide for the reduced volume of people, with a reduced volume of investment, who may want to invest.

That sounds significant, except that there are two catches. They totally overwhelm any benefits that might have come to the Government as a result of papering over this problem. One of the ways that it has papered over the problem is by converting some of our assets of foreign exchange, which have appreciated in value because of the devaluation, into revenue of $2.8 billion this year to dress up the deficit, to make it look better. We have heard from Senator Walsh how dreadful it is that some people convert revenue into assets and that it is pretty crooked of them to do so. What about this Government that converts assets into revenue to dress up a document and give the appearance of respectability to a Budget which is knocking the hell out of investment?

What else is the Government doing? It solved its deficit problem by putting all the money offshore, plus $800m. It has created an internal surplus to totally remove any pressure on the public sector borrowing requirement, but it has transferred the problem offshore. We have to service this. As the Budget Papers say, something like 80 per cent of the external deficit which this Government has created of well over $4 billion requires foreign currency. We are in a serious foreign exchange crisis. This Government worsens it to window-dress its Budget internally. That is a typical example of total irresponsibility from this Government. That money has to be serviced. That total amount of well over $4 billion is more than double the highest figure ever under the previous Government, to which Senator Walsh keeps referring.

We not only have the little problem of worsening our basic situation externally by transferring the problem overseas; we also have the ludicrous situation in which interest rates will now be dominated not by the public sector borrowing requirement or pressures within our internal market but by the fact that we will continue to go broke at the rate of $14 billion-plus a year on our current account. We still have to pay for that by attracting money from overseas. It would not matter a damn what the local demand for funds was. We have to provide a sufficiently high interest differential to attract money from overseas. Senator Walsh ought at last to know about this interest differential because he made a fool of himself over the cost of foreign exchange cover last year when I tackled him about the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. At least the Minister for Finance now understands what interest rate differentials between Australia and overseas are. Our continuing current account crisis will require Australia to have an interest rate differential above that of major potential lending countries, particularly the United States. Any prospect of getting our interest rates down will depend entirely on what happens to interest rates overseas. If they fall overseas, they will fall relatively in Australia. But they will still maintain a large differential because we need to attract the money to pay for our continuing deficit. In other words-and I conclude on this point-on every ground that is fundamental to Australia's future, that is fundamental to providing an environment for investment, this Budget has not improved the situation; it has worsened it. This Government stands condemned for once again imposing an impossible situation on Australian business by hitting it with taxes rather than having the self-discipline to control its own spending, which, as I said, is to increase. Once again this Government is responsible for the disasters facing Australia this financial year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion put in place by the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate condemns the Hawke Government for its failure to provide an economic framework which will encourage the new investment vital to improving the prospects and living standards of all Australians.

After the last four years of government by the Australian Labor Party no one would seriously argue that the living standards of all Australians have not fallen. They have fallen significantly right across the board. Business confidence is lacking, demand is lacking, taxes are high, interest rates are high. All this going into the fourth Budget of the Labor Government. The headline in the Australian says it all: `Budget: dollar down, interest rates increase'. That is what the world thinks of the fourth Budget the Labor Party has brought down. I am not an eminent economist, but I have been in business for 18 years and it seems very obvious to me that if we increase taxes by $1.5 billion we will slow down demand, reduce employment prospects, and ultimately, as plain as night follows day, increase unemployment and face the same old treadmill. The Budget had absolutely nothing in it for small business. When America faced a financial crisis, small business worked its way out of it. Small business would be able to do the same in Australia if it were allowed to prosper and grow. Small business employs 60 per cent of the work force of Australia. It pays the majority of taxes and employs the majority of people; yet it is being stifled by high taxes and by all the impediments that have been placed on it over the last four years. I could run through a long list of those impediments but I will mention just a few. There is the capital gains tax, the prescribed payments, and industrial democracy, which the Labor Government has not brought forward but which is on the menu. Significant amounts of money have been spent on research into industrial democracy. There is no doubt that it is a plank of the Labor Party platform and at an appropriate time will be brought forward. I mention also the 3 per cent productivity claim for superannuation, and redundancy payments. I can go on and on. It is no wonder people are terrified to invest in Australia. It is a country that has all the natural resources, everything going for it; yet we find ourselves being told to lower our aims and expectations, and to reduce the standard of living that we have enjoyed over a significant number of years. Since the Whitlam Government we have fallen from about number three on the world standard of living scale to about 21. As a nation that has everything going for it we should be able to maintain our standard of living if people have confidence, but how can people have confidence when every time they are prepared to invest in the market, in employing people, in machinery, they get an extra tax or obstruction placed in their way?

TALK.START.PARA: —Especially the capital gains tax.

—I have mentioned the capital gains tax. In the 10-week recess I visited previous clients of mine in the hardware industry in Queensland whom I have serviced for over 18 years in my business. I recommend that every honourable senator get out and see what is happening. I was absolutely alarmed as I did not realise the situation was as bad as it is out there. I talked to real estate agents and to social workers. Most people in the business area told me that sales were down by between 25 and 30 per cent. Most people said that they were just holding the line. Real estate agents told me that there was a tremendous tragedy in the community because people had bought $60,000 houses but could not sustain the interest payments and were trying to trade back to $40,000 houses, thus losing between $20,000 and $30,000. Yet this Budget has done nothing to address the problems.

SPEECH.PARA: When taxes are raised to the level of $1.5 billion I cannot see any hope for improvement in the situation. I understand what the Government is trying to do. It is trying to reduce the deficit, but it is doing it, as a number of speakers have said, by increasing taxes instead of reducing government spending. This will not lead to a recovery in the business sector. It will not lead to an increase in employment. It may lead ultimately, in the long term, to slightly reduced interest rates, which will be commendable if achieved. It is obvious from labour costs that we will continue to be uncompetitive with our trading partners. Our interest rates are higher than theirs. Our inflation rate is higher. I will read into Hansard some consumer price index figures to compare Australia with our overseas trading partners. It is interesting to note that Australia has a figure of plus 8.4 per cent, West Germany, minus 0.05 per cent; Japan, plus 0.8 per cent; the United Kingdom, plus 3.8 per cent; and the United States of America, plus 1.7 per cent. Unless we can get the consumer price index down in line with our overseas competitors there is really no hope on the horizon that things will improve.

We should also look at interest rates. In Australia the prime lending rate is 17.5 per cent for borrowers. In West Germany it is 7 per cent, Japan, 4.13 per cent; and the USA, 8 per cent. When we look at those two sets of figures, it is apparent that Australia will not be able to compete unless we attack the fundamental wage structure. Over the last year labour costs have increased by around 11 per cent or 12 per cent. Currently there is a wage case for a 2.3 per cent increase. There is a productivity claim current which the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission has walked away from and left for the industrial jungle to sort out. No doubt we will see the superannuation claim filtering through into many industries. There is a 4 per cent wage claim set for October-November and another 3 per cent claim for April-May. We must recognise that, even though the Government is prepared to discount those wage claims when it takes its cases before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, even if those wage claims are discounted by 2 per cent, that will still not bring us into a competitive phase with our overseas trading partners. Unless we can get that wage structure down, unless we can get our cost-price index and our interest rates down, then-

TALK.START.PARA: —Who wrote that rubbish for you?

—I am standing here in this chamber as a person who has done research on this subject, as a person who has been in business for 18 years, as a person who has gone out over the last 10 weeks and sought some answers to the problems that are besetting this country.
—Who wrote that rubbish for you?
—I wrote it myself. These are my thoughts that I am putting on behalf of the people I represent in Queensland. I think most people would agree with them.
—You represent sheep and cattle mostly, don't you?

—The National Party received 30 per cent of the Senate vote in Queensland, which is a significant vote. As I said, these are the prospects that face Australia. Unless we can pull wage costs down into line with those of our overseas competition this country probably will fall from twenty-first place in living standards to an even worse position.

SPEECH.PARA: I take note of what Senator MacGibbon and Senator Siddons said and I believe that that has to be investigated also. I believe that competitiveness is lacking in the Australian economy. There has been one takeover after another in the retail section. When manufacturers go to sell their products they find that 85 to 90 per cent of their business is coming from four or five accounts. Those four or five accounts have massive buying power, and the discounts they are asking the manufacturers to pay, the television advertising allowances and so on that are required, are squeezing manufacturers' profits to a very marginal rate. That is another problem that has to be addressed by this Parliament and, as far as I know, it is one that has not been raised before. However, it is a very fundamental reason why profits are down. I support the motion moved on behalf of the Leader of the Opposition and commend it to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too rise to support very strongly the motion moved by Senator Watson on behalf of the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney). The motion states:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate condemns the Hawke Government for its failure to provide an economic framework which will encourage the new investment vital to improving the prospects and living standards of all Australians.

The Government had a golden opportunity in its Budget this week to provide leadership, honesty and consistency in its economic management and to give a lead to all Australians. It failed dismally on all those counts. It failed to provide leadership. The Budget lacks direction, it lacks purpose, it lacks cohesion. It lacks any sense of giving to Australians the feeling that the Government knows where it is going and where Australia as a nation should be going. The Budget lacks honesty because its underlying assumptions are so rubbery as to be downright shonky.

Much of the Budget estimates are predicated on a growth in our gross domestic product for 1986-87 of 2 1/4 per cent, made up of an increase in non-farm gross domestic product of 2 1/2 per cent and a fall in farm GDP of a similar amount. The prospect of getting in Australia in the year ahead, indeed between now and June 1987, an overall growth in GDP of 2 1/4 per cent is so slight as to make the Budget estimates quite unbelievable. We have now had three quarters of nil or negative growth in Australia. The Government has predicated its whole economic strategy in this Budget on the expectation that suddenly that negative growth will turn around and grow at a reasonably healthy rate between now and June 1987. There is not one fundamental underlying economic reason why that should be so. Because the growth estimates are far too optimistic, the Government's revenue estimates cannot be relied on. They too are far too high. Even if we accepted the Government's revenue estimates, this Government would still be the highest taxing government in Australia's history when we consider taxes as a proportion of our national output.

On the expenditure side too, it can be seen that many of the figures are highly dubious. For example, the figures for unemployment benefit expenditure are predicated on an increase in unemployment which appears to be far too low, even given the Government's own growth estimates. Those revenue estimates are too low. However, even if both the revenue and expenditure estimates were accurate, we would still have a higher proportion of outlays, certainly in the case of expenditure to gross domestic product, than was the case not only in each of the seven years of the Fraser Government but also in each of the three years of the Whitlam Government. Many people in Australia do not realise that we have for a decade now lived in the shadow of the great economic crisis the Whitlam Government brought upon this nation as a result of the extravagant, wilful and enormously rapid rate of increase in government spending as a proportion of our national output. Despite what the Hawke Government has said about revenue restraint, in each of its four Budgets it has had a higher proportion of expenditure to national output than did the Whitlam Government in any of its three years.

The other thing that is very shonky in relation to the estimates for the forthcoming year-this is a matter on which I tackled Senator Walsh in Question Time today and about which he completely failed to give an answer-is the value of the Australian dollar over the next 12 months. The Budget estimates forecast that the trade weighted index, that is, the overall value of the Australian dollar, between now and 30 June 1987 will be 52. On the day on which the Budget was delivered the trade weighted index for the Australian dollar was 51.5. The Budget estimates forecast a slight strengthening in the value of the Australian dollar against the currencies of other countries. On the day after the Budget the trade weighted index fell by 2 per cent to 50.5. How could the Government forecast and predicate its Budget estimates on a trade weighted index of 52 when it accepts-it is stated publicly in the Budget documents-that inflation will run at 8 per cent? I think that is too low but, even if one accepts the Budget's figure of 8 per cent, that still shows that there is an acceptance by the Government that inflation in this country in 1986-87 will be at least four times higher than that of our major trading partners.

Also the Government has stated in the Budget Papers that it has accepted that the current account deficit, which is the real achilles heel of the Australian economy and which has caused this nation's crisis, will show no improvement in this financial year. According to the Government's estimates, it may even worsen slightly. How on earth can we have a maintenance of the value of the Australian dollar under those two circumstances? The only way in which we can have it is on the assumption that there will be another massive rise in interest rates to attract capital here to balance our external books. If the interest rate increase does not occur, the value of the Australian dollar must fall in the total environment. If that happens, the implications for the whole of the Budget estimates and the whole of the economic strategy on which this Budget is based fall to the ground. I repeat that today the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) failed completely to provide an answer. He said that the figure of 52 for the trade weighted index was a matter of judgment. What a thing to say when that figure is a key element in the planning of the whole economic strategy for this nation for the year ahead.

There are many other rubbery figures that I could mention, but overall suffice it to say again that this Budget will be the highest taxing Budget in our history. It has major weaknesses in its restraint of spending, despite that elusive looking, deceptive figure of zero growth in real spending. Much of that has been arrived at simply by a deferment rather than a cancellation of expenditure. Not one government program, to my knowledge, has been eliminated. The only way in which we will get a realistic approach to spending by a national government is to look at all the programs and get rid of the ones that the government has no right to have. This Government has not done that in this Budget; it has simply tinkered at the edges.

This is not the Budget that Australia needs in 1986. As a nation we desperately need a Budget which would involve less taxation. This Budget has introduced new taxes totalling, across a wide range, $1.5 billion to $2 billion. We need less spending than will occur under this Budget. We need lower interest rates, but the Government's strategy looks as though it will inevitably force up interest rates. We need lower inflation, not a Budget that imposes additional costs which will increase inflation. We need a stimulus to investment, and that is where I come back to the main thrust of the motion that is before the Senate. In Budget Paper No. 2 it is noted that a higher living standard for Australians can be achieved only by an improvement in Australia's external account which crucially depends upon substantial new investment, especially in the traded goods sector. That is a statement with which I and the Opposition totally agree; it is one at which one could not take exception. It is only if there is an increase in business investment that Australia will be able to achieve the necessary growth in production of goods for export and production of goods as substitution for imports. Yet the Treasury is predicting that private investment will fall in 1986-87 from its already abysmally low level.

I note that in today's Press the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is reported as saying that he does not expect investment to fall by one per cent, by which he said it would fall according to the Budget documents that were released 48 hours ago. How can we believe what this Government is saying in terms of some of the fundamentals on which its economic strategy is supposed to be based when, within 48 hours of delivering the Budget Speech in which the Treasurer presented a crucial investment forecast, he is now saying that he does not think that forecast is right? If that is not rubbery figuring, if that is not the sort of statement that is designed-if not deliberately, it certainly has this effect-to undermine completely the confidence of the business sector in this country I do not know what is. If members of the Government were to talk to members of that business sector, be they in small business, large business, primary, secondary or tertiary industry, they would find that these people have completely lost confidence in this Government. That is a result of the performance of this Government, which has been trying dishonestly to present to the Australian people rubbery figures in key documents and events such as this Budget.

Given recognition of the vital role that investment is required to play in restoring the living standards of all Australians, it is quite remark- able that this Budget does nothing at all to stimulate investment. Indeed, it is likely that the measures contained in the Budget will positively discourage investment in the coming year, particularly through the cost increases imposed in a variety of ways, including a wide range of increased taxation. In other words, the Government has failed to address the fundamental reasons for reduced levels of investment in Australia. Economic recovery in this country will be achieved only if due attention is paid to four major areas, which are: Firstly, reduced and restructured taxes made possible by reduced government spending; secondly, reduced and less costly regulation of business activity; thirdly, the restoration of the rule of law in industrial relations and a flexible labour market; and, fourthly, rigorous control and reduction of business input costs, especially government taxes and charges. Those four key areas have been identified and tackled by the Opposition in its policy document Policies for Business which was released at the Federal Council of the Liberal Party of Australia a month ago. It has been quite rightly and widely acclaimed by the business sector because it offers hope, certainty, incentive, a way for Australia to get ahead and a reason to invest in Australia. On all those counts this Government has failed completely to deliver.

The phoney restraint in the Budget that was delivered on Tuesday night comes hot on the heels of a four-year spending binge which has nearly doubled the Federal Budget outlays and which has added nearly $50 billion to the public debt of this nation. At first glance it seems that the Australian Labor Party has finally seen the writing on the wall and turned to responsible economic management, with a zero real increase in spending and a deficit of $3.5 billion. On the face of it they are both good figures but, as the falls in the value of the Australian dollar since the Budget was delivered indicate, the market at least and, increasingly, average Australians have woken up to the tricks that the Treasurer employed in delivering this Budget. It was a Budget done by mirrors. When one looks behind the mirrors one finds that there is little or no substance in the major figures. As I have already mentioned, closer examination shows clearly that assumptions on which the forecasts of government spending and revenue are based are quite out of kilter with fact and with fundamentals of the Australian economy. In particular-I repeat it because it is so fundamental to the whole Budget and economic scenario-the growth forecast of 2 1/4 per cent is over-optimistic. That figure is made up by the Government anticipating that external demand will increase by 1.75 per cent and that domestic demand will increase by half a per cent-0.5 per cent. Yet, given increasing inflation, high and inevitably increasing real interest rates and our present and continuing current account deficit of $14 billion or more, it is highly unlikely that Australia will be able to lift its net export performance by anything like 1.75 per cent or that domestic demand will increase by half a per cent, given that the requisite production of goods and services to replace imports will not occur. At the end of Budget statement No. 2 it states:
. . . it will necessarily take some time to effect the required correction in the external accounts.

A close reading of the Budget Papers leads to the conclusion that if this Government continues to pursue policies of this type it will be a very long time indeed, if at all, before we are able to steer the economy back on to the right track. It is ironic-tragic would perhaps be a better word-that the Government has implemented policies which will increase inflation by more than its own prediction of 8 per cent, and at the very least maintain, but more likely increase, the already high real interest rates and so discourage investment, in turn discouraging and setting back the prospect of economic recovery. It is even more ironic that the Government has neglected to implement measures that will encourage the restructuring of Australia's economy, which is vital to economic recovery.

Improved economic performance depends upon the ability of our producers to make goods at prices at which they can compete on international markets. This requires that the costs involved in producing those goods are reduced. Yet, as I have said, several measures in the Budget militate against a reduction of costs for Australian producers. Indirect taxes, estimated to add $1,400m alone to the Government's coffers, will increase costs for all Australian producers. For example, petrol, an essential input for most industries, is to be taxed yet again.

I am not sure whether the Australian public is yet aware that the 3c per litre hike in fuel excise will drive up the price of petrol to an average of 53c per litre. All in all, this year alone petrol taxes have risen by nearly 14c a litre, from 10c a litre to 23.8c a litre. That is an increase in this year alone of 140 per cent. On top of that, the Budget estimates show that the anticipated increase in revenue from petrol taxes in 1986-87 will be 96 per cent greater than in 1985-86. The swag of anti-business taxes, such as the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax, did not even rate a mention in Tuesday night's Budget. Rather than attempt to reduce the burden of tax on business, this Government has ignored its responsibility to provide incentive for business to invest. As a percentage of gross domestic product, taxation, as I said earlier, will be at a record level-almost 26 per cent. For the second successive year this hike in taxation breaks the taxation promise of the Government's trilogy commitment. For two years in a row-the first two years of its three-year trilogy commitment-the Government has broken the Prime Minister's sacred promise and, with a blatant disregard for honesty, the Treasurer on Tuesday night even failed to mention that the promise was broken in 1985-86. It was only when one looked at the fine print of the accompanying statements that one saw it. There was not one mention of it.

Tuesday night's Budget contained no announcements regarding the reduction of the costly plethora of regulations on business activity. This increasingly onerous burden for business has recently been estimated by the Government's own Business Regulation Review Unit to cost the Australian community between $40 billion and $80 billion annually-an absolutely staggering burden on our economy. The disastrous impact that Government regulation has on business activity and levels of investment is experienced by a myriad of businesses in Australia. We all know of numerous examples. On the third major area crying out for attention, namely wage fixation and industrial relations, the Government has also failed totally to bite the bullet. On page 55 of Budget Paper No. 1 it is stated:
If adequate profitability is to be achieved, additional restraint needs to be placed on labour costs.

I completely agree with that statement. It is clear evidence, too, that the Government is aware of the link between profitability and investment and labour costs. Yet, in the same section of the Budget Papers, the Government indicates that it will restrain wages only by supporting a 2 per cent discount to account for the effects of devaluation. That is, quite frankly, not tough enough. It ignores the inflationary effects of its own domestic policies, such as increases in indirect taxes. It ignores the fact that the consumer price index does not measure everything that is imported, such as business machinery. It ignores the increases in other significant costs, such as postal and telephone charges. Most important of all, it ignores what is happening in the rest of the world. It ignores the fact that Australia has to be internationally competitive. It ignores that fact that price inflation in Australia is continuing to price us out of world markets. It also ignores the urgent need the nation has to lift the level of our productivity. The question of productivity increases is a very wide ranging and very difficult area. It is an area to which we as a nation will have to give much more attention. There has to be a much greater community understanding of what is meant by productivity drive in Australia. We have to start getting on with that job. This Government has failed and is failing completely to do that.

It is ironic that on the one hand the Government is pinning its hopes for economic recovery on increasing levels of investment in and, therefore, production by Australia's manufacturing sector but, on the other hand, Australia's record on the wages front in that sector has been depressing and promises to be even more so as wages increase, regardless of the capacity of business to pay. Wages in Australia in the last two years in the manufacturing area rose by almost 15 per cent, which is more than double the increase which occurred in the United States, Canada and West Germany, and almost double that of our major trading partner, Japan. When wage-related costs are included, our record pales even more in comparison with that of our trading partners. The Budget Papers show the Government's unwillingness to attack the fundamental rigidities of the labour market. By reaffirming its commitment to the centralised wage fixing system and the accord, the Government has ensured wage increases regardless of the capacity of individual businesses to pay and regardless of what it has done in the area of discounting.

One of the so-called achievements of the deal between the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions-namely, the prices and income accord-is that it has resulted, so the Government says, in wage restraint and the lowest level of industrial disputation in Australia for 17 years. There has been an alarming rise in the use of the backdoor method of increasing wages, that is, through on-costs, thereby leading to declining levels of recorded industrial disputation. But the two factors must be looked at together. It is a myth to believe that the Australian experience of declining levels in industrial disputation is unique. For example, over the past four years there has been a world-wide decline in industrial disputation in Western democracies. Between 1981 and 1985 time lost through industrial disputation fell in the United States and Canada by 60 per cent, it fell in West Germany and Italy by 80 per cent, and even in France it fell by 50 per cent. Given that those countries have no centralised wage fixation system or anything resembling our accord, it is absurd to argue that it is the accord which has been responsible for the decline in recorded strike activity.

We simply have to do better on all of these fronts. No wonder the new investment needed to get Australia going again, to make us more productive and to improve our competitiveness is not forthcoming. Our potential is very great if we can get our act together. The Government has failed to provide the leadership, direction and purpose to encourage investment, to make investors, and consumers for that matter, confident in our future. For that failure this Government stands condemned. Therefore, I trust that the Senate will fully support the motion now before it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am bringing up the tail in this debate, which is about the failure of the economic performance of this Government. The Government is now locked into a collision course with economic disaster. All governments stand or fall on their economic policies, and this Government had a chance to rectify the situation when it announced its Budget this week. The whole country was prepared for the Government to take the hard decisions. We had listened to all of the announcements from both the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) telling us that they would knuckle down and take the hard decisions. But when it came to the announcement it turned out that they had not done so. There was a little kick-up in international confidence about the country and its prospects, but that lasted about an hour. Once overseas countries had a good look at what the Government intended to do here, they immediately sank back into their lack of confidence. However, the lack of confidence is not only overseas but also within this country, because it became obvious almost immediately that the Government intended to increase taxes and to increase its own spending. Even taking into account the moderate cuts to a few areas, the overall effect of the Budget is that the Government will spend a lot more than it did last year.

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard a lot about the much vaunted wages accord, extolled by the Treasurer as well as the Prime Minister and the economic spokesman in this place. It started as a mirage but it has now turned into a chimera. Even at this stage the Prime Minister and the Treasurer, their feet planted firmly in mid air, are intending to march steadily forward clinging to an accord that is hardly there any more. The Australian Council of Trade Unions, which met in Melbourne yesterday, expressed its doubts at the Government's ability to maintain its wages policy. However, it is not just the ACTU that is expressing its doubts. Labor Premiers around the country are crying out for this Government to do something about the high tax policies that it is instituting. They are well aware of the lack of popularity of certain of the taxes, particularly the fringe benefits tax, and they are asking the Government to do something about them.

With great fanfare the Prime Minister announced the floating of the dollar. He was more for free enterprise than the conservative parties in Australia. He really had what is known in the business as a dirty float. He floated the dollar only against the American dollar. He did not float it against all of the other currencies. For a while things looked well for the dollar, although it was going down, simply because the American dollar was going down all the time. However, compared with other currencies such as the pound sterling, the deutschemark and the yen, our dollar was showing a much worse performance than it was against the American dollar. When the Prime Minister tacked his colours to the mast and announced his decision on the MX missile, immediately our trading partners lost confidence in this country and the dollar started to plummet.

Our overseas debt is mounting. One of the most startling figures I heard during the debate this afternoon was that we are going down the gurgler to the tune of $26,000 a minute. I was trying to calculate just how far down the gurgler we had gone during this debate. A figure amounting to as much money as a chap would earn in a year is being lost every minute by the Government. I found that startling. The die is cast. Taxes have been increased; the tax cuts have been deferred. Let us compare that with what is happening in, say the United States, which also has a record deficit. The US policy is for personal income tax cuts; it is cutting personal income tax to around 15 per cent. That will create an enormous boom almost immediately, and the United States will take off while Australia keeps going down the tube because we do not have the incentive to work.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what the economic forecasters say in the United States. You know that.

—The Leader of the Government in the Senate interrupts. Let me explain it simply to him. Anything the Government wants less of it taxes; anything it wants more of it subsidises. If it wants less work and less profitability and less success in the country-tax it. That is what the Government is doing. It is taxing the incentive out of anybody who wants to earn a profit, make a success and make the country a success. Interest rates are going up. Increased unemployment will be one of the results of this Budget. Of course, when the unemployed go on the dole, the Government's expenditure will be increased, and that will feed back into higher inflation. The Government is heaping problem upon problem on itself and it cannot recover from its present situation. It is headed for disaster, and I think people now know about this and are concerned about it. There is a loss of confidence in the country, and hence this motion has been moved in the Senate today.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact that sales taxes have risen will increase costs for every pensioner. They get no relief from sales tax; they have to buy on the ordinary open market. Pension rises have been deferred, and so with the increase in sales taxes pensioners will be a lot worse off. One item that has not been mentioned in the debate this afternoon-I mention it now only briefly because I will deal with it in greater detail when I speak on the Budget-is the continuation of Medicare and bulk billing. This has locked us into another situation which is bleeding the country white; it is encouraging over utilisation and overservicing. Medicare now has a nickname in the community. It is called Mediqueue, because of the huge queues that are being created around the country as a result of not only bulk billing-hordes of people are encouraged to see medical practitioners plus there is the new entrepreneurial medicine-but also the shortages of beds and nurses. Literally thousands of beds are missing from the number required in Australia today. Thus there are huge delays for operative surgery that should be planned, there is nursing unrest, and doctors are pulling out en bloc from bulk billing in various areas of the country. Just recently in my area of the Gold Coast doctors decided to cut out bulk billing, and I think we will see more of this. The Government should realise that what it has planned with Medicare is an economic disaster. It has nothing whatsoever to do with health; it has to do with government control and is a costly exercise that we will have to move heaven and earth to remove from the country at some time.

Yesterday we heard from Senator Walsh, Senator Button and Senator Grimes in the Senate that never was there a better climate for exporters in farming and rural industries than at the moment because of the devaluation of the Australian dollar. Even though the devaluation has been massive, it has already been offset by the huge increases in costs that are required to produce goods. Of course these costs-the cost of buying any equipment needed from overseas, increases in wages and increases in taxes-are made worse by inflation.

Yesterday, Senator Collard was ridiculed when he mentioned the unemployment in rural areas because of the application of the fringe benefits tax. One would be so ridiculed only by those who have not been out in the farm communities and seen that farmers have had to put people off. That tax is creating unemployment. It is making the problem worse for the Government because it has to pay the dole to those unemployed people. I am sure that the fringe benefits tax will be the Inchcape Rock that the Government hits.

Fringe benefits arose only because tax levels were too high. They were a way by which people could obtain relief from high taxation. Undoubtedly some rorts crept into the system but, instead of reducing taxes, the Government is taxing fringe benefits. It is taxing those benefits in the hands of the employer, not in the hands of the person receiving the benefit. In other words, it is the wrong way up. It is the wrong thing to do. A reduction in taxes will create the prosperity that will get the Government out of the hole it is in. The Government cannot see that, so it is headed for disaster.

The work practices that have been mentioned this afternoon are leading us to a new era in conciliation and arbitration. Employers are learning that they can use the conciliation side of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Every time that approach has been used recently, employers have been successful and union banditry has been brought to heel. I am sure that no one is against the trade unionism that looks for better wages and conditions but, when it comes to union banditry, that must be stomped on.

We have a beautiful big country with few people and huge resources. It has enormous manufacturing potential that has not been yet realised, and enormous technological potential. I hate to see this country being brought to its knees by the Government's policy. I hope that the people of Australia will get the chance soon to get rid of this Government and its policies and that we can return to some economic sanity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Historically, it seems to take about three years for a Labor Government to reduce Australia to economic ruin.
—Oh, for goodness sake!

—Remember Scullin? The honourable senator would remember him. Remember Whitlam? The honourable senator would certainly remember him. Now there is Hawke. It is interesting that, only a few weeks ago, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was closely involved in a plan to bring another country-in that case, South Africa-to economic ruin. I suppose that that was appropriate because, after all, he is an expert.

SPEECH.PARA: Whitlam did lasting damage in another way. What happened during the Whitlam years-years which, I am sure, future generations will see as a watershed in Australian society-was that it persuaded the Australian people that, if they wanted better standards, the way to achieve them was not, as in the past, to work a bit harder or to install better equipment but to organise and scream for the Government to provide them and at the same time to rubbish anyone who wanted to help voluntarily. As I said, this has done lasting harm to the attitudes of the Australian community.

The demolition job done by the Hawke Government has been very thorough. For the last 50 years, our national wealth had been growing steadily, but three years of Hawke Government rule have halved our national wealth. To put it another way, when the Hawke Labor Government came to power, average weekly earnings of an Australian were slightly higher than those of the Japanese; now they are less than half. The Government clearly does not know what to do. Its motto seems to be: `Now that we have lost sight of our objectives, we must redouble our efforts'.

Not all the blame for our present economic problems can be laid at the feet of the Prime Minister. Our terms of trade have deteriorated sharply-something which the Government has been quick to point out. Actually, during the first year of the Hawke Government's term of office, our terms of trade improved. I did not hear the Government then disclaiming responsibility for the economic recovery, particularly as it was assisted dramatically by the breaking of the drought and the benefits of the Fraser Government's wage pause. When things go wrong, the Prime Minister is very quick to blame others. Over the last three years, our economy has been declining and the Government has not been taking proper and timely measures.

There is no inherent reason why an Australian worker in, say, a General Motors-Holden's car plant in Melbourne should have a much higher standard of living than a Korean worker building a car at a General Motors plant in Korea. The reason for our higher standard of living has been our primary exports and our mineral wealth, but with the falling terms of trade these industries can no longer support us in the style to which we have become accustomed. We desperately need our manufacturing sector to become competitive by international standards, both to provide us with exports and to replace imports. During the reign of the Hawke Government, we have borrowed $50,000 million overseas-$1,000 million a month-and we have little to show for it, certainly not in improvements in the plant and equipment on which an improved manufacturing performance depends. In fact, in the last three quarters, investment in manufacturing plant and equipment has declined, and I note that the Budget predicts that it will continue to decline. We have not yet started to tackle our problems, and the appalling lack of leadership by this disastrous Government is mainly responsible for that.

I get sick and tired of hearing the Prime Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) prattling on about our internal economy going well and saying that it is only the external economy that is in trouble. That is like a family which has suffered a sharp drop in income carrying on spending as it was before and saying cheerfully: `Our internal economy is going well. We are spending more than anyone else in the street'. So it may be, until the hire purchase bills start coming in. The bills for this Government are coming in now.

It is disgraceful that, after four years of economic growth-funded by overseas borrowings on which we will have to pay interest for many years-we still have a budget deficit. Such years of growth should have enabled a competent, sensible Government to be budgeting for a surplus, which would do a great deal to improve our economic situation. The Hawke Government has been recklessly extravagant. New programs introduced by it will cost us $5,400 million in 1986-87-new programs introduced at a time when the economic crisis facing Australia was becoming obvious. If the Government had been sensible enough not to introduce those new programs, we would not have a deficit at all. Delay in tackling problems-or, like this incompetent Government, refusing to admit that they exist-always makes the cure more painful, as we are all finding out now.

As for all this silly talk about the world's greatest Treasurer, Mr Keating has presided over the greatest self-inflicted economic catastrophe in our history at a time when the world economy is prosperous. By the way, other winners of Euromoney's Finance Minister of the Year have been: 1981, Turkey; 1982, Singapore; 1983, Mexico; and 1985, New Zealand. It seems to be an award for countries that are getting, through mismanagement, into diabolical economic trouble.

There is nothing wrong with borrowing overseas if it is done to increase one's efficiency and in the expectation of a return, but that has not been what our borrowing under the Hawke regime has been doing. Imagine what Taiwan, South Korea, Singapore or Japan would have done with $50,000 million borrowed overseas. We have frittered it away in wasteful expenditure, living beyond our means. The world does not owe us a living. We must earn it. If we want to maintain our living standards, we must improve the efficiency of our manufacturing sector. That will require years of sustained effort, and this recklessly incompetent Government has wasted the last three years.

The fall in the value of the Australian dollar has opened many opportunities for our manufacturing sector to become more competitive. Why is it so slow in taking up these opportunities? Part of the reason is the legacy of the old protection system when a manufacturer, if faced with heavy competition from overseas, rather than investing in new plant and equipment to make himself more efficient or resisting unreasonable union demands, would find it much easier to go to the Government to get a tariff slapped on the importer to put him out of business. These same manufacturers, with the overseas competitors now hobbled by the falling dollar, are now relaxing and thinking that they have never had it so good. We should waste no sympathy on these employers, but there are many others who would like to exploit the situation. Well, why do they not do so? The first and most obvious reason is interest rates which, since the Budget, are now going up and not down. If one is going to make an investment, interest rates are critical. Manufacturers probably do not get the equipment for some time and expect to have it in operation for many years. If the interest rates payable on the capital investment are excessive, they just cannot afford to invest.

Our interest rates are much higher than almost anyone else's. The Government must get the interest rates down, both by improving the credibility of its economic management, thus reducing the necessity for the Reserve Bank of Australia to prop up the Australian dollar, but more particularly by reducing the inflation rate, which directly affects the interest rate. Without lowered interest rates we will not get the essential investment in manufacturing plant and equipment--

TALK.START.PARA: —But you need an after tax return, don't you?

—Yes, I will come to other factors. The second worry-the after tax return is involved in this-is the concern over the wages outcome. The present President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Mr Crean, has said that the accord gives certainty to wages outcomes. I suppose it does, but it is a certainty that, locked by the accord into high inflation and high wage increases, we will become less and less competitive. Look at our inflation rate. Our inflation rate is about 8 per cent, compared with inflation rates of 1.6 per cent in the United States of America, 3 per cent in Britain, 1 per cent in Japan and a negative inflation rate in West Germany. Our inflation rate is 8 per cent, which the accord continues to build into wages, and the wages build into inflation.
—Lower than the last six years of your Government.

—This is a very different economic situation. The great objection we have with this Government is that it has not modified its behaviour to fit the economic realities that are now facing us. That is the indictment of this Government. What we are going on with in the circumstances we are facing is economic suicide. We must greatly improve our productivity and eliminate the many restrictive practices which limit our efficiency. We must also work a bit harder. It is absurd to think that we can compete in a world which does not owe us a living when we work for 35, 36 or perhaps 38 hours while others work for 44 hours, with equipment at least as efficient as ours. If we want a decent standard of living in this real world, we can no longer rely on the primary producers and the mineral exporters to provide it for us. We must work for it ourselves.

SPEECH.PARA: This change of attitude will take time, and in the meantime we have an immediate very difficult problem. The spending power of the Australian community, which is largely determined by ourselves, is out of balance with our export income and our import replacement capabilities. The consequence is that we are sucking in imports at $1,000m a month. Until we can build up a more efficient and competitive manufacturing sector, which will take time, we must restrain incomes inside this country. At the very least, we need a wages freeze. Singapore, which has much less serious economic problems than we have, has accepted a 12 per cent wages cut. If we want to work ourselves out of this crisis, we must show restraint and co-operation. We must get away from the confrontational attitude between management and unions, between them and us, and realise that we are all in it together. We must be prepared to re-examine the sorts of things we could do when we were rich but which we cannot afford to do now when we are trying to be competitive-things such as holiday pay loadings, phoney sickies and four weeks annual holidays-other countries get two weeks-more public holidays than a South American republic, corrupt and recklessly extravagant workers compensation, absurd penalty rates. All these sorts of things we could afford when we were rich but we can no longer afford now because they damage our international competitiveness and impose excessive on-costs on the employment of labour.

Madam Acting Deputy President, can you imagine happening here what recently occurred in the copper mining industry in America? In the face of a crisis in copper prices, the miners accepted cuts of up to $4 an hour off existing wages, agreed to no rises at all for the next three years and gave up many long-established restrictive practices. Can you imagine that there? But why not? It is the sort of thing we have to do, particularly in the manufacturing sector, if we are to survive. The trouble is that our unions are not in the business of preserving or increasing job opportunities by increasing efficiency and competitiveness. Too many of them concentrate on preserving jobs by restrictive practices and by feather-bedding. Such things are economically disastrous and are things we can no longer afford.

We must involve both workers and management in the success of their enterprises. Other countries have done it. Why not us? Of course, we are hamstrung by an absurd legalistic and centralised arbitration system. It is not even an Australian invention, by the way; we imported it from New Zealand. We must have one of the worst industrial relations and wage fixing systems in the world. Other countries look at it with astonishment and contempt, yet we seem to regard it as normal and unchangeable. Above all, we must improve our productivity. I am sure that everyone in the Senate could name many absurd restrictive practices which are deliberately designed to reduce productivity. We can no longer afford such absurdities. A mining company in Western Australia recently claimed that there were more than 200 outdated and damaging restrictive practices, and such practices are common throughout our industry. I will give just one example of the sort of thing I mean. In Melbourne, a wharf container crane unloads 12.4 containers an hour. An identical piece of equipment in Singapore unloads 23.8 containers an hour and in Japan it unloads 26.7 containers, but in Melbourne 12.4. We can no longer afford such restrictive practices and deliberate go slows because the world does not owe us a living; we must earn it.

Such fundamental changes of attitude will require highly skilled leadership. This is one thing which this Government and the Prime Minister, in particular, seem incapable of providing. Outside observers thought us insane when straight after the Prime Minister's address to the nation on the economic situation-a pathetic speech, I thought-we granted ourselves a 2.3 per cent pay rise and then started a commotion for a further 3 per cent pay rise by way of a superannuation scheme. All this was applauded by the Prime Minister, who had just made his speech on the economic crisis. Other countries think we are just plain insane. We have a situation where the President of the ACTU refuses even to discuss whether at this time the country can afford a 3 per cent superannuation scheme which, by the way, is not a superannuation scheme; it is a deferred pay scheme. The President of the Public Service Association refuses even to discuss whether we can afford to continue to pay public servants more pay when they are on holidays than when they are at work. These are the sorts of things we must discuss. If we are going to direct the Australian public's attention to them, and do something about them-the Prime Minister is constantly addressing problems but I wish he would do something about them-we will require strong and sustained leadership.

I do not know whether honourable senators remember that, during the Prime Minister's address to the nation on the economy, he swivelled his chair through 90 degrees, fixed his eyes sternly on the new tele-prompter and said:
I will not shirk the hard decisions that are necessary . . . I would rather risk electoral defeat than take the soft options.

That will be a change. The one thing this Prime Minister has shown himself incapable of doing is taking tough decisions. Remember the MX missile fiasco, which did great harm to our international credibility? As soon as the strain came on the Prime Minister buckled and sold his Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) down the river. Remember the fuss over the assets test? As soon as the strain came on the Prime Minister buckled and sold Senator Grimes down the river. Remember the tax reform fiasco? As soon as the strain came on the Prime Minister buckled and sold the Treasurer (Mr Keating) down the river.

Honourable senators must not think that the recent Budget is an indication of prime ministerial leadership. He was dragged kicking and screaming to take decisions that should have been taken two years or more ago. Later in this session we will be debating whether the assumptions upon which the Budget are based are valid, whether the Government restraint is sufficient, whether the encouragement of productivity is adequate and whether the burdens are being fairly shared. But the hardships imposed by this Budget are caused by the intolerable delay of the Government in dealing with the obviously deteriorating economic situation. Of course we do not expect the Prime Minister to provide business guidance. Remember the ACTU Bourke's store, ACTU-Solo Enterprises Pty Ltd, ACTU Travel and 11 more, all, not surprisingly, now either broke or wound up. But even if the Prime Minister cannot provide business leadership he should at least be able to provide general leadership to the nation. The Prime Minister is now talking about the economic crisis facing Australia as being the equivalent of war. I agree with him. Our danger in a different field is as great as that in 1940 when Britain faced Hitler. Our problem is that we have as a Prime Minister a Neville Chamberlain, not a Churchill. There is even the same sort of paper, `Peace for our Time', as Chamberlain brought back from Munich, but Mr Hawke calls it `The Accord'. The Prime Minister seems temperamentally incapable of providing the essential leadership we need to get us out of our economic crisis because he is a manipulator, not a leader, and if he cannot lead he should go.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before this debate on the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry (Appeal) Bill was adjourned I had raised the question of the comments of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) about what would happen to material provided to the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry once that Commission ceased to exist.
