I am grateful to the Minister representing the Attorney-General, the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans), for responding by way of lengthy interjection and providing an assurance, which I think was repeated at Question Time, that this information would be provided back to the suppliers of that information or referred to instrumentalities concerned with the prosecution of those people who had committed offences in one way or another. I had at the time said that it seemed to me that if this was happening-I accept the Minister's assurance that in his view it would be happening and I do not seek to deny that-I would seek to have enshrined in legislation the requirement that it happen. It seems to me quite improper, and I said so at the time, that the Minister should, on the basis of that kind of undertaking on his part, expect the Senate to go along quite happily with a situation which is clearly not properly resolved nor enshrined in legislation. His undertaking has no force and there is nothing about which the Opposition can take forceful measures if in fact that undertaking is not carried out.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst many of us may have total faith in Senator Gareth Evans, many would not share the same faith in the Attorney-General, who is not answerable to this place. I do not know to what extent Senator Evans was in fact the mouthpiece for Lionel Bowen in this matter, but Lionel Bowen did not say that last night, specifically and in the terms that Senator Evans gave today.
Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry (Repeal) Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —I think he meant to.
—He never said it in his second reading speech either; nor did Senator Evans.

—I take the point, Senator Durack. As I say to Senator Evans, whilst I have no difficulty with the point of view he expresses, I have great difficulty with the manner in which this Bill will be translated into reality. If Senator Evans thinks that Mr Bowen actually meant to do something, it seems to me that the only possible and realistic way he could translate his misdemeanour of forgetting into proper behaviour would be to enshrine something in legislation so that he will not forget to do it again. When the job has to be done then the Attorney-General will not forget to do it. As it is, he forgot to mention it. I trust that his memory will be jogged far better if in fact there is a bit of legislation telling him to do something, rather than relying on his memory to do it because his colleague in the Senate has committed him so to do. Nonetheless, I do have some concerns, having listened to Senator Evans before lunch and at Question Time, about what in fact this section of the existing legislation really does require because according to Mr Bowen the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry (Repeal) Bill contains provisions whereby matters or material before the Commission were to be handed back on request. Now that is on the request of the person supplying the information; it is not on the request, as I understand it, of the person to whom that information may be useful. I do not know whether Senator Evans will address his mind to that problem that I have. It does not appear to me to be clear either in what Senator Evans said or in what Mr Bowen meant to say yesterday but forgot to say.
—I would have at Question Time had your mob given me the chance. I am happy to do so now.

—I thank Senator Evans because it does seem to me that it is ludicrous that we have at this stage of the debate to ask him questions which go to the very heart of the matter, questions which were not adequately dealt with either by Mr Bowen-whether he forgot or not-or by Senator Evans in his second reading speech. We have already heard quite a bit of debate on the second reading and it is only when I raised these matters that Senator Evans started-
—I was always going to do this in reply, but your mob just kept talking all morning and you are still talking now.

—The point I am endeavouring to get through to the honourable senator is that he would have saved himself this trouble, firstly, if the Attorney-General had remembered, and secondly, if Senator Evans himself, in introducing the second reading speech, had in fact bothered to deal with something that was clearly a matter of major moment in the House of Representatives debate the previous night.
—I am but a mouthpiece of my Attorney.

—On one occasion he is a mouthpiece in respect of undertakings; on other matters he is not a mouthpiece. That puts my mind at even greater uncertainty about whether or not the undertaking given by Senator Evans is one that relates to the Attorney-General himself. I am overjoyed that that significant point will be resolved, but at the inappropriate time of the rounding up of the debate rather than at the appropriate time of the second reading speech of the Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned also at section 34 of the original legislation, the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry Act, which states that the Commission may communicate information where in the course of its inquiry there might be a suggestion of the commission of an offence. The word `may' in this circumstance disturbs me for one very good reason. At this preliminary stage of the inquiry the Commission has received so much information that it has not had an opportunity to examine it with any degree of thoroughness. For example, the report of the Commission to Parliament said in paragraph 6:
Counsel assisting the Commission estimate that the hearing of evidence on all present allegations, including cross-examination, up to the stage at which the Judge might be called upon-
that is excluding any suggestion of calling Mr Justice Murphy-
to give evidence would last at least four months, and possibly much longer.

The reason I stress that is that much information has not been effectively examined to establish whether or not, in Mr Lionel Bowen's terms, it is information which may provide evidence of the suggestion of the commission of an offence. At this preliminary stage of the Commission's examination there may be little indication that the information might provide a suggestion of the commission of an offence. Four months inquiry is required by this Commission before it will even be in a position to cross-examine the judge. Yet here we have a situation--

TALK.START.PARA: —That was not our intention.
—Whatever your intention was--
—Our intention, not mine.

—Lionel Bowen's intention, apparently, was to tell us the truth about this matter last night and he failed to do so. There is a great slip between intention and realisation in this place. What concerns me is that a lot of material, which will require, according to the Commission, four months of examination before it even gets to the stage where it wants to cross-examine the judge, may well not be at a stage where it adequately provides any suggestion of the commission of an offence. But after four months there may well be a mass of material, if this inquiry were permitted to continue, of major relevance relating to the commission of an offence, not relating to the judge at all. I am not concerned about that; I am concerned about the third parties. This examination bears so heavily on the possibility of commissions of offences by third parties, yet the possibility of inquiring into that is now being destroyed by destroying this inquiry. The Act clearly states that the Commission may communicate information where in the course of its inquiry there might be the suggestion of the commission of an offence.

SPEECH.PARA: What I am saying is that if Senator Georges or anyone else wishes to cover up the consequences for, for example, the right wing machine of the Australian Labor Party in New South Wales, or whoever else may be involved in these matters, so be it. The essential point is that at this stage the Commission is not in an adequate position to be able to tell whether this material might include the suggestion of the commission of an offence and on that ground will not have the right to communicate it to other authorities, because the Act says `the Commission may'. It is under no compulsion to communicate information, but it may if there is a suggestion.

It seems to me that there is a real need for a requirement for this information to be required to be transferred to appropriate bodies, if it is the intention of the Government, with the support of the Australian Democrats, to close off this inquiry and prevent it from being continued and to bury this mountain of material. As the shadow Attorney-General, Mr Spender, said in the other place, this Bill sets up what the Attorney-General has called an exclusive code which is designed to bury in perpetuity any material before the Commission of Inquiry in any way relating to the conduct of Mr Justice Murphy and has the effect of denying access to the material in perpetuity, even if it is directly relevant to the proof of a criminal offence against some third person.

Senator Evans has outlined that where the person providing information requests-the word `requests' was used by Lionel Bowen-its return, that situation does not obtain. I put to Senator Evans that it depends on that request. I will deal also with clause 7, under which the Presiding Officers jointly have the exclusive right to the possession of any document that was in the possession of the Commission immediately before the commencement of the clause as a law. That refers to `any document', so there may be documents of major significance-who knows-which will be buried in perpetuity under this situation. As Mr Spender pointed out, an A class document is defined as meaning a document that contains material relating to the conduct of the Hon. Lionel Keith Murphy. It does not say `adversely reflecting on the conduct of Lionel Keith Murphy'; it says `relating', which means relating in any way, good or bad, even if the way in which it relates is purely in passing and even though it contains material directly relevant to the proof of criminal activities by some third person. Therefore, so long as the document falls within the description of a class A document it is to remain in the possession of the Presiding Officers, with the reservation which has been clearly stated by Senator Evans, the full meaning of which I look forward to hearing. The reason I am outlining in full my concerns--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is because you cannot stop yourself talking.

—If only the Attorney-General had started talking to the issues, we would not have had to continue in this way. I will concede to being obsessive about this, but for almost 20 years I was a journalist and I take a specific objection to governments which seek to intrude into the rights and duties of journalists to inquire into information which is properly the possession of the people.
—Nothing he says he is going to do will fix that up.

—I take that point. The issue seems to me to be that whether the information goes back to the people who supplied it or to instrumentalities which may be able to prosecute people, if for some reason a journalist becomes aware of that information which has gone back to the person who originally presented it, the journalist, even if briefed by that person, appears to me to be still subject--
—No. If you sit down, I will explain all this.

—I want the Minister to be aware of the proper concerns of which the Minister in the House of Representatives obviously was either not aware or for which he had an arrogant disregard because he did not answer them. These concerns are quite properly held. I certainly oppose any suggestion that this kind of information should be buried forever. If the Government wants to achieve the result which it now indicates it is seeking to achieve it should rewrite this legislation so that it does not appear to be acting in a draconian and offensive way which is aimed at imposing appalling penalties on people. It now tells us that it has no real intention of doing so and that it would not happen. Why on earth, if it would not happen, are there such penalties? Why is the matter being approached in this way? What is the purpose of the Government's appearing to heavy the media, to heavy everyone, in a way that does not exist in other matters.

SPEECH.PARA: I wonder why a new principle is established in this legislation which to my knowledge does not exist in other legislation. Perhaps Senator Durack can help me on that matter. I am not aware of similar examples of such penalties. Senator Evans too may be able to help me. If it is not the intention to single out people for special attack, I simply ask the Minister: For heavens sake, why not try again and do a little better this time? I ask the Attorney-General to do a little better this time and, while he is ramming things through and preventing adequate debate, to remember to tell the Parliament what the legislation is all about.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-The Opposition has done itself no credit by its performance today. It has demonstrated through a number of speakers all that same determination to impugn the character, the reputation and the integrity of Mr Justice Lionel Murphy that has been so evident for the whole 2 1/2 years that this matter has been afloat. It has also demonstrated a total lack of any human compassion in the response that has been made to the horrible reality that the man it has been persecuting is now dying. Those opposite pay no attention to the reality that the man is no longer in a physical condition to participate further in the inquiry and to defend himself against the allegations that have been made. They have paid no reasonable attention to the fact that he is in no physical condition to continue to sit on the Bench, although Mr Justice Murphy chose to reassert briefly his right to do so in a way that I think was both understandable and honourable.

SPEECH.PARA: Those opposite have chosen, in short, simply to ignore the reality that this man will very soon be dead. Everyone dealing with this very unhappy matter-the Government, the Presiding Officers and the commissioners of the Inquiry-had hoped that it would not really be necessary to put into the public domain precise details of Mr Justice Murphy's illness and condition, to state anything more than that he had a terminal illness and was unfit to proceed, without having to spell out the time frame involved, the probabilities of remission and so on. It became necessary to do so today through the tabling of the medical certificate by the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives because of the extraordinarily squalid contribution of a number of members of the Opposition who in the other place yesterday questioned the bona fides of this entire repeal legislation. It was questioned in an indirect, sneering kind of way by Opposition shadow Attorney-General Spender. It was questioned in a much more direct and quite contemptible way by Opposition member Aldred, who said at one point:

I suggest that the reason the inquiry has been closed down relates not so much to the purported state of health of Justice Murphy but more to the enormity of the material that has been put together by the Commission and the ramifications that flow from that . . .

That was the sort of snide, contemptible allegation that was permeating the entire debate yesterday in the House of Representatives. It was a snide set of responses that had to be put at rest, and I hope that it was put at rest by the medical certificate that was tabled this morning, which in stark and unequivocal terms makes it clear that Mr Justice Murphy's condition is indeed terminal. The time frame on any view is very short. By implication, the possibilities of remission are as small as they possibly can be in this sort of case. I seek leave to incorporate that medical certificate in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

Mr Justice Murphy is a 63 year old man whose symptoms, enlarged liver and chronic anaemia, suggested carcinoma of the colon. This was confirmed by X-ray examination of the bowel and by colonoscopy. The cancer has spread throughout the liver, as evidenced by clinical and ultrasound examination.

Carcinoma of the colon with diffuse liver involvement is a terminal disease. While it is difficult to prognosticate in any individual, the life expectancy for a patient suffering from this stage of colon cancer, without further treatment, is in the order of 3-9 months. Should chemotherapy be used, there is a limited (about 20%) prospect of prolonging his survival for a further period of months.
Mr Justice Murphy has been seen by the following specialists:
1. Professor William Doe,
Specialist Physician in Gastroenterology,
Department of Medicine and Clinical Science,
Woden Valley Hospital, Canberra
2. Mr Ray Hollings,
Specialist Colorectal Surgeon,
Royal North Shore Hospital,
Sydney
who concur with the above statement.
Rob Griffiths, MB BS (Mon), MRCP (UK),
46 Mugga Way,
Red Hill. Canberra.
1 August 1986

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a disgrace that we have to do it.

—Exactly, it is a disgrace. It demeans those who made it necessary for that course to be taken. But it was taken with the consent, and indeed at the request this morning, of His Honour Mr Justice Murphy because he was unhappy at any lingering impression that this whole matter could be a terrible, artificial attempt to create out of nothing an excuse for winding up the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: More could be said about Mr Justice Murphy's condition, certainly by those who have had some personal acquaintance with him recently, but I do not feel it appropriate to do so. I simply say that his condition is desperately serious and to question its seriousness is to demean the person so questioning. That leads me naturally to the question which occupied a good deal of the debate today, even if the question of Mr Justice Murphy's medical condition was not so prominent as in the other place. I refer to the timing of this measure and the haste with which the legislation allegedly was brought into the Parliament. Mr Justice Murphy clearly is unable, because of his present condition, to appear before the Commission to give evidence-not that that would even be required for something like four months, on the Commission's own account of its timetable-nor is he in a condition to follow the kind of evidence that would be given and to give appropriate instructions to counsel appearing for him so that they could cross-examine and carry on his defence effectively. The Commission has made it clear in paragraph 8 of its first report:
The prognosis of the medical certificate makes obvious the problems posed by this course.
The course to which it refers is the continuation of the Commission for the many more months which it says would be necessary because of the state of the material. It continues:
To continue hearings if the Judge were too ill to take part in them would be contrary to established practice and to natural justice.

I must say that I did not understand anyone in the Opposition contributing to this debate today to be in any way challenging that proposition that if someone is too ill to participate it is clearly inappropriate for the Commission to proceed.

TALK.START.PARA: —We did not challenge that. We said it was a matter for the Commission to handle.

—I acknowledged that nobody on the Opposition side challenged that, accepting the reality of the Commission's determination of that matter. If the disability being experienced by the judge were merely temporary, obviously something in the nature of an adjournment of the Commission's proceedings rather than their cessation would have been the appropriate course to follow, but it is manifestly clear that the disability in question is not temporary. It is for all practical purposes permanent. The illness is terminal, and in a very short time indeed His Honour Mr Justice Murphy will no longer be with us. On the Commission's own assessment, there is no prospect of its finishing its task before 30 September, the reporting date in the legislation, nor, on its present assessment of the material, before the end of March 1987.

SPEECH.PARA: Even if Lionel Murphy were to live that long he would not be able to participate by virtue of his condition, on any view of it, with or without some miraculous remission, so the matter cannot proceed. Under those circumstances it was manifestly pointless and, moreover, expensively pointless, for the Commission to stay on foot longer than was strictly necessary to wind up. Accordingly, this repeal legislation has been brought in at the first available parliamentary opportunity. It was the obvious and rational response, and it is not a response, I understand, that has been objected to by the commissioners.

As to whether this course is in accordance with His Honour Mr Justice Murphy's wishes-and we have had today an extraordinary series of bleatings by people suggesting that His Honour did not want the Commission terminated, that he wanted it to continue, and that it was some sordid motivation leading the Government against his wishes to wind it up-although there was some misunderstanding to that effect based on public comments made by well-intentioned counsel on Mr Justice Murphy's behalf, once it became apparent to him that because of his condition there was no possibility of his participating actively in the Commission's proceedings, much as he would like to be able to clear his name, he acknowledged that the only appropriate course was for the Commission to close. I will continue my remarks after the dinner suspension.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter to which I now turn is the means employed in winding up the Commission, and in particular the provisions in the legislation about the treatment of material accumulated by it. A number of quite extravagant and fanciful claims have been made about the intent and effect of the legislation in this respect. I think it is important now to try to sort them out.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation draws a distinction between class A and class B material. Most of the argument has been about class A material, which is material relating to the conduct of the Hon. Lionel Keith Murphy. Most of the argument has been about that, and I will come back to that in a moment. Class B document means a document containing material relating to the meaning of section 72 of the Constitution or any other matter, but not including a class A document. There has not been much argument about the class B material except for people suggesting that there is something inappropriate about vesting the custody of that material in the Presiding Officers. I simply say that it is in the view of the Government obviously appropriate that this material be accessible on ordinary freedom of information type principles. It is especially appropriate that the section 72 material-whatever one thinks of its worth-be open to scrutiny. This is a parliamentary commission that has been established and it is further appropriate that the custody of its material be vested in the Presiding Officers, who represent, of course in their persons-very able persons at the moment-this particular parliamentary institution, and that access to the material be regulated at their discretion in accordance with proper principles. It may be thought and may have been thought appropriate that some classes of this material could more tactfully or properly have not been brought into the public domain at least until such time as Mr Justice Murphy's illness has run its course. It is obvious that the release of the opinions, particularly in the terms in which they appear, by the judges about section 72 will generate another debate now about the various allegations that have been made about Mr Justice Murphy in the past, and whether they were such as to justify his removal from the Bench. We had an earful of that today, in particular from Senator Lewis. I suspect that there will be many more.

TALK.START.PARA: —You were just dead wrong; that is all.

—When I get impressed by opinions of the kind that have been produced by those judges and weigh them against the opinions of previous Solicitors-General and so on I have to make my own judgment about it. The argument is by no means over yet, but it is not an argument we need to have now. I simply make the point that had there been any serious commitment to an element of compassion on the other side in its approach to this matter rather than cheap point scoring it might have been appropriate for some consultation to have taken place between the Presiding Officers and the party leaders with a view to that material being put into the public domain as soon as it was appropriate, but with that course perhaps being deferred for some little period. In any event that did not happen. For one reason or another, the material found its way into the public domain today, and so be it. There is nothing much left then apart from, I suppose, some administrative documentation, if anyone is interested in that, that satisfies the description of class B documents.

SPEECH.PARA: The argument is really about class A material, that which relates to the conduct of Mr Justice Murphy. It is true that the Bill as it has been drafted prohibits certain kinds of disclosure of Commission documents in a very comprehensive way. The obvious objective, if we need to go back to basics on this, is to prevent the kind of grotesque unfairness to Lionel Murphy and his family that would flow from untested allegations about any aspect of his life-public life, private life, on the Bench, in politics, or before all that over the last 60-odd years. There would be an obvious unfairness in that untested material getting unhindered into the public domain for use in the kind of way that we know so many people, institutions, organisations and journals are anxious to use it. It has not been the subject of any investigation at this stage. It is simply in the nature of untested allegations. It has not been reinforced by any oral evidence at all put to the Commission. It has not been subjected, as I said, to any testing in the Commission or anywhere else.

This may be a unique provision-and I will indicate the qualifications to the way in which it operates-and to the extent that it is a uniquely far-reaching non-disclosure provision supported by vigorous sanctions it must be appreciated that the circumstances in which this legislation is being drafted are themselves unique. There has never been, in the history of this country, anything like this Commission established before. Never has there been a commission, whether a parliamentary commission, a royal commission or any other kind of committee of inquiry, established to inquire in a completely general and completely open ended way into the conduct and the behaviour over an unspecified period of years, in an unspecified array of roles and offices, of a single individual. It is unique that an individual should be exposed to that kind of treatment, that kind of examination, that kind of scrutiny, and it is uniquely appropriate under those circumstances that we be uniquely sensitive to the implications of that material as it bears upon that individual getting, unhindered, untrammelled, without significant limitation, into the public domain.

It was not a matter of destroying the material, though the Democrats continue to display some affection for that particular solution and appropriate as it may be for the quality of some of that material, as it undoubtedly will be. That is obviously not on if one maintains any sense of history. It is appropriate that basic archival rules apply to this and that in 30 years time the basic ground rules for Commonwealth documentation generally apply, subject to such exemptions as apply to this sort of material, which can properly be administered by the Presiding Officers. It was an oversight in the drafting to leave it completely open ended. It was not the intention really to do that forever. It was appropriate that archival rules apply, and an amendment relating to that has been circulated, We can debate that later on.

Nor was it a matter of in any way burying material that had any law enforcement relevance, not only in relation to the judge but also to other people. It was not a matter of trying in any way to suppress allegations that people made to the Commission and may themselves want to make again, either in the public domain if they are prepared to risk the law of defamation, to the extent that it continues to apply-which will not be, regrettably, very much longer in the case of Lionel Murphy himself-or to the extent that they want to make such allegations to law enforcement agencies of various kinds. If, for example, the Age newspaper has made-again, I do not know whether it has or it has not-along with other public journals, the National Times and so on, the kinds of allegations it has been making over the last 2 1/2 years, or if it wants to put them on to the public record with such documentary evidence as it put to the Commission, there is nothing in either the terms of the present Act or the repeal Bill which will prohibit the originator of such material using it again. It is just a matter of the proper construction of clause 8 of the Bill before us. We can talk more about that at the Committee stage if honourable senators want to. It is only material derived from documentary material before the Commission that is prohibited from going back into the public domain. It is not that documentary material itself to the extent that it is available to its originators.

Could I focus more closely than I had time to do in Question Time today, or than some people thought was appropriate to do then, to explain just what the situation is about the material so far as law enforcement agencies are concerned. Let me repeat what I said. The Commission, I was advised, was in the process of returning materials made available to it by the law enforcement agencies. Since Question Time today I have been further advised that all law enforcement agencies that have supplied documentary material to the Commission have requested their material back and all requests have already been met. The material has been returned. Copies of some of this material are still held, however, on Commission files. As such it is subject, in that capacity, to the rigorous non-disclosure rules that are here contained in the Bill. Material received from other persons, not from law enforcement agencies, who have requested the return of that material is being returned. I am advised by the Commission that no copies of that material are being kept. Material not requested is not being returned. That is consistent with the terms of section 18 (2) of the present Act, which makes the power of the Commission to return material contingent on such a request. I think that answers the point made about that.

So far as the Commission's capacity itself to pass on to law enforcement agencies material not originated from such agencies, but perhaps turning up in the course of documentary submissions made by other people, the Commission has the capacity under section 34 of the present Act to communicate such as it thinks appropriate of that material to law enforcement agencies. Those law enforcement agencies are set out and include the Attorneys-General of the Commonwealth and the States, the National Crime Authority and the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police or of a police force of a State or Territory.

Material which, in the view of the Commission, satisfies that description is, as I have indicated, being passed-if it has not already been passed now-to the National Crime Authority. Therefore, there simply is no conceivable question of any kind of cover-up of the sort that has been alleged. Of course it is in the interests of justice and public policy and everything else that if material should have turned up in the course of this extraordinary saga, which does bear upon possible criminal behaviour by third persons, then of course it ought to be investigated and properly dealt with and, of course, it will be dealt with-unless honourable senators opposite want to challenge the integrity not only of the Government on this matter but also of the three Commissioners who have been subjected to so much praise during the course of this whole argument. Of course such material will be returned. There will be no mechanical problems about that occurring. As I indicated at Question Time today and as I repeat, the Bill will not formally be presented for assent and, as such, the repealing Bill come into force until around the middle of next week, by which time it has been indicated to the Government by the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry the processes that are in train for dealing with the documentary material will be complete.

For the sake of completion might I just respond now to the other question asked of me today as to whether I could inform the Senate of the situation in relation to informants to the Commission-other than informants from law enforcement agencies. I was asked whether they are prevented from taking any allegations they may wish to make to any law enforcement agency or to the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, if they believe that some national security matter is involved, or whether such material is, as some people keep asking, going to be forever buried by virtue of the operation of the clauses of this Bill. I say in relation to this that no, there is no inhibition on individuals dealing with their own material and allegations in this way. Nor, as a corollary to that, are such agencies as ASIO or anybody else, should that be relevant, prevented from using that material if it proves to have some relevance. All that the Bill now before us does is to preserve the confidentiality of the material the Commission had immediately before winding up. The Commission would punish disclosure only of material that is derived from the material in the Commission's possession.

Clause 5 of the Bill, which I gather is the subject of some concern also, has been written in such a way-it may even be unnecessary given the fact that there was no oral evidence before the Commission-that it has some potential effect of narrowing the scope of section 16 of the parent Act so that it applies only to documents created for the purposes of the Commission. It would not apply in any way to inhibit the admissibility in other proceedings of other kinds of documents not created for the purposes of the Commission, such as the report of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking and the Age tapes or an allegation an informant might make to a law enforcement agency. As I said, no oral testimony has been taken by the Commission; so use of that kind of testimony, to the extent that that basically is what clause 5 is about, is in no way affected by the operation of that clause.

I think that answers just about every question that has now been raised about the treatment of that material. However, so far as the Age tapes are concerned I cannot forbear in winding up from reminding Senator Puplick in particular, who gave this ferret a run for the umpteenth time, of what the bi-partisan all-party report of that first Senate Select Committee on the Conduct of a Judge in August 1984 said of that material, on the assumption that it might eventually prove to have some authenticity in whole or part. What the members of that Committee said unanimously-I remind the Senate that both Senator Durack and Senator Lewis were members of that Committee-at the conclusion of the Committee was:

. . . even if the tape recording is a complete and unaltered record of the conversation as it actually took place, such conversation contains nothing which could amount to, or provide evidence of, any misbehaviour on the part of the judge, whatever interpretation of misbehaviour under section 72 of the Constitution is accepted.

That is the kind of conclusion that was drawn, and properly drawn, by the Senate Committee in regard to that material. Let us hear no more of the Age tapes and the great undisclosed mysteries that continue to lurk beneath them so far as the judge or, for that matter, it seems just about anyone else is concerned. The Senate has passed upon this question and whatever interpretation we might be minded to accept of section 72 in the light of the further consideration of it, it will not change the course of history so far as our perception of his Honour Mr Justice Murphy is concerned.

It is not time now to review, much as I am tempted to do so, the whole course of the campaign that has been so maliciously waged against Lionel Murphy over the last two and a half years and against, for that matter, the Government-not to mention myself in particular-for endeavouring to continue to apply some kinds of consistent principles about fairness and justice and about the way in which individuals are treated to ensure that an individual and his family are not subjected to inquisition and not subjected to trial, criminal or otherwise, simply because allegations are made.

Let me finish where I began: Surely this is a time at last for some compassion for this man who is, whatever one thinks of the contribution he has made over the years, whatever one thinks of his character, a man who has made a gigantic contribution to the life of this nation, a man who has suffered unmercifully as a result of the pressures that have been placed on him, not least by the behaviour of those in this chamber, and a man who is now dying. For God's sake can we not let him and this issue now rest in peace.
Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 to 4-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two general observations that I wish to make in relation to this Bill. The first and most serious and rather distressing one is that I feel that I must reply to the observations made by Senator Gareth Evans during this debate and particularly in his peroration.
—You are out of order.

—Okay, we will hear from Senator Georges as well if he wants to participate in this debate. At the beginning of my speech in opening the debate on the second reading of the Bill on behalf of the Opposition I went to some lengths to point out that we--
—You are out of order.
—Is the honourable senator taking a point of order? Does he want to shut me up?
—No.

—If not, the honourable senator should not waste my time. I went to some lengths to point out that in my view the Opposition was placed in a most invidious position by the Government in this matter. Having been through this debate, and speaking on behalf of some of my colleagues who expressed the same feeling, I felt it was most unfortunate that this Senate should have been put in the position by the Government-it is its responsibility-of debating this matter. There was absolutely no need for this legislation to be brought into this Parliament at this stage or even at all. The responsibility for this debate rests fairly and squarely on the Government, particularly, I suggest, on the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans), who is at the table. He has been trading on all the feelings of sympathy of honourable senators for Mr Justice Murphy. He is trading on those feelings to put us in a totally false position. I resent very bitterly not only the attempt that he has made to do so but also his constant reiteration of that matter. I do not propose to add any more to it.

SPEECH.PARA: The other general observation that I wish to make concerns the total inadequacy of the Government's handling of this matter. The Government has probably been very surprised by public reaction to its proposal in this legislation and to the terms and details of the legislation. Obviously it believed that it could, as I said, trade on public sympathy. It has done it unmercifully and, I believe, in a quite disgraceful way. That led it to believing that it could get away with murder with this legislation. That is literally what it has been about, but it has been caught out well and truly. If one were to read the Hansard record of the performance of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) yesterday in another place one would see very clearly what I mean. I do not propose to go over again the totally unseemly and unnecessary haste with which this legislation was brought in and the totally inadequate opportunities which the Opposition was given to consider the legislation and its position and reaction to it.

The Government knew perfectly well that in any program it laid down for the sittings of the Parliament the Opposition would be having a party meeting on Tuesday of each week. The Government had ample time to have the legislation made available to the Opposition so that the Opposition could process it in its ordinary course of shadow Cabinet and party room discussions. Despite the fact that the Government had made a decision a couple of weeks ago, it made no attempt to accommodate the Opposition. We were given some scrappy first draft of this Bill on Tuesday evening. It was only when the debate was called on in the House of Representatives yesterday morning at 10 o'clock that the final printed version of the Bill became available to the Opposition. I think that was about the time that my colleague the shadow Attorney-General was on his feet. We were expected to respond to this legislation in the House of Representatives yesterday and are expected to respond to it in the Senate today without having had any adequate opportunity to analyse the legislation.

Fortunately, because there is a vigilant Opposition and a vigilant free Press in this country, real efforts were made to examine the legislation and to detect its deficiencies. The Government was confronted this morning with an outcry, which it thoroughly deserved, from the Press about the cover-up aspects of the legislation and its draconian provisions to muzzle the Press, members of the Parliament and everybody within the Government's sights in regard to the material before the Commission. I feel that this is probably one of the most sorry episodes I have ever seen in this Parliament or that any of us are ever likely to see. The responsibility rests not with the Opposition but fairly and squarely with the Government, and particularly with Senator Evans and the Attorney-General.

The Government has replied to the second reading debate in the Senate. We have had a debate in the House of Representatives, before which there was very little opportunity for anybody to study the legislation. There was the second reading speech of the Attorney-General, who introduced the Bill, which made no reference whatsoever to what was going to happen to a whole lot of vital documents. In reply in the House of Representatives, the Attorney-General made some totally garbled and unintelligible comments which I think Senator Michael Baume tried to unravel at some stage in the debate here. I do not know whether the Attorney-General simply was not briefed properly, whether he cannot understand briefs or whether he could not care less, but I have never seen a more deplorable performance by a man who is the first law officer, a legal adviser of the Government and, into the bargain, the Deputy Prime Minister. He left everybody yesterday in a total state of confusion as to what on earth this Bill means.

The Bill is not well drafted, but we will go into that later in the Committee stage. The Attorney-General should at least have clearly explained what the Government's intentions were in relation to a whole lot of vital documents. He did not do so. The Bill was then introduced into the Senate last night by Senator Evans, who probably has a somewhat better grasp of legal matters, albeit a very academic one, and certainly has a better command of expression than the Attorney-General. One would have thought that Senator Evans, when he introduced this Bill, would at least have repaired the glaring deficiencies of the Attorney-General's speech in the House of Representatives. But not on your life! He introduced the Bill into the Senate last night in the same totally inadequate terms as those used by the Attorney-General. The Bill was brought on for debate first thing this morning.

There was another interesting little episode this morning when there were further attempts at suppression of reports by Senator Evans, a matter which we will go into later. But the fact is that it was only as a result of the probing of this legislation in the House of Representatives by the shadow Attorney-General and others, by the Press this morning, and in the debate here today which has further probed what the Government is about, that we finally got any effort by the Government to explain what it intended to do about a whole range of vital documents. That is the setting against which we go into this Committee debate. We go into the Committee debate having had every attempt by this Government not only to rush through this legislation and to get rid of the Commission but also to mislead the Parliament, the people and the Press about what the Government was about. The Government was hoping-there is only one interpretation-that no one would probe, that no one would see the point. It was hoping to suppress forever documents of vital importance to, if nothing else, the history of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —They could not do that; you know that.

—Of course the Government could do it. That is what this Bill does. Senator Georges does not know any more about it than the Attorney-General knows, I am sorry to say. The whole of the Labor benches are empty except for Senator Georges and Senator Evans. The Government and its supporters could not care less. They mouth a lot of stuff they do not believe in about freedom of information, academic freedom, and civil liberties-you name it. They are all bleeding hearts for these things-as long as it does not affect their mates; their little mates, their big mates, their middle mates or whatever. They are in this business to protect their mates at all costs.
—Regardless of principle.

—Regardless of principle. This Bill is the greatest example of that deplorable characteristic of the Labor Party and everybody who is a member of it. As far as I can see there is no one of principle in that Party whatever.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses agreed to.
Clause 5 (Statement made by witness not admissible in evidence).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 5, leave out sub-clause (1), insert the following sub-clause:

`(1) A statement or disclosure made, or a document produced, by a witness in the course of giving evidence before the Commission is not admissible in evidence against the witness in any civil or criminal proceedings in any court of the Commonwealth or of a State or Territory.'

This is not one of the most important amendments proposed by the Opposition. However, I believe that it is one which needs to be moved and passed because clause 5 as it stands is quite inadequate and unprincipled. The clause deals with evidence that has been given before the Commission. That is what Senator Evans says it is meant to mean. It refers to:

A statement or disclosure made, or a document produced, by a witness in the course of giving evidence before the Commission, or any information or document obtained as a direct or indirect consequence of the statement or disclosure or the production of the first-mentioned document . . .

The clause seems to me to be a bit mixed up. It is a good example of the very sloppy, inadequate drafting of the Bill. Senator Evans says that the clause applies only to actual evidence given before the Commission but that is, I think, a matter for some debate. According to Senator Evans, I gather, it does not matter now because in his view no evidence was given before the Commission. That may or may not be so; we do not know.

Clause 5 could be interpreted to prevent statements, documents, disclosures or information-pretty wide expressions have been given to the Commission in some shape or form-from ever being used. It states that such documents are `not admissible in evidence in any civil or criminal proceedings'. That is an extraordinarily wide prohibition and one which is simply not justified. It is quite at variance with other provisions in the parent Act and with all the rhetoric we have heard from Senator Evans as to how documents that belong to other law enforcement bodies or documents which have been generated within the Commission and which may be of relevance to other law enforcement bodies should be made available to them or given back to them. It is quite clear that if that provision is to take effect-the Government now says that that is intended-it may well be that much of that evidence should be available in a civil or criminal proceeding.

The normal principle in relation to royal commissions and other commissions of inquiry is that where people are obliged to give evidence and may or may not have privilege against self- incrimination, that evidence should not be used against them in any other subsequent proceeding; but evidence they give generally, which may not be against their interest or incriminate them in any way, should be available. There is no reason why it should not be available-in fact there is every reason why it should be available-in any other criminal or civil proceedings. As I have said, that is the rule generally in relation to commissions of inquiry.

This clause goes way beyond that, and it would stultify and negative other provisions of the existing legislation. The amendment to clause 5 which I have moved adopts the principle that the only prohibition is that evidence cannot be given against a person who has been forced to give evidence, statements, disclosures or information, as stated in this clause, to the Commission of Inquiry. Incidentally, the Commission of Inquiry does not protect any right of self- incrimination, so people may well have been forced to give evidence. Therefore, it is even more important that we should be able to give protection to people who have been required to give evidence. Apart from that circumstance, clearly evidence that has been given should be admissible in other proceedings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I interjected that Senator Durack was out of order. He had other means available to him by which he could have made a statement rather than making it at the Committee stage. I did not raise a point of order in case he thought I was endeavouring to gag him. However, if he had sought leave to make a statement I do not doubt that we would have given him leave. He also has the opportunity of speaking at the third reading stage without again opening up the second reading debate. At this stage I will confine my remarks to the matter immediately before us.

SPEECH.PARA: What troubles me about the Opposition's proposition is this: My understanding of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry we set up was that it had very narrow terms of reference. What worries me is that somehow the Commission took on a life of its own. Whether or not that was with the agreement of the Presiding Officers is not relevant. It certainly was not without the permission of this Parliament that the Commission should proceed as it did. It was not as though people were brought before the Commission to give evidence, as has been suggested by Senator Durack: That was his concern-that the evidence having been given ought not to be in a position of not being disclosed. What worries me is that the Commission took the unusual step of advertising without our permission for information from people in general on a very serious matter which we had delegated to it. It advertised for information in such a way that any person could come forward with unfounded allegations, scurrilous allegations, quite extraordinary allegations, and obtain the privilege of this Parliament for that information. Virtually what the Commission did was to extend to people in general a privilege to come forward and give information, and this is the sort of information that Senator Durack is endeavouring to free-quite untested allegations, scurrilous allegations, allegations of a nature that we have been familiar with over the past two years.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you know, George?

—I am saying that I know the background of some of the information and it is quite unfounded, scurrilous and vindictive, endeavouring to destroy. We have given assistance to that type of information being given, that type of activity. I cannot understand just how the Commission suddenly decided to take upon itself a further inquiry which, on its own admission and on its own request, would take another four or five months. Thus another chapter was opened in this sorry affair. In a way we are endeavouring to prevent that sort of information from getting further currency.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the Opposition has exaggerated. I feel that the Opposition has masked an attempt to continue the attacks that were levelled earlier. I am sorry to say that, but when a certain person in Queensland said `Pursue him to the end', that person was subjected to considerable and justifiable criticism. However, it seems to me that that person was not alone in that attitude. Hidden in what is happening here today is that sort of motive, a motive to pursue to the very end. I find that very difficult to accept.

It is clear to me that the intention of the legislation is to prevent this unfounded information which was sought by the Commission in a most extraordinary way from becoming available. Where else could a jurist find a situation where, when a person comes before a court-and the Commission of Inquiry was, in effect, a court-an advertisement is put before the public seeking information against the person? In this case that is exactly what happened. The Commission advertised for information.

TALK.START.PARA: —You voted for the legislation.

—I know, with considerable reservations at the time. I said at the time that the whole matter should have been brought to an end, but for some reason we did not bring it to an end and suddenly we find the matter extended in this way. Let us get back to the matter before the Committee. Senator Durack seems to think that information or proceedings or records can be hidden forever. They cannot because at some future date this Parliament may determine that we should release them. It is within the power of this Parliament to reverse legislation it has passed. So it is no use saying that this sort of information will be buried forever. In any case, the people who brought forward information to the Commission can, if they so desire, bring it forward elsewhere. But of course they are not game to do so. The information is unfounded; it is scurrilous and it is defamatory. How can they get that information out? They can do so by getting the cover of privilege, either before a Senate committee or before a special commission. To the eternal discredit of this Commission, it advertised for information against the person before it-someone whom it would have put upon the rack, using the information which it had so obtained.

SPEECH.PARA: We are party to these procedures. I am angry that the Senate has lent itself to these procedures and that the Presiding Officers have agreed to them. We suddenly find that special investigators have been appointed. On whose authority were they appointed to search for evidence to support information obtained by the Commission's advertising?

TALK.START.PARA: —Ask the Minister.
—I am asking the Senate in Committee.
—It is no good asking the Senate.

—I agree with Senator Durack. The matter should not have been the subject of any debate, and I am sorry that it is. It could lead to one making accusations in the heat of the moment which one may later regret. It would be far better to do what we wish to do as quickly as possible and allow this matter to pass. We are participating in a tragedy of classic proportions. A further chapter must unfold in this place. I am waiting to hear what will be said by those who attacked and those who ceased to come to the judge's defence. I am waiting to see just one further chapter unfold.

SPEECH.PARA: The whole episode has been to the Senate's discredit as it has pursued a person to the point where he has no further defence. His ability to fight back has been taken away from him, and I regret that. It should be of regret to the Committee that the person concerned cannot fight back to clear himself completely of these scurrilous allegations, which will have currency in the future no matter what the Parliament decides in this legislation. He is not able, because of the circumstances in which he finds himself, to fight back.

Recognising that the judge cannot fight back, we should never put him on the defensive, where he would seek to fight though he no longer had the strength to do so. Let us pass the Bill. Let us get rid of the wretched Commission which we set up and the three judges who suddenly have set themselves up to place a person further on the rack. Let us put an end to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am puzzled why the Opposition seeks to amend clause 5. I am even more bemused as to why the Government put clause 5 in the Bill in the first place. I was under the distinct impression, perhaps wrongly, that no witnesses have appeared before and no evidence has been given to the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry. I do not understand why we are worrying about who is, or who is not, protected as a consequence of a non-existent witness giving non-existent evidence before a still barely existing Commission. The Opposition has simply varied clause 5 (1) so that it deviates from section 16 of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry Act 1986, which set up the Commission of Inquiry, and fits in more with the normal protection for witnesses giving evidence before a royal commission. The Opposition wishes clause 5 (2) to remain in the Bill. But that does not seem to make sense or serve any point in the exercise if no witnesses have given evidence before the Commission. I hope that the Minister can say whether witnesses have given evidence before the Commission and, if not, why those who drafted the Bill inserted that clause in the first place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — Senator Haines is already proving herself to be a worthy successor to Senator Chipp. Armed with information which I gave her just two minutes ago, she has engaged in a grandstanding belt at the Government. I hope that that gets it out of her system and that we shall have a clear run for the rest of the Bill. There is no practical room for the application of clause 5, either in its Government version or in its Opposition version. I will accordingly suggest to the Committee that it vote against the clause. The reason is that clause 5 is premised on references to:

SPEECH.PARA: A statement or disclosure made, or a document produced, by a witness in the course of giving evidence before the Commission

As Senator Haines said, on the basis of information I just gave her, we found out only today that no witness had formally appeared before the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry to make a statement or to produce a document as a witness. Of course documents have been tendered to the Commission in the form of allegations, supporting evidence, and so on, but not in such a way that this clause would bite upon them. We were not to know that because it is a parliamentary commission of inquiry and the Executive Government does not go poking around in the internal affairs of parliamentary commissions. We have due and proper respect for the separation of powers and all those things. It was only when someone involved with the Commission saw the Bill-not much more recently than the Opposition has seen it, despite its yowls to that effect-that the Commission said that there was nothing on which this clause could bite because, as some may not have known, there had been no witnesses. I suggest that we can cut short what might otherwise have been a prolonged debate on the merits of admissibility clauses by simply voting for the removal of this provision.

TALK.START.PARA: —The comment I want to make relates to the matter raised by Senator Georges in his contribution. He sought to put upon all senators, in particular members of the Opposition, the fact that somehow it is to their discredit that we are dealing with repeal legislation. If anyone deserves censure for getting this Parliament into that position, it is the Government which refused to deal in a proper fashion from the outset with all the allegations against the judge. This Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry should not have been and would not have been necessary and this legislation would not have been presented to Parliament had the Government taken seriously and properly its obligations to clear up at an earlier stage the matters in relation to the allegations against His Honour.

—On a point of order, Mr Chairman: I must make the point that Senator Puplick is saying nothing that bears upon the clause. I frankly and cheerfully acknowledge that neither did Senator Georges, but in a sense he was making up for Senator Durack's opening burst, which again had nothing to do with the particular clause under consideration. There has been a reasonable amount of evening up. Perhaps, after Senator Puplick has spoken for another minute or two, honourable senators will let the matter rest there and return to the Bill. By all means Senator Puplick should continue for another minute, but I think that that would be about right.

—The point of order is valid. Senator Durack's contribution was relevant to clause 3, so it was in order. Senator Georges was allowed some latitude because of his obvious emotional involvement in the matter. Senator Puplick may reply to Senator Georges but he should not develop the argument for too long.

—Mr Chairman, I will accept your strictures in that regard and, indeed, those of Senator Gareth Evans. I am glad to see that once again Senator Gareth Evans is fast to his feet to protect the interests of his mate, in this case Senator Georges, on whom previously he would not have made any interruption. Nevertheless, the point remains one that needs to be answered. If Senator Georges is to be put in a position where he can, in fact, say that we have been brought to this situation because of the actions of this Parliament, it needs to be put upon the record that the party of which he is a member and the Caucus of which he is a member had the capacity to resolve this matter years ago. If the Government, the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) and, indeed, the previous Attorney-General had had any sense of propriety about how to handle this matter, Senator Georges is quite correct in saying that we would not now be in the position in which we find ourselves today.
—Senator Durack, I understand that you wish to withdraw your amendment, by leave?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the light of the views expressed by the Minister and the information he has given us, it would appear that the only remaining problem with clause 5 may be its very wide ambit. Certainly I do not want to see anything in the legislation which may inhibit the giving of evidence in relation to any material or information that may have been given to the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry. I think the Opposition's purpose would be served by simply voting against clause 5, so I will simply withdraw my amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.
Clause negatived.
Clause 6 agreed to.
Clause 7 (Custody of documents).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are amendments to this clause by the Government as well as by the Opposition. We are proposing the complete deletion of clause 7 and its rewriting. Accordingly, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out clause 7, insert the following clause:

``7. (1) Where, at the commencement, information or documents are in the possession of the Commission and that information or those documents relate, or may relate, to the commission of an offence, or evidence of the commission of an offence, against a law of the Commonwealth, of a State or of a Territory, the Commission may, if in the opinion of the Commission it is appropriate to do so, communicate the information or documents to any one or more of the following-
(a) the Attorney-General of the Commonwealth or of a State or of the Northern Territory;
(b) the National Crime Authority;
(c) the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police or of the Police Force of a State or Territory;
(d) the authority or person responsible for the administration or enforcement of a law referred to in this section.

``(2) Any document that is in the possession of the Commission at the commencement which is not disposed of in accordance with sub-section (1), and which was obtained by the Commission pursuant to section 13 of the repealed Act, shall, as soon as practicable after the commencement, be returned to the National Crime Authority.

``(3) Any document that is in the possession of the Commission at the commencement and which is not disposed of in accordance with sub-section (1) or (2) shall, as soon as practicable after the commencement, be placed in the custody of the Presiding Officers jointly.

``(4) Documents placed in the custody of the Presiding Officers in accordance with sub-section (3) shall be deemed to be records in the possession of the Senate and of the House of Representatives jointly, and shall be disposed of in accordance with the Archives Act 1983, subject to any resolution passed by each House of the Parliament relating to the disposal of those documents.

``(5) Notwithstanding the repeal of the repealed Act by this Act, the repealed Act shall continue to have effect after the commencement for the purpose of, and to the extent necessary for, compliance with this section.''.

There has been a great deal of debate about clause 7 and its effect. I do not think there is really any doubt about its effect as its stands. It is an absolutely outrageous and indefensible clause and the Government now recognises that and has proposed an amendment to it which the Opposition believes is inadequate. We believe that clause 7 should be amended, if not exactly in the terms of our amendment, certainly along those lines. To that extent I am open to any suggestions during rational debate about how my proposed amendment to replace clause 7 could be worded. I have an open mind on it. I acknowledge that we have had very little time to work out a completely suitable alternative code to the totally outrageous provisions of clause 7 which were originally proposed by the Government but from which it now resiles.

I suppose one should give credit where credit is due. The Government has proposed a clause which was going to completely bury forever these documents, but it now proposes to simply bury them completely for 30 years, and thereafter for an indefinite time, depending upon the jointly exercised discretion of the Presiding Officers. We believe both these proposals are quite wrong and we have sought to put forward a principled approach to this difficult question. Our first limb under 7 (1) simply picks up the provision that is in section 34 of the existing Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry Act. That expresses the principle, which obviously is accepted by the Government, that any documents which the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry has, whether it generated the material itself or they were documents given to it by somebody else-say, documents it obtained from the National Crime Authority under the provisions of section 13 in the existing Act-which may be relevant to the commission of an offence against a law of the Commonwealth or of a State, may be communicated at the discretion of the Commission to any appropriate law enforcement authority, whether it be the Attorney-General of the Commonwealth or of a State, the National Crime Authority or a police force of the Commonwealth or of a State.

As I have said, that is a principle which seems to be accepted by the Government. Certainly it is a principle to which the Opposition adheres. That principle is already in the existing Act and it should have been retained in the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry (Repeal) Bill 1986. The Government has sought to answer this amendment by saying that over the last few days the Commission, in the light of this decision to repeal the legislation, apparently has been giving consideration to this question and that the Government would undertake that it would not present this Bill for royal assent until such time as the Commission had been able to complete that task.

I draw the attention of the chamber to the fact that clause 2 of the Bill, which we have already passed, provides that the Bill will come into operation on the day it receives royal assent. Therefore, if we pass this legislation tonight, the Government could easily, without any dramatic midnight flits to Yarralumla, have this Bill in force at a fairly early hour tomorrow morning. We have been asked by Senator Gareth Evans, on behalf of the Government, to accept some assurance that the Government will not do that. In fact, the Government has such a dedication to the prosecution of criminals in this country, such a dedication to the legal processes of this country and such a reputation for honour and a dedication to the proper processes of the law and the democratic process that we should be prepared to accept its undertaking. I am very much afraid and regret to have to say that the Opposition is simply not prepared to accept those assurances by the Government in the light of its record in this matter.

I have already been through this sorry episode of the way in which the Government has behaved. We have not been told what the Government or the Commission was about. Frankly, I do not believe that the Government really adverted to this problem at all until the Press really gave it the works this morning and the Government was alerted to the enormity of what it was trying to do. There was the spectacle this morning of the Government, or at least the Minister at the table on behalf of the Government, I presume-maybe on behalf of himself, I do not know and I suppose it does not matter-trying to suppress the tabling in this Senate today of the reasons for judgment, the purely legal reasoning of the Commission, in relation to section 72 of the Constitution. Despite the fact that that document had been given by the Commission to the Presiding Officers and the Presiding Officers were about to table it in the proper discharge of their duties, this morning there was an attempt by the Government to suppress it. Why would we in the Opposition accept any assurances or undertakings by the Government on this matter at all? We certainly do not. Therefore it is most important that we have this principle contained in the new Bill. It should not disappear out the window, as it could by the Government flitting out to Government House tonight and getting royal assent.

The second point is that we believe that any documents which have been received by the Commission from the National Crime Authority under section 13 should be returned to the Authority. There does not seem to be any argument about that. The third point is that the remaining documents should be placed in the custody of the Presiding Officers. The fourth point-this is the big difference between us and the Government-is that those documents should then come under the provisions of the Archives Act, subject however to any motion passed by each House of Parliament relating to their disposal. So it still would remain within the power of the Parliament to make other arrangements about their disposal, but if it did not do so the disposal of those documents would not be left to the discretion of the Presiding Officers. I think that would be a very unreasonable discretion to leave to those people. We do have the Archives Act, which was the subject of lengthy consideration and debate in this Parliament some time ago. That would appear to be a very adequate means of disposing of this problem. As I understand it, that legislation was supported in a bi-partisan way and it is working perfectly well. The essential feature of that Act is that it protects these documents for 30 years, although there is provision in special circumstances for some documents to be made available earlier than that. But in general they are protected for 30 years. Thereafter the general rule of that Act is that the documents are available for historians and others to write the history of the nation.

There seems to be no reason, apart from the reason I gave earlier in the debate, for some of the attempts by the Government clearly to put Mr Justice Murphy in some unique position whereby his conduct can never be scrutinised by historians. I do not think the Government now maintains that position and I am pleased to have that recognition by it. It would have been unnecessary for us to have made such rather harsh comments had the Government let us into this secret at an earlier stage, but that was not its intention. It gave every indication until 10 o'clock this morning that that was its intention. If anything harsh has been said in this debate about those matters I am afraid the responsibility again is fairly and squarely on the Government and not on the Opposition. There is a savings provision as part of this amendment to enable the Commission to have the power to do the things that we say it ought to have in this clause. For all those reasons I have moved the Opposition's amendment, which is really a rewriting of clause 7.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government obviously rejects the attempt to rewrite clause 7 and to undermine one of the basic principles of this Bill, the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry (Repeal) Bill, in the way that the Opposition has attempted. We do, however, have an amendment of our own. Is it appropriate for me to move that at this stage?
—No, we will get rid of this one.

—Well, that is an appropriate thing for me to do, Mr Temporary Chairman. I accept that. Let me just say that the Opposition's concern with the Government's clause 7 seems to be twofold. Firstly, its argument, which it has been beating the drum about during the morning but much less robustly since, is that there is no opportunity in the way in which the present clause is drafted for information in the possession of the Commission of Inquiry to get out to law enforcement agencies where that might prove to be appropriate. Secondly, it is concerned about the archival provisions, and the particular one that the Government proposes to introduce to amend clause 7, and their allegedly uniquely circumscribed character.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the Opposition's first concern in relation to the disposal of material, I hope by now that concern has been sufficiently answered without my needing to explain yet again how that material will go back to existing law enforcement agencies, where it has originated from them, by virtue of section 18 of the present Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry (Repeal) Act and how, by virtue of section 34 of the present Act, the Commission is in the process of making some of that material available, to the extent it thinks it might be useful, to the National Crime Authority and perhaps to other agencies as well. I find vulgar in the extreme, and quite at odds with the normal parliamentary courtesies of this place, Senator Durack's assertion that he will not accept the undertakings that I have given on behalf of the Government in relation to the time available for these processes to work themselves out. An undertaking is an undertaking, Senator Durack. I think if I were to act in breach of an undertaking I would personally, and on behalf of the Government, deserve the censure of the Senate. There is no question of that occurring and I find the suggestion that it might extremely offensive and not befitting a--

TALK.START.PARA: —We could not trust you as far as we could throw you.
—I could not throw the senator very far.
—There is no reason to admit your weakness in this matter.

—Hercules himself. Can I proceed to the second part of the Opposition's concern, and that is the archives? It is the case that the Government has responded to concern that has been expressed about what was an oversight. As I frankly conceded earlier today, in the rush of events we had not thought about the longer term problems that would be associated with people who may have a reasonable interest at some time in gaining access to this material. That was present in our minds to the extent that we rejected the concept of destruction of the documents which had been pressed upon us from various quarters as being appropriate for anything, however outrageous the content of those documents might be. That does offend what Senator Puplick would no doubt describe as the historian's sensitivity, and we were not intending to do anything of the kind. It is the case that there ought to be some appropriate archival rule proscribed for this. However, there is a concern that the normal archives rules, with their exemptions, including in particular the capacity for the Prime Minister of the day to single handedly release any document or any class of documents that he in effect chooses to. Confident though we are, of course, that there will not be a Prime Minister of another colour for some considerable time, we did not nonetheless think it appropriate that a matter of this kind should be subject to political vagaries in any short term context.

SPEECH.PARA: It is, if one likes, a unique provision that is here proposed-when I get around to amending it, and I have foreshadowed that. It is different from just applying the Archives Act in the ordinary way. But as I sought to explain earlier, we are faced with a unique set of circumstances. Let me repeat: For the first time in the history of this country we have had a commission of inquiry established with full, wide ranging investigative powers, privileges and protections, not to inquire into some particular incident or some particular course of conduct that is identified for the purpose of the inquiry, but rather to open up the entire life of a person, a human being, in public and in private and expose that to scrutiny with all that that entails. That is a unique thing, a uniquely draconian and uniquely far reaching thing to do. I say to Senator Durack, who is smirking away there in the corner, that he now regards it an appropriate precedent to be employed against all sorts of people in the future if he gets his way. But it is not something we ought to embark upon with any lightness of heart at all, and I hope it never will be again. Having been embarked upon on this occasion, for better or for worse, it is appropriate to treat the matter in the way that the Government proposes.
