For all those various reasons I do urge the Committee to reject the amendment to clause 7 and in due course to accept the Government's amendment, which I will formally move in a moment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) has identified two areas which he says have given the Opposition particular cause for concern about this clause. He has said, in effect, that if the Opposition's amendment is passed it will undermine the basic principles of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry (Repeal) Bill. The two concerns are, firstly, our concern about the access of law enforcement agencies to this material and, secondly, the establishment of a somewhat different and unique archival regime for the treatment of the material in the possession of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry. However, there is a third element of concern which I believe is just as strong as the others and on the basis of which the Opposition amendment ought to be accepted.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer particularly to the regime which would be established by clause 7 (4) of the Opposition's amendment. This touches upon the matter of the relationship between the Presiding Officers and the chambers. Under the regime which the Government seeks to put in place certain duties and restrictions are laid upon the Presiding Officer, in terms of his or her ability to release, even to the Parliament, material which is in his or her possession. The Presiding Officer is constrained by the Government's regime in clause 7-even in the way it would be amended by the Government's foreshadowed amendment-not to release certain information even if the House determines that the information ought to be released. There is in fact a double veto. There is the extent to which the Presiding Officer of the chamber concerned is precluded from releasing the information and there is the further veto that the matter also has to be undertaken in consultation with the Presiding Officer in the other chamber.

The Opposition's amendment in proposed clause 7 (4) would make it clear that the documents placed in the custody of the Presiding Officer-those documents which are in his or her possession and are distinct from those which have been returned to the originating authority or law enforcement agency, or those which have been passed by the Commission to any of the authorities mentioned in proposed clause 7 (1)-shall be deemed to be records in the possession of the Senate and the House of Representatives jointly and shall be disposed of subject to any resolution passed by each House of the Parliament relating to the disposal of those documents. In other words, it establishes the clear principle that the documents in the possession of the Presiding Officer are to be taken as documents actually in the possession of the chamber over which that Presiding Officer is presiding and the determination as to their fate at any time lies in the hands of the chambers. It does not lie in the situation in which the Presiding Officer would be constrained by legislation from not giving effect to the resolution of the chamber.

I cannot remember the precise quotation, but I recall that one of the great parliamentary events is supposed to have been when Speaker Lenthall addressed Charles I on his arrival in the House, telling him that the Speaker had neither eyes to see nor ears to hear nor tongue to speak save by the way in which that honourable House gave him leave. But this legislation, as established by the Government, would say to the Presiding Officer: `Regardless of the opinion of the chamber over which you are presiding and regardless of the direction that chamber may give you as Presiding Officer in possession of documents, you are constrained from giving effect to the will of the Parliament. Not only do you have difficulty, but the will of one chamber in that respect is to be subject to the veto of the Presiding Officer in the other, if it came to that'.

TALK.START.PARA: —But the chambers can change the legislation.

—I believe that the correct way to proceed is in accordance with the principle that the Opposition is laying down in sub-clause (4) of its amendment, namely, that when the material comes into the possession of the Presiding Officers it shall be regarded as being in a situation in which its disposal is a matter for the resolution of the two Houses. If the Houses decide that the material shall be disposed of in a particular fashion, this piece of legislation should not constrain that undertaking on the part of the Houses.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Georges says that if that is a problem, just repeal the legislation. I put it to Senator Georges that we should not have to go through the exercise of seeking to repeal a piece of legislation in order to give effect to the principle that the Houses of Parliament have the right to dispose of material lodged with their Presiding Officers. We should not, therefore, enact the Government's proposed clause 7 as far as this matter is concerned and establish those restraints in the first place. We should take the opportunity now to establish that principle and establish it clearly.

I say in conclusion on this clause that it is of some interest to look at the information the Minister has provided to us about the return of documents already having been undertaken. It is not just a matter that this has had to be dragged out of the Government, but it makes a total nonsense of the subsequent clauses of this legislation dealing with the prosecutions of people who print or disclose information derived from documents received or in the possession of the Commission, since it will undoubtedly be impossible to prove that the document was leaked from the Parliamentary Commission rather than from the National Crime Authority, the Attorney-General's Department, the Director of Public Prosecutions, the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Alleged Telephone Interceptions or whoever it was that gave these documents to the Commission in the first place and has now had them returned. Who will be able to prove whether the leaked document was the National Crime Authority's original document or a copy of the document retained on file by the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry and leaked from that source? All that will mean is that the whole regime falls to the ground and presumably the officers of the Australian Federal Police, the Director of Public Prosecutions or whoever is involved will have to scurry around trying to demonstrate the source of this particular leak if it is to proceed with some sort of prosecution under clause 8.

The very admission by the Government of the way in which this material has been handled goes to expose the way in which this legislation has been drafted on the run, amended on the run and undermined on the run. It indicates not only the extent to which this piece of legislation should not be given effect to in any fashion, but also specifically why the Government's proposed regime in proposed clause 7 is so totally unsatisfactory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Puplick is always a bit harsh on the Government and me on these occasions. Here we are behaving like a legislative chamber-not just a rubber stamp belting our way through legislation, endorsing it and kicking it out the door again; we are actually talking about it, arguing about it and fixing up a few things as they appear along the way-yet here he is getting grumpy about it.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me respond to the third alleged advantage of Senator Puplick's clause 7 over ours-the vesting of this discretion in the Presiding Officers rather than in the two Houses as a whole. Let me say two things about that: Firstly, it does not demonstrate much confidence on the part of Senator Puplick or the Opposition that they should have that feeling towards the Presiding Officers, who for all sorts of other purposes honourably and effectively represent the interests of the respective chambers.

The other point I make is that it is really a mirror image of the sort of provision in the Archives Act, which vests in the Prime Minister personally the discretion to make available archival material, rather than in the government of the day, the Governor-in-Council or any of the other familiar euphemisms. No doubt the Prime Minister would take advice and consult his Cabinet colleagues on a matter of sensitivity that arose under the Archives Act. Equally, one would anticipate that the Presiding Officers would take account of the prevailing currents and views of opinion and so on. It is really for those sorts of reasons that the legislation has been drafted in this way. It does not need all the fire and brimstone and enthusiasm that Senator Puplick brought to the debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —May I just ask for a clarification from the Minister. Is he saying that under the Government's proposed regime, if the Senate and the House of Representatives both resolve to direct their Presiding Officers to make material in the possession of those Presiding Officers available to the chambers, the Presiding Officers would have the discretion to do so or would be empowered to do so?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are talking about two situations. One is that of the class B material which is now vested in the discretion of the Presiding Officers and is not subject to any overriding provision about directions from the Parliament as a whole. The other material is the class A material, and I am here referring to the Bill as it will look when hopefully it is amended by the passage of my foreshadowed amendment, which vests a discretion in the Presiding Officers to make such material available after 30 years. There are parallels to be drawn-not exact, but parallels nonetheless-between the Archives Act vesting a discretionary authority in the Prime Minister and this amendment vesting a limited authority, as it is only a few years down the track, in the Presiding Officers. The reason for making the archives rule as it is in my amendment is as I have described-the peculiarly unique character, if that is not a tautology, of this Commission material and the circumstances in which it is derived.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the words proposed to be left out (Senator Durack's amendment) be left out.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments (by Senator Gareth Evans)-by leave-agreed to:
(1) Page 2, clause 7, line 25, after ``law'' insert ``, during the period of 30 years after the commencement''.
(2) Page 2, clause 7, lines 38 to 40, leave out sub-clause (4), substitute the following sub-clause:
``(4) Notwithstanding any other law, a person is not entitled to have access to, or to make use of-
(a) a class A document after the end of the period of 30 years after the commencement; or
(b) a class B document at any time,
except in accordance with the written authority of the Presiding Officers.''.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 8 (Disclosure).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has been deeply troubled by clause 8. It is clear now that the Government has also seen the difficulties with its clause 8 and it is proposing an amendment to it that we do not believe is adequate, although it may make some improvement to it. The interesting thing is that the Government has obviously realised, at long last, that everything that has been said by the Opposition and by others elsewhere about the enormity of clause 8 is justified. We do not believe that it is sufficient to tinker around with clause 8. We believe that the clause proceeds on a totally wrong basis. The amendment we propose is consistent with a whole range of similar situations. It is in accordance with our efforts to introduce some principle into the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry (Repeal) Bill 1986.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a great many agencies that have been created by this Parliament in recent years which have possession of sensitive personal material. It is desired by the Parliament to protect that material in a reasonable, responsible way. That is done by putting an obligation on the members and staff of the agency to protect the documents, the information, and making it a criminal offence for the members or staff of the commission or the agency to divulge that information except in accordance with statute. That is what we propose here as it is the right, principal and consistent course, and is in accordance with the precedent of other decisions of this Parliament.

In addition, this has been the principle of official secrets legislation in this country and elsewhere. The sections of the Crimes Act dealing with the protection of official secrets have followed the same principle. That Act has made it a crime for the person who has possession of the information which is to be kept secret to breach those provisions and he is visited with sanctions if he does so. All such legislation, of course, has left open the question of what is the responsibility of someone who comes innocently into possession of such information. None of that legislation on our statute books states that the person who has innocent possession of that information is entitled to publish it. I think I am pretty right in saying that. Maybe the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) can state where that is not the case. It certainly is the case under the Crimes Act and in other legislation, which precedent we have followed in our amendment. It is the basis of the D-notice to the Press, under which the Press has, by way of a gentlemen's agreement, accepted that principle. The Press in this country has been free to publish information if it knows or is in league with the person who unlawfully discloses that information. If it has obtained information innocently it publishes it freely as no government has prosecuted any newspaper for publishing information which by statute it is an offence for the person who has custody of it to disclose through the Press. If Senator Gareth Evans can prove me wrong I will be pleased to hear it. It would be an extraordinarily bold government, a very much bolder government than the present Government, if it really knew what it was doing, that changed that. That is clearly what the great concern in this morning's Press is all about. It is about the complete reversal of those precedents and those standards. Maybe the Government did not realise that. It has now come up with an amendment to try to correct that position. I do not happen to think that what the Government has come up with will do that, but that is another matter.

We have been concerned about two aspects of clause 8. We have been concerned about the wider aspect of it, namely, that on a literal interpretation it would prevent the disclosure of not only any information generated within the Commission but also any information which happens to be in the possession of the Commission. I do not want to go into a legal argument about the literal interpretation of statutes, but I can assure the chamber that it is not just my opinion but the opinion of a great many other lawyers who have read this legislation that the literal interpretation of clause 8 could have the widest ramifications not only in respect of disclosure by the Press but also for the law enforcement agencies and others the Government believes should have the right to the information and to use it. Clause 8 could well prevent that and could impose draconian penalties on people for disclosure. The other concern we have about clause 8 is one I have already mentioned, namely, the freedom of the Press to publish information which it obtains in an innocent way. Unless that is clearly made unlawful--

TALK.START.PARA: —How is it likely to obtain it innocently?

—The fundamental rule of statute interpretation is that penal provisions have to be perfectly clearly laid down and that they are always interpreted strictly. That is the basis of what I am saying about the way in which the statutes have been applied in the past. This particular clause completely changes that. No guilty intention or knowledge is required. It is purely a statement of objective fact. If somebody discloses a matter which is derived from a document or information received by or in the possession of the Commission and that person publishes it, whether he knows it came from the Commission or elsewhere, he is in breach of this provision. That is what clause 8 literally means. The Government has become worried about that, and for good reason. It is trying to patch it up and we can argue later about how successfully it has done that.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition is approaching this matter from a completely different standpoint. Our standpoint is based upon the precedent of a great many other statutes that have created agencies. This matter has been dealt with in legislation covering the Human Rights Commission, the Ombudsman and other agencies that have been created in recent times. That legislation protects this sort of information in the way suggested by our amendment. Our clause 8 is based on the precedents of many other statutes passed by this Parliament in recent years. As I said, it is based also on the way in which official secrets are protected in the Crimes Act. We believe that that is all that is required here and all that should be provided for. Accordingly, I move my amendment concerning clause 8:
Leave out clause 8, insert the following clause:

``8. (1) A person who is, or has at any time been, a member of the Commission, a member of the staff of the Commission or counsel assisting the Commission shall not, directly or indirectly, disclose to any other person or make use of any document or information to which the first-mentioned person has had access by reason of being or having been such a member or counsel.
``Penalty: $5,000 or imprisonment for 6 months, or both.
``(2) Sub-section (1) does not prevent or hinder-
(a) the performance of any act otherwise authorised by this Act or the repealed Act as continued in effect by this Act; or

(b) the participation of a person in any investigation undertaken by a person or organisation referred to in section 7, or any proceedings, in which use is made of information or documents referred to in section 7.''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The basic and overwhelming problem with the Opposition amendment is that it applies the pro- hibition on disclosure only to the Commission itself. It applies it to the Commissioners-not that it is very polite to contemplate that they might disclose anything-a member of the staff or the Commission or counsel assisting the Commission. The amendment would not extend any kind of prohibition on disclosure by anyone else. It must be acknowledged that in the particular circumstances of this Commission of Inquiry the risk of disclosure of desperately defamatory material by someone other than a member of the Commission is quite high. Let us remember what we are talking about here. We are not talking about documents originating from outside the Commission, because there is no prohibition or restraint on the originators of documents in fact choosing to publish those documents themselves. If someone sends in a set of allegations, whether or not the particular document embodying those allegations is sent back to the individual does not limit the capacity of that individual to publish it either personally or with the assistance of a newspaper or some organisation of that kind.
—It does not say that at all.

—To the extent that it has not been made clear enough-I know that that is a point that Senator Haines had made publicly-we can fix that up. We will come to that when I get to my own amendment, which I will be foreshadowing in a moment. However, the problem is that in regard to this Commission we are not talking only about documents generated externally and which have been in the Commission's possession, and which may or may not be in the Commission's possession any longer. Those documents can be utilised, at least under our Bill, by the originators if not by anyone else. They can get into the public domain if the originators want them to get into the public domain. As I say, there is no prohibition on that.

SPEECH.PARA: However, there is another class of documents which is likely to be very sensitive and crucial. I refer to documents originating from within the Commission itself-such as the list of allegations which obviously has been prepared and which is the subject of various Committee documents that have now been made public; for example, reports, opinions and so on. I refer also to internal analysis of those allegations and the cross-referencing of material, and the products of such investigation and information gathering as have been initiated or generated from within the Commission and about which Senator Georges spoke earlier. I have no idea how much of that material exists but I am sure that by now, after several weeks of operation and the Commission having got to the stage of its report that it has, that there is quite a bulk of that material. I am sure that it is enormously sensitive material and that it is potentially enormously damaging. Let us remember again that none of this has been tested by cross-examination; it is made up merely of allegations and purported but as yet untested evidence. Let us assume, I think realistically, that heaps of material exists within the Commission. It becomes a matter of ensuring that the material does not leak out or, if it does leak out, that there are serious disincentives to anyone else using it.

Senator Durack says that when one is talking about bodies empowered to gather information of a sensitive character the usual legislative practice is simply to have a clause in there of the kind that he himself has moved, which imposes rigorous, sometimes perhaps draconian, sanctions against the members of the institution or the organisation itself. Thus he cited the Ombudsman and, I seem to remember, the National Companies and Securities Commission and a miscellany of other agencies of that kind of which that is so. There is no wider disclosure provision; the reliance is on the prohibition against the body itself.

Again, I point to the unique character of this exercise. Let me repeat: Never in the history of this country has a body with coercive powers been set in train to examine at large, in an open-ended way, the life of a human being. Would any of us cope with that kind of scrutiny? Could any of us contemplate having whatever is turned up by anyone around the place who might be minded to make allegations getting unhindered, or less than totally hindered, into the public domain? Of course we would not welcome that and we should not be anaesthetised by the mass of this material which has already been circulated about poor Lionel Murphy into thinking that there is something more reasonable about that in these particular circumstances.

Yes, this is a harsh provision; designedly so-but for a very good reason. As to its harshness, might I just say something about the penalties because they have been the subject of some public comment. I see that the Opposition is not fussing about the $5,000 or imprisonment for six months because it picked that up itself. Indeed, so it should have because that is a commonly recurring thing. However, there has been concern about the fine of $100,000 for a corporate defendant. I suppose that as a corporate defendant is not contemplated in the Opposition's draft it is omitted anyway. I refer to the fact that the Joint Select Committee on Parliamentary Privilege recommended in its final report of October 1984 that the penalty for a person who commits a breach of parliamentary privilege should be a fine not exceeding $5,000 or imprisonment for a period not exceeding six months. On the basis that this, as a parliamentary commission, appropriately attracts parliamentary privilege sorts of sanctions, the Bill proposes to adopt that recommendation.

TALK.START.PARA: —That has not been passed by Parliament.

—True, but we are getting there. The Joint Select Committee recommended a penalty of $10,000 for corporations which commit a breach of parliamentary privilege. However, the Government is of the view that a penalty of that amount for bodies corporate simply is not a sufficient deterrent and would be easily absorbed as a business overhead by many such bodies corporate. The level of $100,000 that is here settled upon has not, however, just been dragged out of the ether. It is the same level of penalty as that applying to bodies corporate which contravene Part V of the Trade Practices Act. That is the reference point that has been here applied. I mention that should any honourable senator be minded to make that point.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the drafting of the existing clause 8, which Senator Durack has indicated he does not like, I acknowledge that there has been some misunderstanding of the effect of this particular clause. That might be a product of the language chosen by the draftsman even though I think that when properly construed and looked at in the context of the legislation as a whole the language is perfectly apt and precise. The difficulty seems to be with the expression `derived' in sub-clause 8 (a) which states:
. . . any allegation relating to the conduct of the Honourable Lionel Keith Murphy derived from a document received, obtained or prepared, or information received or obtained, by the Commission . . .

I think there is a concern that this language is not sufficiently precise and that it does not make it sufficiently clear that it is not the document itself and the originator of that document, who are here the subject of attention, but rather someone else who gets access to that document and then uses the material in it and publishes it or discloses it that is the target. In the Macquarie Dictionary the word `derived' means `to receive or obtain from a source of origin'. The only circumstances in which sub-clause 8 (a) is intended to apply, and we believe would apply, is where the only source of information is the particular document or the particular information that was before the Commission. If the substance of that document or information was known from any other source it would not be caught by the prohibition. That was our intent in drafting the provision in this way. I think that that is a proper construction and interpretation of it. It is consistent with everything I have been saying all day. However, I acknowledge that perhaps the terminology is a little unusual and not as clear as it might be in distinguishing between the position of the proper possessor, or proper originator or creator of the document in question, and somebody who might get inappropriate access to it. With that in mind I foreshadow that I will move an amendment later on which leaves out the words `derived from a document received, obtained or prepared' and substitutes, rather, the expression `which is known to the person only from a document received, obtained or prepared'. I think that much more clearly conveys the intention of the clause itself and avoids some of the problems of the perhaps unduly literalistic interpretation Senator Durack referred to before.

There is another element to the Government's amendment which again has been prompted by concerns expressed by the Australian Democrats. I refer to the concern about the practical viability of this clause when one is talking not so much about a document being leaked but rather something in the nature of information, perhaps orally obtained and not around in documentary form. The feeling was that to prosecute someone for a disclosure based on, as it would have to be now, information known only to that person from information before the Commission is perhaps being a bit unduly harsh and perhaps not especially realistic in the light of how real world prosecutions may run and that it would be better and simpler all round to confine the scope of this prohibition to straight documentary material so defined. That is in explanation and anticipation of the Government's amendment to this clause. Given the nature of this Commission and the material before it, which are unique in Australia's history, it is important that we have a clause that goes further than the usual non-disclosure clauses and extends the deterrent, disincentives or penalty to persons other than those within the Commission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have before us from the Opposition an amendment to the clause contained in the Bill, to which Senator Gareth Evans has foreshadowed that the Government will also propose an amendment. It is all reasonable Alice in Wonderland stuff, but quite frankly let us look at what will happen so that we may be able to work out what ought to occur. There are three types of documents that we are now discussing. Firstly, there are the documents which contain allegations submitted to the Commission. Secondly, there is a range of documents that were commissioned or otherwise delivered to the Commission, which are of a legal nature and which are now being disclosed, so we can put them aside. The third set of documents is the working papers of the Commission. The first type of document, that is, the allegations, by definition must be in the possession of people in the community other than members of the Commission. In other words, already they are documents to which people have access and with which people may, of their own choosing, do what they will. If it is defamatory material people or the newspapers can take a risk, but at least one person in the community other than members of the Commission must have access to those allegations, that is, the person who made them. I think that type can really be put aside.

SPEECH.PARA: We are reduced to the working papers of the Commission. Quite frankly, I think they ought to be shredded. Let us look at the comparison that we want to make. We are talking about a parliamentary commission. Let us look at what happens to committees of this chamber or of this Parliament. They have similar types of documents. They have submissions which are archived. The committees publish reports which are made public and which are archived. The working papers of a committee are not kept; they are trashed. They are the types of things with which committees work as they prepare their final reports; they are not kept. Any documents of a legal nature that are received by a committee are kept, along with the submissions. We have the same types of material when we prepare committee reports.

What I think are much more important in terms of both Senator Durack's amendment and the Government's proposed amendment are the problems of what happens to the documents. Senator Durack has covered the first leg of the journey only. He has talked about the Commission as it now exists, its staff as it now exists and the possession of information and documents relating to that Commission. Senator Durack's amendment will cover those people at a future time, but by nature of this Bill those documents are to be delivered to another set of people who are not covered by Senator Durack's amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Presiding Officers.

—The Presiding Officers and presumably their staff. Unless our Presiding Officers cart mountains of this material around with them, some other people will have access to this stuff. We are in Alice in Wonderland because we are carting around this stuff at which nobody will ever be able to look and which will be of no earthly use to anybody. I do not think Senator Durack's amendment covers the proposition of the next leg of the journey.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Evans's amendment, on the other hand, does not seem to me to deal with the practical problems that may then go to when we may want to use the clause, that is, when we may want to launch a prosecution. Pray tell: How would anybody know that he wants to launch a prosecution? Other than the commissioners and staff, nobody knows what is in the documents; but the commissioners and staff are not allowed to tell anybody. May I put to an amendment which has already been carried, that this overrules all other laws. Does it go into the courts so that a prosecutor cannot use the material, or is that to be exempt? If courts are to be exempt, what about this chamber? Under our privileges are we to be exempt? How does the prosecution know that this clause has been breached? Maybe the Presiding Officers are the ones who launch this prosecution. Who launches it? Would it be the Attorney-General? But the Attorney-General does not know what is in these papers, so he cannot do it. The Director of Public Prosecutions cannot launch it because he does not know what is in them. How do we then prosecute the case? This is absurd. What do we do when presumably the Press publishes this material? I cannot imagine anybody else wanting to publish working documents of the Commission, God help us, and I do not know what Press would want to publish those either.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about a list of allegations?
—All right; let us take a list of allegations. Let us say that the National Times on Sunday is to publish a list of allegations.
—With summaries of supporting material derived from the allegations that have been made. It is pretty heady stuff, isn't it?

—All right, it is heady stuff. Presumably the Attorney-General or the Director of Public Prosecutions will know that that is one of the documents. I would like the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) to tell us how the Director of Public Prosecutions would find that out-he will have plenty of time to tell us-or who informs the Director of Public Prosecutions of that fact; presumably the Presiding Officer does so. I am worried, I must admit, by a point that Senator Puplick raised a while ago about what we are doing to the Presiding Officers in drawing them into this area, what their standing and obligations will be with regard to the ongoing nature of this material and with regard to the prosecution of these. I am more concerned about how, when we have a person there, we are to make the foreshadowed amendment stick as a matter of pure prosecution. How do we prosecute that? Do we then go to the next point? Presumably we say to a member of the Press `What is your source?', or does that person merely sit on his hands and wait for the prosecution to prove its case?
—They can't.

—It cannot prove its case. One of the Minister's concerns about Senator Durack's amendment was that one of the members or staff of the Commission may leak the material and then it would be very difficult to prosecute. I think that is perfectly true. We have already had a problem in this chamber in terms of a leak from a committee that was dealing with this matter. We found it almost impossible to find out who did the leaking. I am not sure whether it was a leakee or a leakor. Obviously it had to be someone who was in possession of the material.
—It was impossible.

—Yes. I was a member of a committee which publicly asked each of the persons who were in possession of that material, on oath, and we did not get anywhere. I think Senator Durack's proposition also is a very difficult one to articulate in relation to trying to get anything done with it. I do not think we could get a prosecution out of that or out of the Government's proposition, either. I am not sure what it is we are doing in waving these flags at people when essentially they are inoperative. Ultimately one has to fall back on the fact that these working documents really should not continue in existence. The stuff that will be in existence are the allegations-and they will remain in existence anyhow-and the legal information which we have already paid for as a community. I do not know what use that will be to anybody but no doubt it will be interesting to read through, for academics to work over and for people to get theses out of. I cannot see any practical way of dealing with the working paper in a way which will protect it. I do not think that either under Senator Durack's proposition or the Government's proposition we could launch a successful, feasible prosecution that would not put us into the position of gaoling journalists, for example, for six months. I am not quite sure what this Government is up to, but I know that it certainly would not be up to gaoling journalists for six months.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government might well be in the business of fining newspaper corporations large sums of money for blatant and flagrant breaches of a law of non-disclosure which is put onto the stat- ute books for very good and sound reasons which--
—You have to prove the documents.

—I will get to that. Let me take just one point at a time in the great melange of excitement that has emerged from Senator Macklin having suddenly got absorbed in this debate. That is a path one might choose to go down if one were embarking on a journey as a government of seeking to avoid the disclosure of material which is profoundly and disgracefully defamatory, as this material will be because it will only be allegations, supporting assertions and untested evidence; let us repeat all that. There are reasons-and I do not want to repeat them ad nauseum-why this material should not get into the public domain. I do not understand Senator Macklin to be contesting that. His bottom line is not to let the information out; his bottom line is to burn it, to shred it. We have some sympathy for that when it comes to this material but book burning went out of fashion in mediaeval Florence and it has not been terribly successfully done by anyone very attractive since.

SPEECH.PARA: Whatever the squalid character of the material and however much it might not deserve ever to see the public light-and I cannot believe that any of this stuff will-I have a natural abhorrence of the concept of getting over a difficulty by destroying the problem, by destroying the evidence. I do not know whether Opposition members share that view or not; they were a pretty good bunch of book burners in their time. In this particular context it is not really a viable option. One has to look for lesser options. Senator Macklin should appreciate that this is probably about the best we can do. There are always problems of proof in running any prosecution about anything and Directors of Public Prosecution are always whingeing away about the problems of proof besetting them. They are always telling Governments about the impossibility of chasing someone down some burrow who many people think ought to be chased. That happens all the time in a criminal context.

TALK.START.PARA: —Here they have a law stopping them from finding out anything.

—But the problems of proof are not especially greater here than anywhere else. If a collection of allegations, let us say, is published as the allegations that have emerged from the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry-`exclusive scoop', that sort of thing-it will not be too hard, on the face of it, to establish the likely origin of that material by looking at the language of it, by seeking testimony in affidavit form in the first instance and subsequently orally in court if necessary from not just the Presiding Officers but also the officers of the Commission. They are able to be chased up easily enough. Unless they have been stolen, presumably there will be documents within the possession of the Presiding Officers to compare the allegations with and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Government's amendment is accepted there is another course open, again to weaken, I suppose, the force of this measure, and that is that if the documents themselves are not published as such but merely the information in them set out in some different way, the problems of proof are multiplied to that greater extent. If one is prepared to make non-prosecutable-as we are now prepared not to do-information derived from information before the Commission that provides another avenue. The legislation is not especially draconian in terms of the way in which, I guess, it is likely to operate because there are ways around it. There are ways in which, as it has been said, the original material not created within the Commission itself can get back into the public domain. But the legislation is important, even with all the limitations which I acknowledge in its likely effectiveness. There are not impossibilities but there are limitations. With all those limitations the legislation is still important because of the uniquely devastating nature of this kind of material and the unique circumstances in which it has been obtained-a parliamentary commission with all the royal commission powers established to explore the life of a human being.

Under those circumstances surely disincentives, deterrents and penalties can be created for those who would, not innocently but maliciously, put this material into the public domain. As Senator Durack says, there is a presumption of malice if there is a penal clause operating as such and that would be read into it. I cannot imagine what an innocent disclosure would be likely to look like with this material getting out into the public domain through some leak from a Commission Officer or parliamentary officer in due course. I do not know what an innocent disclosure would look like and I cannot imagine that anyone getting this material out would deserve too much sympathy. But I think it is the best we can do. Obviously, there are big problems of principle involved-I frankly and cheerfully acknowledge them-in any sort of law, in any context whatsoever that is aimed at limiting disclosure. I am a freedom of information person. There are not many of us left in the Government these days.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, you're joking!

—I am not joking. I have never been more fair dinkum. I believe in those principles. I believe in their importance. But even the best run freedom of information system in the world is full of appropriate exemptions for breaches of confidence regarding material of a kind which has no conceivably redeeming public merit and which has been obtained in the kind of circumstances that this material has been obtained in. I do not know whether Senator Macklin has any more specific questions. I acknowledge some of the points that he is making, but surely the destruction of this material is not the alternative. The only alternative is to go down the middle course, which has been chosen here, of stringent non-disclosure rules but by no means absolute ones.

—I raised some questions when I spoke previously regarding Senator Durack's amendment. Would Senator Durack like to respond in terms of how he sees the proposition being dealt with at the next stage, that is, when the documents come into the possession of the Presiding Officers and, obviously, of the staff of the Presiding Officers. Perhaps Senator Durack could consider whether they ought also to be included in his amendment because at the moment the people who have access to the documents, that is, members of the Commission, are covered but the next group of people who will have access to them is not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —We believe that our amendment is adequate for its purpose. It seems to me that once the documents get into the hands of the Presiding Officers and other parliamentary officers, the various powers, prohibitions and sanctions that can be exercised over the misuse of documents by parliamentary officers will apply. I do not think we need to have any special rules to cover that.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the words proposed to be left out (Senator Durack's amendment) be left out.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is: That the words proposed to be inserted by Senator Durack's amendment No. 2 be inserted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —A logical consequence of where we are now at would be for the Australian Democrats to oppose the insertion of Senator Durack's words on the basis that they clearly do not believe in there being any effective sanctions against the disclosure or publication of this material. Why they should bother to impose sanctions on the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry staff when the Commission is about to go out of existence and not to impose sanctions on parliamentary staff or anybody else who will be in possession of this material from now on, let alone anybody else who might come into the possession of this material, I simply do not know. It would be a thoroughly quixotic enterprise on the Australian Democrats' part to now support this proposal, particularly since they have indicated their preferred position is to shred the material entirely. I know it is suck-up-to-the-media time, but the behaviour of the Democrats tonight is totally incomprehensible and not such as to justify any respect from any self-respecting member of this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — There is a further amendment consequential upon God knows what sub-section it now is--
—I do not think your amendment, which you are looking at, Senator, fits very happily into Senator Durack's amendment.
—Whatever penalty we now have ought not to apply in relation to anything done in accordance with authority given under sub-section 7 (4), which is still on foot. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Notwithstanding any other law, a person is not entitled to have access to, or to make use of, a class B document except in accordance with the written authority of the Presiding Officers.
Clearly we do not want that to apply in relation to Senator Durack's clause 8 (1). Do we not just call Senator Durack's amendment clause 8 (1) and insert my amendment as sub-clause (3)? I move:
(3) Page 3, clause 8, add at the end the following sub-clause:
`(2) Sub-section (1) does not apply in relation to anything done in accordance with an authority given under sub-section 7 (4).'.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a third time.
One technical problem has shown up in the drafting of Senator Durack's measure. That can be fixed up.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to speak on the third reading.
—It is time to go home.
—I know it is time to go home. I think that we should all congratulate ourselves--
—Speak on the adjournment.
—No.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since I have been a member of Parliament, both in this chamber and--
—The standard of debate has dropped.

—I thank the honourable senator. I expected better of her, but now that she has adopted the role of Leader of the Australian Democrats I shall, no doubt, expect far worse. Since I have been a member of Parliament, both as a senator and as a member of the House of Representatives before then, I have been subjected to continual smears and attacks of a personal nature by members of the Australian Labor Party. I am prepared to wear that. I have always done so. It does not bother me. If it did, I would not have decided to come back for a second dose of it. As a result, I am not in the business of setting out to smear Labor senators. Although I intend to raise some serious matters, I do not intend to smear or make innuendoes against any members of the Government. However, I would like to draw to the Senate's attention that on two occasions the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has had the opportunity to respond to serious comments made very publicly indeed about him at the weekend in a Sydney newspaper. On both occasions, he decided against making a response of any substance. In case honourable senators are not aware of it, I seek leave to table the article entitled `The Keating-Anderson Connection', which appeared in the National Times on Sunday.
—Is leave granted for the tabling of the document?
—No.
—Because leave has not been granted as Senator Georges chose not to allow it to be tabled--
—Would you like me to explain why?

—If the honourable senator would like to follow me in the debate, he may do so. This puts me in a difficult situation. I had sought not to refer to the article. If it is not to be tabled, I am forced to refer to elements in the article, which I would certainly rather not do.
—You are tabling the thing. You are making it a public document under the privilege of this Parliament. You cannot cover it by privilege in that way by tabling it.

—I do not imagine that that is a matter of moment. The Treasurer has had every opportunity since Sunday to issue whatever legal response he wants to. So far, I have not heard of any legal matters being raised.
—What are the accusations in the article?
—A range of comments are made.
—What are the specific accusations made in the article?
—Clearly, Government senators lack knowledge of the content of the article.
—We have read the article.
—In those circumstances, it seems even more unfortunate that leave has not been granted to table the article. I am not seeking to incorporate the article; I simply want it tabled.
—I raise a point of order, Mr President. I have to use the device of a point of order. You will have to be tolerant with me.
—Order! The honourable senator has risen on a point of order. I shall hear the point of order.

—My point of order is that, by endeavouring to table a document or by referring to it, the honourable senator gives that document a privilege which will enable other newspapers to pick up the document, which is clearly defamatory, and use the privilege of Parliament to protect themselves against any action. I do not know whether the honourable senator is aware of what he is doing. I am trying to protect him and prevent him from doing something that I hope he does not intend doing-that is, to give currency to a scurrilous article in the newspaper and use the Senate to do so.
—Order! There is no point of order. It is a point of explanation, but not a point of order.

—I thank the honourable senator for explaining the consequences of the article being tabled. I have no knowledge of whether the matters in the article are correct. That is one reason why I did not want to be obliged to state them. By stating them, I would incorporate them in Hansard.
—By tabling the article, you are making it a public document.
—If anyone wants to reprint the article, I imagine that the absence of any writ at this stage, after four or five days, from the Treasurer would carry some suggestion--
—Not at all.
—The honourable senator has used the word `scurrilous'. I have no idea whether the article is scurrilous.
—Well, you should not use it.
—Order! I ask that interjections cease. I ask Senator Michael Baume to address his remarks to the Chair.
—Thank you, Mr President. On Wednesday at the National Press Club, Mr Ross Dunn from the Sydney Morning Herald asked the Treasurer this question:

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the recent article in the `National Times' concerning your relationship with Warren Anderson. Can I ask you when did you become aware that Mr Anderson was under investigation by the Tax Office, and is it proper for the Treasurer to continue to have a relationship with a person under investigation for tax matters until that investigation is resolved.
Mr Keating replied:

Yes well you see I thought the `Sydney Morning Herald' could grasp the sense of occasion about the national economy and the Budget. But apparently this seems to be a disease of the Fairfax organisation.
I should mention that the National Times on Sunday is a Fairfax publication. He went on:

And I only make the obvious point that I'm not privy to any taxpayer's affairs-that's a matter for the Tax Commissioner. And therefore I think the implication in your question which probably is by implication a slight upon the taxpayer you mentioned whose tax affairs I am totally unaware of.
I understand that to be the transcript, although it does not necessarily make sense. I raise that question. I raise also a question by Mr Peter Reith in the other place in which he said:

I refer the Treasurer to an article in last Sunday's National Times on Sunday in which it is suggested that he sold antique clocks at inflated prices to his friend, the property developer, Mr Warren Anderson, thereby deriving an improper personal benefit. In view of the high responsibilities of his office and the need for total confidence in his integrity, what steps does the Treasurer intend to take to answer these and other allegations contained in the article?

I was obliged to read that question because the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) asked me what allegations were made in the article. Having been obliged to do so, I now say that it seems at least that the Treasurer-by the way, his reply was of no consequence to the substance of the question-should either reject outright the matters raised in the article, which he has so far failed to do-

TALK.START.PARA: —Or be found guilty. Is that what you are saying?
—No, I am not suggesting that he should be found guilty by this or any other place.
—That is what you are saying, if he does not answer.

—I am suggesting that the Treasurer has a duty either to concede, if some things are true, that there is some truth in them, or to deny them, if there is no truth in them. To leave these substantial allegations unanswered and uncommented on is quite unsatisfactory. For the benefit of Senator Grimes, one of the other allegations related to the Treasurer's providing a reference for Mr Warren Anderson, who was found guilty in a court case of importing a loaded revolver into Australia, which clearly breached the licence conditions attached to that revolver.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, these are matters of great substance and of great seriousness, or at least they appear to be. If in fact the suggestions, statements, innuendos or whatever they are in this article are not correct, surely the Treasurer has a duty to the people of Australia, apart from us in this place, to establish that his credibility cannot be questioned. For example, the Budget just brought down rests very heavily on the credibility of the figures contained in it and on the man who presented it. Australia's status internationally depends very heavily on the credibility of the Treasurer. I am certainly not damaging his credibility because any damage which has been done to it has been done by those people who have read this article and who believe its contents, none of which so far have been repudiated by the Treasurer. On the occasions when the Treasurer has had the opportunity to repudiate elements of it, he has decided against doing so. That is his decision. All I am saying is that it is a matter of concern to me, having been subjected to the sort of criticism which has been unsubstantiated but perpetual in this chamber and having responded to it. I respond to it by providing the facts and by reading segments of reports that magically manage to evade the eyes of those people who choose to attack me improperly, unfairly and scurrilously in this chamber. I am prepared to respond because I have nothing to hide. I have a report by the government inspector--

TALK.START.PARA: —The person you are talking about has nothing to hide.

—I am glad that I have the support of Senator Georges because if the person involved has nothing to hide he should not damage his standing, particularly his standing as Treasurer and as a result indirectly, I submit, the standing of Australia because of the very significant position he occupies, by failing to deal with these very serious allegations. It would be simple to deny some of these things if in fact they are not so. For example, there was a suggestion-we will call it an allegation to suit Senator Grimes-that the Treasurer and another person borrowed more money from the Local Government Superannuation Board than the value of the property involved and that some of his mates-I do not know whether they were little or big mates-from his time in the Municipal and Shire Council Employees Union and the right wing of the Labor Party in New South Wales were on the board of that group. If those things are not correct, for heaven's sake should not the Treasurer say so? To leave them unanswered and up in the air seems to me to be extraordinary.

SPEECH.PARA: There is also a suggestion that the Treasurer has not lived in what was described in the last travel allowance list as his home base. For some extraordinary reason that list came out 17 months ago. I do not know why the TA list is so obviously late. I do not know what the Government has to hide by not providing the TA list of what people list as their home base, but in the last list, which came out in March 1985, the Treasurer gave Elizabeth Bay as his home base. In fact, that is listed as his home in the statement of interest for all members of the House of Representatives that came out during the week. As I understand it, interviews in the past have suggested and statements in the newspapers have said that the Treasurer lives in Canberra with his family because his duties keep him in Canberra so much. There may be a simple and proper explanation, but this newspaper suggests that there is an improper one. Would it not be a good idea, if there is a simple and proper explanation outlining why the Treasurer's last statement gave Sydney as his home base, and as the Government has not brought out a travel allowance statement for 17 months, for him to say whether it is still his home base? I stress to the Senate that I have no knowledge of whether these allegations are correct. I have no desire to give them some special status, as Senator Georges is suggesting I am. What I am saying is that there is a duty on the Treasurer to answer these very serious allegations. Until they are answered, there is serious doubt. For example, this question of taking profits on the sale of clocks, which is alleged in this publication, I suppose can be related to an interview that the Treasurer had with the ABC program Four Corners on 18 August in which he said that back in the 1970s when he first started collecting these clocks they were really around for nothing and that buying them did not involve much money. He said that they have massively appreciated. It is interesting in the terms of the new tax arrangements that they have massively appreciated, because they are excluded-

TALK.START.PARA: —When did he sell them?
—Order! The honourable senator is out of his place and is not entitled to interject.

—I do not know whether the interjection is also out of place, but I do not know when he sold them. I have no idea. I do not know how accurate the allegations are; all I know is that they have been made and that they have been a matter of public discussion. He was interviewed on the ABC program Four Corners and was asked about taking profits and so on. Obviously, intention, when buying an item, is of some moment when clearly there is an indication that significant profits can be taken on the sale of an asset which has appreciated. That simply may well show the good taste and good sense of the Treasurer and also his knowledge of the tax laws, but the reality is that there are allegations in this document relating to the sale of these clocks to Mr Warren Anderson. As I say, I have no idea. All I want to know, and I think the Australian people have a right to know, is whether these allegations can be rejected out of hand by the Treasurer, as I believe they should be if they can be, or whether there is some substance to them. Even if some of the facts are right, the inference or gloss put upon them by this kind of headline or story may be totally wrong. If that is so, surely we could expect a man in such a significant position to deal with that sort of matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The Special Minister of State (Mr Young) was obliged to stand down for some period. He was in serious trouble over a Paddington Bear, for heaven's sake, so does not that kind of experience and the sort of standard that obviously people expect of their parliamentarians require some kind of response in this case? I simply say to Senator Georges that his actions force me to retail some of the allegations. I had intended to refer the Senate to the article without retailing it. As I started off saying, I had no intention of retailing them--

TALK.START.PARA: —You did not really.

—Indeed, and Senator Georges can take the credit for my being obliged to make the point I am making, for forcing me to retail some of the matters, the merit of which I have no idea whatsoever. Given that situation I believe the Treasurer has a duty to us to respond.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since Senator Michael Baume has taken me to task I will have to respond. I thought I was giving him good advice on the matter of tabling documents, because he may have misused the processes of the Senate. But as he spoke it became fairly obvious that he was going to disclose the contents of that article because his purpose was maliciously to attack the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and to put on the record, under privilege, some allegations that have been made which, if they had been made about you, you would not have dignified them with a reply.
—Order! I suggest to Senator Georges that he address his remarks through the Chair and not direct to Senator Michael Baume.
—I am only looking at him.
—You are also speaking to him.

—I will look at you, Mr President, and speak to him. You have diverted me somewhat. I was about to say that the honourable senator himself has been subject to a number of attacks in this place over the years. I recall the Senate Select Committee on Securities and Exchange inquiry. I recall certain allegations that were made about him, and I thought those allegations were unfair. Of course they were made under privilege and he had no means of responding. I would have thought that that experience would have led him to be much more cautious about what he does to others, but that is not the case.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me go back and repeat some of the words I said previously. This chamber is not here for the purpose of using privilege in the manner in which it has just been used. It has the capacity to rebound. There are a couple of examples where a person who has used this place to attack others has suddenly found himself at the receiving end. It is not very edifying--

TALK.START.PARA: —I have attacked nobody.
—Well, you have just given us--
—And Senator Grimes knows that.

—The honourable senator has just given us a good example. All I am suggesting is that it was a very pathetic attempt to give further currency to some unfounded allegations against the Treasurer. I would say that the Treasurer has no responsibility in this matter and he ought not to answer. That is my view of it. When people make such unfounded allegations they ought not to be dignified by a reply. What the honourable senator has tried to do is to build a case against the Treasurer in a rather pathetic and undignified way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Monday I had a conversation with a very senior and very conservative journalist and commentator in this place. He asked me whether I had read the article to which Senator Michael Baume has referred in the National Times on Sunday, and I said I had. His view was, and it is my view, that that article is in fact a very lengthy dissertation on one Warren Anderson and the alleged association with the Treasurer (Mr Keating). But, as the journalist said, upon reading the article I found there were in fact no substantive allegations in it at all. It is a typical article by that newspaper which tries to play on the fact that the Treasurer was apparently a friend of Mr Anderson, and tries to make some references to the fact that the Treasurer has a clock collection and buys and sometimes sells clocks. It must be the most publicised clock collection in the whole country. There has never been any secret about it.

SPEECH.PARA: The article claims that Mr Anderson is under investigation for tax, but does not say that the Treasurer has any association with that or anything to do with that, and it makes some claim that the Treasurer at some time or other made a reference for Mr Anderson. I think they were the things that Senator Michael Baume referred to tonight. But it was the judgment of this senior and, as I say, very politically conservative journalist, that that sort of article was typical of the sorts of articles that have been produced in this newspaper for some time. But when I read it there was plenty of innuendo and no substance at all. The Treasurer has apparently chosen not to respond to the article and, as Senator Georges said, I do not blame him.

Plenty of newspapers write articles such as this. They even write worse articles than this. In fact people on both sides of this place have had scurrilous things written about them in a well known Melbourne newspaper, but I do not think anyone has ever responded to them, nor should they. In fact I know that no one in my time in here has ever raised any of those articles in this place about anybody else and nor should they. I will refer the matters that Senator Baume has raised to the Treasurer. I cannot guarantee him an answer.

Let me just say something else. I believe there is all the difference in the world in standing up in here and producing articles such as this and making speeches of this type, and even attempting in a feeble way to blame Senator Georges and, I suppose, me for refusing leave to table the document. There is a custom in this place that before leave is sought an honourable senator at least asks the relevant Minister in the place if it is okay to table it. That was not done. Maybe Senator Michael Baume does not know the customs in this place. He has not been here long and he does not know the customs. I suggest to him that there is all the difference in that and the sort of argy-bargy that goes on in this place both from me and from him in the heat of the moment and by interjection. I defy Senator Baume ever to find a time when I have made the sorts of accusations which I am never proud of in this place, other than in response to a remark by him, usually about someone in this place. I remember one beautiful Thursday when the honourable senator got up and made a scurrilous attack on the previous Australian Labor Party speaker here.

TALK.START.PARA: —I accused him of reading his speech. How scurrilous!
—The honourable senator said more than that.
—I said he was reading his speech and no more than that. That is an absolute lie. That is a lie.
—Order! The honourable senator will withdraw that remark.
—I am not worried about asking for withdrawals.
—I withdraw, Mr President.
—I never ask for withdrawals either; I just think it is nonsense.
—Order! It is not the Minister's place to ask for a withdrawal. The Chair is directing a withdrawal.

—Okay. There are always times in this place when people say vigorous things and I am one of those who do it. Make no bones about it, I will respond in kind at any time. But there is all the difference in the world in that sort of behaviour-in getting up here and producing a document of that type and trying to blame the Government for the fact that the honourable senator had to read what he claims are allegations in it and making a smear attack on the Treasurer. If that is the way he wants to do things, I do not mind-I think there is all the difference in the world in getting up here and cold bloodedly making a speech and accusations of impropriety against someone on the other side, and the sorts of things that are sometimes shouted across this place. Of course we all say things in here in interjection in the heat of the moment that we regret. I have regretted it many times but I have always said that I will do it only in response to something that comes from the other side, and that is true. The honourable senator can check the Hansard. It is true every time. But I do not get up here and produce documents from the National Times on Sunday, the Toorak Times, the Truth or any of those newspapers.
—You just tell lies.

—Senator Walters says that that is lies. She cannot cite one example of when I have got up here and read something from a scurrilous document of that type. Sometimes in interjection across this place some of the things I have said of course have not been true. But I have not gone out in the streets of Hobart and told lies about me in the way that Senator Walters has done. Senior members of the medical profession in Hobart have told me about the scurrilous nonsense she has said about me. I have not asked her for an apology because they do not take her seriously as they know what she is like. So let us have our interjections and vigorous debates, but let us not come in here with the Toorak Times, the National Times on Sunday or the Truth and repeat the sort of stuff that is written in them and say that it is up to every senator or member of this Parliament who has this sort of thing written about him or her to get up and reply to it. If we do that, we help the people who write this sort of stuff and we increase the circulation of the Toorak Times, the Melbourne Truth and the National Times on Sunday.

SPEECH.PARA: What sort of behaviour will there be in this place if every time someone has something of that type written about him or her, he or she has to get up here and explain it? I think it is significant that that article came out last Sunday and I think we should look at the names of the people who chose to bring up those articles in this place. They will be judged by their peers and everybody else. As I say, I will refer the matter to the Treasurer, but I cannot guarantee a reply.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Grimes, in his usual fashion, has stood up here tonight and told the untruths that he admits he does in this place. I do not believe that that is an excuse for standing up here and repeating untruths. I do not tell untruths in this place and for him to stand here tonight and admit that he does, then to continue on, is quite unforgivable and is no excuse, whether it is in the heat of the moment or otherwise, and he should pull himself together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation, Mr President.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said tonight that I had had reported to me by people in Hobart that Senator Walters had had certain things said about me. I once confronted Senator Walters with such an accusation and her response was that the person who had allegedly said it, for some reason or other, was not responsible for what she said. I have since found that that is not true. Senator Walters can go on with this nonsense as long as she likes, but there are people who have heard what she has said and have retailed what she has said to me and to others. Maybe she does not know what she says sometimes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation, Mr President.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Grimes is not telling the truth. He is incapable of telling the truth in this place or in any other place. What he said to me and what I said to him was that what he had been told was not true. The person who he said had relayed the untruth to him was not capable-I agree with him that that is what I said-and it was recognised that that person was not capable. Senator Grimes throws his hands in the air, but he has said in this place tonight-I am very pleased to have it in Hansard-that he does stand up and tell untruths in the heat of the moment.
—No, I didn't say that.

—That is exactly what Senator Grimes said and he will not change it in Hansard, because that is indeed what he said. It is quite accurate; for once, it is quite accurate. He does stand up here and tell untruths. According to him, it is in the heat of the moment. But I do not believe that. It is all planned. Senator Grimes really is quite irresponsible in this place, completely irresponsible.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.05 p.m.
