ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian National Gallery: Touring Exhibitions and Loans

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, upon notice, on 11 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the policy of the Australian National Gallery in regard to-
(b) loans to State and regional galleries.
(2) How many touring exhibitions were organised for 1985 and 1986.
(3) What special touring exhibition plans are in place in readiness for 1988.
(4) What financial provision is being developed for this commitment.
(5) What is the budget allocation for touring exhibitions in the current financial year.
(6) How many works are on loan throughout Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Australian National Gallery policy is to organise and manage touring exhibitions giving preference to localities not well served by major collections and varied exhibition programs. In general these exhibitions consist of less fragile works of art.

(b) The Gallery has a policy of lending to art museums and other institutions (including State and regional galleries) for exhibitions when it is considered that such loans would make a contribution to art and historical knowledge. Loans are not normally approved for works likely to deteriorate through travel.
(2) Two travelling exhibitions were organised for 1985 and three travelling exhibitions were organised for 1986.
(3) The National Gallery will lend extensively to the touring exhibitions planned by the Australian Bicentennial Authority.
(4) The Authority will meet the costs of touring exhibitions for the Bicentenary.
(6) The Gallery has more than 500 works of art on loan throughout Australia at any one time.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Territories, upon notice, on 30 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: How does the Government, in view of its stated aim of developing Australian industry and reducing our balance of payments deficit which will be at record levels this year, probably about $13 billion, explain the fact that the carpet in the new Parliament House will be made totally from New Zealand wool, despite the fact that Australia produces carpet wool of as high a standard as any in the world.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The carpets for the new Parliament House will not be made totally from New Zealand wool. Carpets of 100% Australian wool will be featured in the Cabinet Suites and the Main Committee Room.

As a Commonwealth agency the Parliament House Construction Authority (PHCA) is required to apply the provisions of the Closer Economic Relations Trade Agreement with New Zealand in calling tenders for work on the new Parliament House. This requires that New Zealand products be treated as if they were Australian.

In the case of carpets for the new building four tender packages were called on the basis of specifications developed by the Parliament in consultation with the Australian Wool Corporation. Tenderers were asked to indicate the source of the wool content of their tenders. There was no restriction on Australian carpet wool being tendered.

Following the evaluation of tenders it became apparent that the application of the tender procedures would result in no Australian carpet wool being used in the building. The Authority advised the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House of this situation and indicated that one or two areas of the building could be exempted from the general tender provisions.

The Committee subsequently decided to ask PHCA to negotiate with the relevant contractor so that the Cabinet Suite and Main Committee Room would have carpets of 100% Australian wool. Both areas are significant spaces in the building.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 7 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are the fortunes of some Australian farmers being adversely affected by the tactics of certain Australian banks.
(2) Are certain banks adding an extra margin for risks to farm interest rates; if so, which banks have been identified by the Federal Government in this regard.
(3) Are certain banks failing to pass on the benefits of falling interest rates to the agricultural community; if so, which banks have been identified in this regard.
(4) Are certain banks attempting to recoup money by prematurely foreclosing on farmers; if so, which banks have been identified in this regard.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The major Australian banks provide the majority of finance to the rural sector. I understand that rural finance forms about 10% of their business and the banks have assured me on a number of occasions that they are committed to supporting the sector.

The level of lending and the interest rates charged by banks are matters for their own commercial judgment, having regard to the risk involved with each customer and proposal. As part of these normal commercial practices, banks set interest rates in light of the security offered, the commercial prospects of a proposal and the business standing of the borrower. For example, the prime or reference interest rate on overdrafts is the rate charged to corporate clients of the highest standing. Interest rates for other customers are usually set slightly above this reflecting higher risks which may be associated with various lending proposals. An issue which your question raises is whether farmers are being charged margins for risk which might be considered excessive. I am advised, in this regard, that there is no difference in the setting of interest rates to farmers and other business borrowers with similar prospects.

I would also note that, as a result of the deregulation of the financial system, banks and other financial institutions are offering a greater range of financial packages to the borrowers. This development means that farmers are now better placed to obtain financial facilities suited to their individual circumstances and needs.

(3) I am advised that the main consideration by the banks in setting interest rates is the market cost of funds. Depending on the mix of borrowing facilities, the cost of funds between individual banks can vary from time to time leading to variations in interest rates on offer by different institutions.

(4) I have been assured on a number of occasions that the banks consider the best way to maintain their investment in rural Australia is to maintain farmers on the land. Only as a last resort will banks foreclose. I am informed that while procedures may vary from bank to bank such decisions are made only after the alternatives have been fully considered by senior bank management. The number of foreclosures which have occured have been miniscule when compared with the number of Australian farmers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, upon notice, on 11 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Crown of Thorns starfish in plague proportions on the Great Barrier Reef.
(2) Are Cod and Parrot fish the only 2 predators of the starfish and are they in low numbers because of fishing.
(3) What action is being taken by the Commonwealth Government to protect the Reef.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The crown of thorns starfish currently infests about 2% of reefs on the Great Barrier Reef (GBR), according to a survey of 220 reefs conducted by the Australian Institute of Marine Science in 1985. (An `infestation' or aggregation of starfish is defined as more than 40 starfish seen in a dive.)

In the 1985 survey no infestations were found in the Far Northern Section of the GBR (41 reefs surveyed), Cairns and Cormorant Pass Sections (64 reefs surveyed), and Southern Section (64 reefs surveyed). In the Central Section off Townsville, 7% of reefs surveyed had infestations. This represents a significant decrease from the apparent extreme period between 1982-1984 when about 34% of the Central Section reefs were infested. During that period the overall infestation rate in the Great Barrier Reef region was about 16%.

(2) There has never been any scientific record of either cod (grouper) or parrot fish preying on crown of thorns starfish. (There is an unverified report of crown of thorns remains being found in a cod, but they are considered highly unlikely predators of starfish.) The only fish ever reported eating adult crown of thorns are a species of pufferfish and two species of triggerfish. None of these fish are normally caught by fishermen. Parrotfish, abundant on all reefs, are also not normally caught by fishermen. The tusk fish (wrasses) are sometimes mistakenly referred to as parrotfish and are commonly caught and eaten. However they are not known to prey on crown of thorns starfish. Several shrimps and the giant triton shell are also confirmed predators of the crown of thorns starfish. The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority is currently funding studies on the predators of this starfish.

(3) The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority (GBRMPA), which was established under the GBRMP Act 1975 for the protection of the GBR, has been centrally involved in the crown of thorns starfish issue.

The Authority has funded research on the starfish since its reappearance on the Reef in 1979 and has monitored its spread using visitors' reports. The comprehensive database obtained from these reports was expanded substantially in 1985 by a survey conducted by the Australian Institute of Marine Science.

In 1984 GBRMPA convened an expert committee, the Crown of Thorns Starfish Advisory Committee to review the situation. As a result of this Committee's recommendations, the Government granted GBRMPA $971,000 in 1985-86 for the first year of an intensive four year research program.

The Authority has mounted a comprehensive research program involving more than fifty of Australia's senior research scientists in what is probably the most concerted, coordinated research on a single problem ever to have been undertaken in Australia's seas. Although removal of the starfish from the GBR is obviously impossible (one heavily infested reef may have several million starfish) the Authority has conducted localized controls and assisted tourist operators in several other controls. It has recently conducted a trial program on an infested reef off Townsville using Royal Australian Navy divers to determine if localized areas can be kept free of the starfish.
